editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE TRIAL OF William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, FOR THE MURDER OF Cri≈øpus Attucks, Samuel Gray, Samuel Maverick, James Caldwell, and Patrick Carr.
The Indictment was as follows.
div.p: AT his Maje≈øty's Superior Court of Judicature, Court of A≈ø≈øize and general Goal Delivery, begun and held at Bo≈øton, within, and for the County of Suffolk, on the ≈øecond Tue≈øday of March, in the tenth year of the reign of GEORGE the THIRD, by the Grace of GOD, of Great-Britain, France and Ireland, King, defender of the Faith, &c.

The Jurors for the ≈øaid Lord the King, upon their oath pre≈øent, that Thomas Pre≈øton, E≈øq William Wemms labourer, James Hartegan labourer, William M'Cauley labourer, Hugh White labourer, Matthew Killroy labourer, William Warren labourer, John Carroll labourer, and Hugh Montgomery labourer, all now re≈øident in Bo≈øton, in the county of Suffolk, and Hammond Green boat builder, Thomas Greenwood labourer, Edward Manwaring, E≈øq and John Munroe, Gentleman, all of Bo≈øton afore≈øaid, not having the fear of God before their eyes, but being moved and ≈øeduced by the in≈øtigation of the devil and their own wicked hearts, did, on the fifth day of this in≈øtant March, at Bo≈øton afore≈øaid, within the county afore≈øaid, with force and arms, feloniou≈øly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, a≈ø≈øault one Cri≈øpus Attucks, then and there being in the peace of God,
and of the ≈øaid Lord the King, and that he the ≈øaid William Warren, with a certain hand gun of the value of twenty ≈øhillings, which he the ≈øaid William Warren the ‚Ä¢ and there held in both his hands, charged with gun powder and two leaden bullets, then and there, feloniou≈øly, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought, did ≈øhoot off, and di≈øcharge at and again≈øt the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus Attucks, and that the ≈øaid William Warren, with the leaden bullets as afore≈øaid, out of the ≈øaid hand gun, then and there by force of the ≈øaid gun powder, ≈øo ≈øhot off and di≈øcharged as afore≈øaid, did then and there, feloniou≈øly, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought ≈øtrike, penetrate, and wound the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus Attucks in and upon the right brea≈øt, a little below the right pap of him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, and in and upon the left brea≈øt, a little below the left pap of him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, thereby giving to him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, with one of the bullets afore≈øaid, ≈øo ≈øhot off and di≈øcharged as afore≈øaid, in and upon the right brea≈øt, a little below the right pap of him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, one mortal wound of the depth of ≈øix inches, and of the width of one inch; and al≈øo thereby giving to him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, with the other bullet afore≈øaid, ≈øo ≈øhot off and di≈øcharged by the ≈øaid William Warren as afore≈øaid, in and upon the left brea≈øt, a little below the left pap of him the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus, one other mortal wound, of the depth of ≈øix inches, and of the width of one inch, of which ≈øaid mortal wounds, the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus Attucks then and there in≈øtantly died; and that the afore≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, John Carroll, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manwaring, and John Munroe, then and there, feloniou≈øly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, were pre≈øent, aiding, helping, abetting, comforting, a≈ø≈øi≈øting, and maintaining the ≈øaid William Warren, to do and commit the felony and murder afore≈øaid.

And ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their ≈øaid oath, do ≈øay, that the ≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, Hugh Montgomery, Hammond Green, Thomas Greenwood, Edward Manw ‚Ä¢ ring, and John Munroe, then and there in manner and form afore≈øaid, feloniou≈øly, wilfully, and of their malice aforethought, did kill and
murder the ≈øaid Cri≈øpus Attucks, again≈øt the peace of the ≈øaid Lord the King, his crown and dignity.
div.bibl: JON. SEWALL, Att. pro Dom. Rege. This is a true Bill. WM. TAYLOR, Foreman.
div.p: At the ≈øame Court the ≈øaid James Hartegan was indicted for the murder of Samuel Gray; and the ≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, E≈øq William Wemms, William M'Cauley, Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carroll, and Hugh Montgomery, for being pre≈øent, aiding, helping and abetting the ≈øaid James Hartegan to do and commit the felony and murder afore≈øaid.

And at the ≈øame Court the ≈øaid Matthew Killroy, was indicted for the murder of one Samuel Maverick; and the ≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery, for being pre≈øent aiding, helping, abetting, and a≈ø≈øi≈øting the ≈øaid Matthew Killroy, to do and commit the felony and murder afore≈øaid.

And at the ≈øame Court the ≈øaid John Carrol was indicted for the murder of one James Caldwell; and the ≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, William Wemms, William M'Cauley, James Hartegan, Hugh White, William Warren, and Hugh Montgomery, for being pre≈øent aiding, helping, abetting, and a≈ø≈øi≈øting the ≈øaid John Carrol to do and commit the felony and murder afore≈øaid.

And at the ≈øame Court the ≈øaid Hugh White was indicted for the murder of one Patrick Carr; and the ≈øaid Thomas Pre≈øton, William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol, and Hugh Montgomery for being pre≈øent aiding, helping, abetting, and a≈ø≈øi≈øting the ≈øaid Hugh White to do and commit the felony and murder afore≈øaid.
On Saturday, the 27th November, 1770, the Court being met, the pri≈øoners were brought into Court and ≈øet to the bar, when the Court proceeded thus.

sp.p: Pri≈øoners hold up your hands. Gentlemen of the Jury look upon the pri≈øoners, and hearken to the charge. (The Clerk then read the ≈øeveral indictments again≈øt them as before ≈øet forth.) Upon each and every of the≈øe ≈øeveral indictments. the pri≈øoners at the bar have been arraigned, and upon their arraignment have pleaded not guilty, and for trial have put them≈øelves upon God and their country, which country you are; your charge therefore is, to enquire whether they or either of them be guilty of the felony and murder whereof they ≈øtand indicted, or not guilty. If they or either of them are guilty, you are to ≈øay ≈øo; if they or either of them are not guilty, you are to ≈øay ≈øo and no more. Good men and true, ≈øtand together and hearken to your evidence.

div.stage: Samuel Quincy, E≈øq addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf to the Court and Jury, opened the cau≈øe nearly in the following words:

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe your Honours, and you Gentlemen of the Jury.

div.p: THE pri≈øoners at the bar, are that party of ≈øoldiers belonging to his Maje≈øty's 29th regiment, who in the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt, were induced from ≈øome cau≈øe or other to fire on the inhabitants of this town, in King ≈øtreet.

They are charged in five di≈øtinct indictments, with the wilful premeditated murder of five different per≈øons mentioned in the re≈øpective bills; to each of the≈øe indictments, they have ≈øeverally pleaded, not guilty; and by that plea have thrown upon the crown the burthen of proving the fact alledged again≈øt them: It is my province therefore to give you evidence in ≈øupport of this charge, and yours, gentlemen of the Jury, to determine whether they are guilty, or not.

The cau≈øe is ≈øolemn and important; no le≈øs than whether eight of your fellow ≈øubjects ≈øhall live or die! A cau≈øe grounded on the mo≈øt melancholy event that has yet taken place on the continent of America, and perhaps of the greate≈øt expectation of any that has yet come before a tribunal of civil ju≈øtice, in this part of the Briti≈øh dominions.

I am aware how difficult, in ca≈øes of this ≈øort, it ever is, and more e≈øpecially ≈øo in the≈øe times, and in this trial, to pre≈øerve the mind perfectly indifferent; but I remember, we are bound, not only by the natural obligations towards God and man, but al≈øo by an oath, to examine into the evidence of fact without partiality or prejudice; I need not therefore caution you of your duty in this re≈øpect: It is upon that evidence and the law re≈øulting from it, you gentlemen are, in the language of your oath, to give a verdict; and I will venture, before hand, to pronounce that verdict righteous, if it is founded in the≈øe principles as the rule of your judgment.

It has become my duty, it ≈øhall therefore be my endeavor, to acquit my≈øelf in the cour≈øe of this trial with
decency and candour; reflecting, that however intere≈øting the que≈øtion may be, the object of our enquiry is ≈øimply that of truth, and that this enquiry is to be conducted by the wi≈ødom of the laws and con≈øtitution.

In ≈øupport of this accu≈øation again≈øt the pri≈øoners at the bar, it is incumbent on the crown, to a≈øcertain the following things; viz. The indentity of the per≈øons charged; the fact of killing; and the circum≈øtances attending and aggravating that fact.

To this end, I ≈øhall immediately produce to you ≈øuch evidence, from the te≈øtimony of credible witne≈ø≈øes, as may be ≈øufficient to ≈øu≈øtain the ≈øeveral indictments, and when I have gone through the examination, make ≈øuch remarks upon it, as may be mo≈øt conci≈øe and pertinent to the pre≈øent i≈ø≈øue.
The following witne≈ø≈øes were then ≈øworn and examined in their order.
div.stage: Jonathan Williams Au≈øtin, clerk to John Adams, E≈øq ≈øworn.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Do you know either of the pri≈øoners at the bar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Which of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: M'Cauley.‚ÄîI knew the man before, but did not know his name; I was afterwards told it was M'Cauley. On the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt, I heard the bells ring, and immediately went into King-≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many people do you imagine might be there when you got into King-≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There might be twenty or thirty I believe.‚ÄîI ≈øaw the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe door ≈øwinging his gun and bayonet; there were a parcel of men and boys round him. I de≈øired them to come away, and not mole≈øt the Sentry: Some of them came off and went to the middle of the ≈øtreet; I then left them and went up towards the Main-Guard. Immediately a party came down, I walked by the ≈øide of them till I came to the Sentry box at the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe. M'Cauley then got to the right of the Sentry-box; he was then loading his piece.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near was you to M'Cauley at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was about four feet off: M'Cauley ≈øaid "Damn you, ≈øtand off," and pu≈øhed his bayonet at me: I did ≈øo:‚ÄîImmediately I heard the report of a gun.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did M'Cauley ≈øtand to the corner?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He came round the Sentry-box, and ≈øtood clo≈øe to it on the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When the party came down, were there many people there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot really ≈øay, I think about fifty or ≈øixty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did they ≈øay to the people as they came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear them ≈øay any thing.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any orders given?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not, either to load or fire.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear the Sen ‚Ä¢ y cry out for help to the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; I was not there half a minute.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabouts did you ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øtood in≈øide the gutter, clo≈øe by the box.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabout did the Sentry-box ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Three or four feet from the corner of the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many guns did you hear?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Five or ≈øix, I cannot ≈øwear to any particular number.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you look round after you heard the guns fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee M'Cauley then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was he loading again?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he was; it ≈øo lies in my mind; (I cannot ab≈øolutely ≈øwear it.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether any ≈øoldiers ≈øtood on the right of M'Cauley?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took ≈øo particular notice of M'Cauley, that I minded no other object.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners at the bar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I particularly ≈øaw that tall man, (pointing to Warren, one of the pri≈øoners.) Next day after the firing in K. ≈øtreet, I ≈øaw more of them whom I cannot particularly ≈øwear to now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the ≈øoldiers before the ju≈øtices on examination?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you then ob≈øerve you had ≈øeen any of them the night before in King-≈øtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was well per≈øuaded next day in my own mind, that I ≈øaw that tall one; but a few days after, I ≈øaw another man belonging to the ≈øame regiment, ≈øo very like him, that I doubt whither I am not mi≈øtaken with regard to him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there any other of the party you knew?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am well ≈øatisfied I ≈øaw the Corporal there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee White there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the ≈øituation of the Corporal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was the corner man at the left of the party.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee either of the per≈øons, you think you know, di≈øcharge their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; the man I take to be the tall man, di≈øcharged his piece as it was upon a level.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the Corporal di≈øcharge his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was behind them in the circle.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What part of the circle did the tall man ≈øtand in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ≈øtood next but one to the Corporal. The tall man whoever he was, was the man I ≈øaw di≈øcharge his piece.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing thrown at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there were many things thrown, what they were I cannot ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How did the Soldiers ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ≈øtood with their pieces before them to defend them≈øelves; and as ≈øoon as they had placed them≈øelves, a party, about twelve in number, with ≈øticks in their hands, who ≈øtood in the middle of the ≈øtreet, gave three cheers, and immediately ≈øurrounded the ≈øoldiers, and ≈øtruck upon their guns with their ≈øticks, and pa≈ø≈øed along the front of the ≈øoldiers, towards Royal exchange-lane, ≈øtriking the ≈øoldiers guns as they pa≈ø≈øed; numbers were continually coming down the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any per≈øon take hold of any of the guns or bayonets of any of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any particular words from this party of twelve.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard no particular words, there was ≈øuch a noi≈øe I could not di≈øtingui≈øh any words.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did they load their guns before the people ≈øurrounded them, or after?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were loading at the time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did they go to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Very near them, almo≈øt clo≈øe to their guns.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the people who ≈øtruck the guns, there at the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay whether they had gone away or not.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you apprehend the ≈øoldiers in danger, from any thing you ≈øaw?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not, indeed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Where did you ≈øtand at the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I kept my place. At the time of the firing of the fir≈øt gun, I heard a clattering noi≈øe on the right like one gun ≈øtriking again≈øt another, and immediately the fir≈øt gun was fired from the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time of firing that gun was any a≈ø≈øault made on the per≈øon that fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ≈øee the per≈øon that fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ≈øaid, you ≈øaw ≈øeveral blows ≈øtruck upon the guns, I ≈øhould like you would make it more plain.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw the people near me on the left, ≈øtrike the ≈øoldiers guns, daring them to fire, and called them cowardly ‚Ä¢ a≈ø ‚Ä¢ ls, for bringing arms again≈øt naked men; bid them lay a≈øide their guns, and they were their men.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any per≈øon fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw Gray fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He fell in the middle of the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the place where he fell nearly oppo≈øite to the tall man you talk of?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; the gun that killed him, mu≈øt have been nearer to the center. When the ≈øoldiers on the left fired, there were fewer people on the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee a molatto among tho≈øe per≈øons who ≈øurrounded the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ob≈øerve.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they ≈øeem to be ≈øailors or town's men.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were dre≈ø≈øed ≈øome of them in the habits of ≈øailors.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any bell ring?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What bell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe all the bells in town were ringing, I heard the Old South fir≈øt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the clattering or blows on the guns to the right, immediately before the fir≈øt gun went off, appear very violent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very violent.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was the ≈øecond gun fired from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be the per≈øon next to him who fired the fir≈øt, or very near him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Betwixt the fir≈øt and ≈øecond gun, did you ≈øee any a≈ø≈øault given to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: When the firing came along to the left, were there many people in the ≈øtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were very few people then in the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What place did tho≈øe few ≈øtand in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Right over the way.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you looking at the per≈øon who fired the la≈øt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw him aim at a lad that was running down the middle of the ≈øtreet, and kept the motion of his gun after him a con≈øiderable time, and then fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the lad fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He did not, I kept ‚Ä¢ ay eye on him a con≈øiderable time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: This ≈øoldier was towards the left you ≈øay, was he quite to the left?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not quite, but towards it.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was the lad among the party that ≈øtruck at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was pa≈ø≈øing the ≈øtreet, I cannot ≈øay where he came from.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After the firing of the fir≈øt gun did the people di≈øper≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They drew away down Royal-exchange-lane, but others were coming continually down the ≈øtreet; but when the fir≈øt per≈øon was killed, they ≈øeemed all to draw off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people that came down the ≈øtreet, endeavour to join the party that was ≈øtriking the ≈øoldiers, or did they come becau≈øe of the ringing of the bells?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe they came becau≈øe the bells were ringing, for they came from all parts of the town, and did not appear to me to join in the a≈ø≈øault.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe ≈øeven.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many ≈øoldiers were of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not count them, but I believe twelve.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I know Warren, and ≈øaw him with the party in King-≈øtreet on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt‚Äî

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the re≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I know them all by ≈øight, but that is the only per≈øon I can ≈øwear to.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The night of the firing, did you ≈øee the Corporal there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not ≈øo as to know him; but Warren I can ≈øwear to.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee him di≈øcharge his piece?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No: I went away when the fir≈øt gun fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the per≈øon ≈øtand, who fired the fir≈øt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ≈øtood towards the left of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabout did you ≈øtand your≈øelf?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oppo≈øite the ≈øoldiers, by Mr. Warden's ≈øhop the barber.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw none fall. I went off when the fir≈øt gun was fired, and came back again and heard there were three men killed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you mean the fir≈øt gun was fired from your left, or from the left of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the left of the party; there were two ≈øtood to the left of Warren.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What appeared to be the conduct of the ≈øoldiers before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I got there, they were ≈øwinging there guns backward and forward, and ≈øeveral among the people, ≈øaid, fire, damn you fire; but I think it was Capt. Pre≈øton that gave the word to fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took them to be about fifty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What had they in their hands?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They had nothing in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ice or ≈ønow-balls thrown at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw ≈øeveral ≈ønow balls and pieces of ice thrown, and heard a rattling again≈øt the barrels of their guns, whether it was ≈øticks, or what, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the ≈ønow-balls ≈øeem to come from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From the people right before the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ≈ønow-balls ≈øeem to be thrown in anger?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know; I ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers pu≈øhing at the people before any ≈ønow balls were thrown.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the people pre≈ø≈øing on?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were very near, within reach of their bayonets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any oy≈øter-≈øhells thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ≈ønow trodden down, or melted away by the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, the ≈øtreet was all covered like a cake.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the pri≈øoners in King-≈øtreet on the 5th March.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, before the affray happened.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which of them was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was White. He was ≈øtanding Sentry at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe: he ≈øpoke to me, and a≈øked me how we all did at home. I immediately went home. Soon after I heard the bells ring, and went into King-≈øtreet. When I came there, the ≈øoldiers were drawn up by the Main Guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there at the time of the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you ≈øpoke to the Sentry, was there any body with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he was walking backwards and forwards by him≈øelf.

div.p: I am one of the Town watch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in King-≈øtreet that evening the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The bells began to ring, and the people cryed fire: I run with the re≈øt, and went into King-≈øtreet; I a≈øked where the fire was; I was told there was no fire, but that the ≈øoldiers at Murray's barracks had got out, and had been fighting with the inhabitants, but that they had drove them back again. I went to the barracks, and found the affair was over there. I came back, and ju≈øt as I got to the Town pump, I ≈øaw twenty or five and twenty boys going into King-≈øtreet. I went into King-≈øtreet my≈øelf, and ≈øaw ≈øeveral boys and young men about the Sentry box at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe. I a≈øked them what was the matter. They ≈øaid the Sentry had knocked down a boy. They crowded in over the gutter; I told them to let the Sentry alone. He went up the ≈øteps of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, and knocked at the door, but could not get in. I told him not to be afraid, they were only boys, and would not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the Sentry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is he among the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's he. (Pointing to White.)

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the re≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that man. (Pointing to Killroy.) The boys were ≈øwearing and ≈øpeaking bad words, but they threw nothing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they pre≈ø≈øing on him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were as far as the gutter, and he went up the ≈øteps and called out, but what he ≈øaid I do not remember.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did he call loud?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, pretty loud.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: To whom did he call?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know; when he went up the ≈øteps he levelled his piece with his bayonet fixed. As I was talking with the Sentry, and telling him not to be afraid, the ≈øoldiers came down, and when they came, I drew back from the Sentry towards Royal-exchange lane, and there I ≈øtood. I did not ≈øee them load, but ≈øomebody ≈øaid, are you loaded; and Samuel Gray, who was ≈øhot that night, came and ≈øtruck me on the ≈øhoulder, and ≈øaid, Langford, what's here to pay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øaid you to Gray then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaid I did not know what was to pay, but I believed ≈øomething would come of it by and bye. He made no reply. Immediately a gun went off. I was within reach of their guns and bayonets; one of them thru≈øt at me with his bayonet, and run it through my jacket and great coat.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was you then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Within three or four feet of the gutter, on the out≈øide.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who a≈øked, are you loaded?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know whether it was the ≈øoldiers or inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the word given to load?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard the que≈øtion a≈øked, whether they were loaded! but I heard no orders to load. Somebody then ≈øaid, are you all ready: I then heard the word given to fire, twice di≈øtinctly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there before the ≈øoldiers at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About forty or fifty, but there were numbers in the lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they nigh the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were not in the in≈øide of the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had any of the inhabitants ≈øticks or clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know. I had one my≈øelf, becau≈øe I was going to the watch, for I belong to the watch.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many ≈øoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not count the number of them, about ≈øeven or eight I think.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was it fired the fir≈øt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where about did he ≈øtand that fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ≈øtood on my right, as I ≈øtood facing them: I ≈øtood about half way betwixt the box and Royal-exchange-lane. I looked this man (pointing to Killroy) in the face, and bid him not fire; but he immediately fired, and Samuel Gray fell at my feet. Killroy thru≈øt his bayonet immediately through my coat and jacket;‚ÄîI ran towards the watch-hou≈øe, and ≈øtood there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did Killroy ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ≈øtood on the right of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he the right hand man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell I believe there were two or three on his right, but I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ≈øpoke to him you ≈øay before he fired, what did you ≈øay to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaid either damn you, or God damn you do not fire, and immediately he fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What in particular made you ≈øay do not fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hearing the other guns go off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns went off before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Two: but I ≈øaw nobody fall. Gray fell clo≈øe to me. I was ≈øtanding leaning on my ≈øtick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Gray ≈øay any thing to Killroy before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He ≈øpoke to nobody but me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he throw any ≈ønow balls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor he had no weapon in his hand; he was as naked as I am now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw nothing at all thrown of any kind.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you talking with Gray at the time the gun went off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ≈øpeak with him at that in≈øtant, but I had been talking with him ≈øeveral minutes before that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you ≈øo near Gray, that if he had thrown any thing you mu≈øt have ≈øeen it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, his hands were in his bo≈øom, and, immediately after Killroy's firing, he fell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any other gun at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: None, till I had got near to the watch-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were the people ≈øtanding to the ≈øoldiers, at the time that gun ≈øhot Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were ≈øtanding near the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing hit the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw nothing thrown. I heard the rattling of their guns, and took it to be one gun again≈øt another. this rattling was at the time Killroy fired, and at my right, I had a fair view of them; I ≈øaw no body ≈øtrike a blow nor offer a blow.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you any doubt in your own mind, that it was that gun of Killroy's that killed Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No manner of doubt; it mu≈øt have been it, for there was no other gun di≈øcharged at that time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know the Indian that was killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body pre≈øs on the ≈øoldiers with a large cord wood ≈øtick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After Gray fell, did he (Killroy) thru≈øt at him with his bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was at me he pu≈øhed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Gray ≈øay any thing to Killroy, or Killroy to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not to my knowledge, and I ≈øtood clo≈øe by him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you perceive Killroy take aim at Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not: he was as liable to kill me as him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who rung the bell at the Brick meeting hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body get in at the windows of the Brick meeting hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee what pa≈ø≈øed betwixt the ≈øoldiers and others at the barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ten minutes after nine, I ≈øaw a ≈øoldier, and a mean looking fellow with him, with a cu ‚Ä¢ la≈øs in his hand; they came up to me: ≈øomebody ≈øaid, put up your cutla≈øs, it is not right to carry it at this time of night. He ≈øaid, damn you ye Yankie bougers, what's your bu≈øine≈øs: he came up to another that was with me, and ≈øtruck him. We beat him back, when ≈øeven or eight ≈øoldiers came out of the barracks, with tongs and other weapons; one aimed a blow at a young fellow, John Hicks, who knocked the ≈øoldier down. As he attempted to ri≈øe, I ≈øtruck him down again, and broke his wri≈øt, as I heard afterwards. I went to King-≈øtreet, and when the guns were all fired, I ≈øaw ≈øeveral per≈øons dead.

div.p: N. B. The Court being unable to go through this trial in one day, the King's Attorney and the pri≈øoners con≈øented to the Court's adjourning over night during the Trial, the Jury being kept together in the mean time, by proper officers, appointed and ≈øworn by the Court for that purpo≈øe.

Wedne≈øday, NINE o'clock, the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Plea≈øe look upon the pri≈øoners, do you know any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I remember this man (pointing to Killroy.)

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and as I got to the head of it, I ≈øaw the Sentry on the ≈øteps of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, with his bayonet brea≈øt high, with a number of boys round him:
‚ÄîI called to him, and ≈øaid, I did not think any body was going to do him harm. I ≈øaw Capt. Pre≈øton and ≈øome ≈øoldiers come down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which of the pri≈øoners was the Sentry?

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How old were the≈øe boys?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did you take to be the rea≈øon that the Sentry charged his bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I could not tell what the rea≈øon was; there was no body troubling him. I was at the corner of Royal-exchange-lane, and a young man went up to the Sentry and ≈øpoke to him; what he ≈øaid I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was yo ‚Ä¢ there in the time of the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I went towards the Sentry-box, there I ≈øaw Capt. Pre≈øton. I ≈øaid to him, Sir, I hope you are not going to fire, for every body is going to their own homes. He ≈øaid I hope they are. I ≈øaw no more of him. He immediately went in among≈øt the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of ≈øoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think ≈øeven or eight, I did not count them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Capt. Pre≈øton lead or follow them down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he was upon the right of them. As they came down they had their guns charged brea≈øt high. I ≈øaw Chri≈øtopher Monk, who was wounded that night, I turned to ≈øpeak to him, and directly they fired, and he ≈øeemed to faulter. I ≈øaid are you wounded, he ≈øaid yes. sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it the fir≈øt gun that you thought wounded Monk?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Ju≈øt before the firing, when Killrey ≈øtruck you, was there any thing thrown at the ≈øoldiers then?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any people coming from Quaker-lane with ≈øticks?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had he a ≈øtick or club?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzas or cheers as they are called?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them call the ≈øoldiers any names?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any body ≈øay, kill them, damn them knock them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the whi≈øtling about the ≈øtreets at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any per≈øon ≈øtrike with a club at the ≈øoldiers or any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee them attempt to ≈øtrike their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a greater noi≈øe than u≈øual, when the bells rang for fire?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ≈øword naked or not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of a ≈øword was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did not Dr. Young ≈øay the ≈øoldiers were beat to their barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; He ≈øaid they had made a rumpus, and were gone to their barracks.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I do not remember to have ≈øeen any of the re≈øt?

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was ≈øtanding along with the Sentry, on the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe ≈øteps; I ≈øaw a number of boys round the Sentry.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Twenty or thirty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they all boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, none older than ≈øeventeen or eighteen years old.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any thing pa≈øs between you and the Sentry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, When I fir≈øt went up to him, I ≈øaid, what is the matter?‚Äîhe ≈øaid he did not know.‚ÄîThe boys were throwing pieces of ice at him, and after I went to him, they threw no more; I ≈øtood with him five or ≈øix minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he tell them to di≈øper≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he did not ≈øay a word to them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the pieces of ice hit him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was nothing thrown after I went to him; if any thing was thrown, it was before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How came you to go to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went up to him becau≈øe I knew him, and to ≈øee what was the matter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear him knock at the door?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he call for any a≈ø≈øi≈øtance?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that fir≈øt ≈øhot kill or wound any per≈øon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ice or ≈ønow thrown betwixt the fir≈øt and ≈øecond gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was a noi≈øe among the inhabitants, but I cannot ≈øay what they ≈øaid.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; Montgomery was knocked down with a ≈øtick, and his gun flew out of his hand, and when he recovered him≈øelf he di≈øcharged his gun.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you came to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, and ≈øaw the boys throwing ice, where did they ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of ≈øticks, do you ≈øuppo≈øe might be in the whole?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ≈øeven or eight I ≈øuppo≈øe; ≈øome of them whi≈øtling, ≈øome huzzaing and making a noi≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know their de≈øign?

sp.speaker: A

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ≈øoldiers about that time in the ≈øtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw a number at Murray's barracks, and ≈øome officers driving them in.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I know Montgomery, I ≈øaw him in King-≈øtreet with the party on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt. I was with ≈øome gentlemen in company, I heard the bells ring after 9 o'clock; I went into King-≈øtreet, and I ≈øaw the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe door as u≈øual, and no body with him: when I came to the Town-hou≈øe, I was told the ≈øoldiers were abu≈øing the inhabitants; I a≈øked where, and was told at Murray's barracks. I went down there, and ≈øaw four or five ≈øoldiers, with their guns and bayonets; I told the officer who ≈øtood by, I was ≈øurpri≈øed they ≈øuffered the ≈øoldiers to be out at that time of night; an officer ≈øaid, do you pretend to teach us our duty Sir, I ≈øaid no, only to remind you of it: You ≈øee, ≈øays he, the ≈øoldiers are in their barracks, why do not you go home. I ≈øaw Mr. Hickling, he was my neighbour, he ≈øaid he was going home, we came up as far
‚Ä¢ ns the po≈øt office, where he left me; then I ≈øaw Mr. Spear,
‚Ä¢ he ≈øaid he was going to his brother David's; when I got to the Town pump, I heard a noi≈øe, and was told there was a ‚Ä¢ rumpus at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe; I ≈øaid, I will go down and make peace, he ≈øaid, you had better not go. I left Mr. Spear, and went down, and ≈øaw Capt. Pre≈øton at the head of ≈øeven ‚Ä¢ or eight ≈øoldiers, with their guns, and bayonets fixed; I went to Capt. Pre≈øton, and ≈øaw Mr. Theodore Bli≈øs talking with him, who ≈øaid to Capt. Pre≈øton, "Why do you not fire," "God damn you fire." I ≈øtept betwixt them and a≈øked Capt. Pre≈øton if the ≈øoldiers were loaded, he ≈øaid yes, with powder and ball: I ≈øaid, I hope Sir you are not going to fire upon the inhabitants, he ≈øaid by no means: That in≈øtant I ≈øaw a piece of ice ≈øtrike Montgomery's gun, whether ‚Ä¢ t ≈øallied him back, or he ≈øtept one foot back. I do not know, but he recovered him≈øelf, and fired immediately. I thought he ≈øtept back and fired, he was the next man to Capt. Pre≈øton, the only ≈øoldier that was betwixt the Captain and the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe. When he fired, I heard the word fire, who gave it I do not know. Six or eight ≈øeconds after that, another ≈øoldier on the Captain's right fired, and then the re≈øt one after the other, pretty quick; there was an interval of two or three ≈øeconds, between the la≈øt gun but one, and the la≈øt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know certain, ≈øeven or eight I believe, I did not count them. Before the la≈øt gun was fired, Montgomery made a pu≈øh at me with his bayonet, I had a ≈øtick in my hand, as I generally walk with one, I ≈øtruck him, and hit his left arm, and knocked his gun down; before he recovered I aimed another ≈øtroke at the neare≈øt to me, and hit Capt. Pre≈øton, I then turned and ≈øaw Montgomery pu≈øhing at me again, and would have pu≈øhed me through, but I threw ‚Ä¢ ny ≈øtick in his face, and the third time he ran after me to pu≈øh at me again, but fell down, and I had an opportunity to run down Royal-exchange lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take notice of the ≈øituation of the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw the form they were in, they were formed in a half circle.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He fronted the watch hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øtand in a range with the watch hou≈øe and corner of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain that Montgomery was ≈øtruck and ≈øall ‚Ä¢ back before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether it was with a piece of ice or club?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know whether it hit his body, or his gun, „Äà‚óä„Äâ both?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any other violence offered, except th ‚Ä¢ which ≈øtruck Montgomery and the blows you ‚Ä¢ emed and gav ‚Ä¢

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, no other.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are you ≈øure Montgomery did not fall, „Äà‚óä„Äâ before h ‚Ä¢ di≈øcharged his gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Upon the firing the fir≈øt gun, did the people ≈øeem ‚Ä¢ retire?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the decea≈øed fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, I did not, but afterwards I ≈øaw Gray and Attu ‚Ä¢
lying.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee all the re≈øt of the ≈øoldiers di≈øcharge the ‚Ä¢ pieces?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw the ≈ømoke, and it appeared to me at that tim ‚Ä¢ they all fired.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: When the la≈øt gun was fired, where were the people

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were running promi≈øouou≈øly about every whe ‚Ä¢

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Call James Bailey again.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q

Are you ≈øatisfied, notwith≈øtanding what Mr Pal ‚Ä¢
≈øays, that Montgomery was knocked down by a blow give him, immediately before he fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the pri≈øoners at the Rope walks i ‚Ä¢ the affray there, a few days before the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw Carrol one of the pri≈øoners, there with other ≈øoldiers in that affray.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the≈øe two men of the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The bigge≈øt part of them had clubs,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of them afterwards in King-≈øtreet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not that I knew

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee a tall man at the head of them?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body with a ≈øword, at the bottom of Royal exchange lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were about as thick as one's wri≈øt.
I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and the fir≈øt I ≈øaw was Montgomery, I ≈øaw him pu≈øhing his bayonet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know Montgomery then?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes: I drew back about five feet, and I ≈øaw his gun go off.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I know Montgomery, he u≈øed to live clo≈øe by my hou≈øe; I know none of the re≈øt. I was at home the whole evening, the Old-≈øouth bell rung for nine as u≈øual; about a quarter after, I heard Mr. Cooper's bell ring, I went out and I ≈øaw the Old ≈øouth Engine haulled out. I ran down as far as the town-pump, there ≈øeemed to be a con≈øiderable body of people, and ≈øome with buckets. The people out of the chamber windows, ≈øaid, do not go down there, you will be killed.‚ÄîI ≈øaw ten or twelve ≈øoldiers with naked cutla≈ø≈øes by Boyl≈øton's alley:‚ÄîI ≈øaw them with their cutla≈ø≈øes and bayonets drawing up towards the people. I went back and ≈øtopped at the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were there a number of the town's people there at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, and many with buckets in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No they were ≈øtanding in the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were brandi≈øhing their ≈øwords and ≈øallying up to the people, but I did not tarry there one minute.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What number of people were there?

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had the per≈øons the ≈øoldiers came up to, any thing in their hands?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No they had nothing but buckets. I took it they were brandi≈øhing their ≈øwords at the people, but I ≈øaw them ≈øtrike no body. I went to the Main Guard, I ≈øaw the Sentries before the Guard hou≈øe, walking as u≈øual. I ≈øtaid on purpo≈øe to ≈øee ≈øome body come back from Boyl≈øton's a≈øley, to know if any were wounded. People were coming down from the South-end, crying where is the fire? Where is the fire ‚Ä¢ I ≈øaid there is no fire, but the ≈øoldiers fighting. At that time, in King ≈øtreet, I do not think you could ≈øee a man, child, or boy pa≈ø≈øing. I ≈øtood there at the Main Guard about four minutes.‚ÄîThe Old Brick bell began to ring, and the people ≈øeemed to come along fa≈øt, with buckets and bags.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No, I ≈øtaid there about five minutes, and in a very ≈øhort time I looked down King-≈øtreet, and ≈øaw thirty or forty people in King-≈øtreet; Capt. Pre≈øton came down to the Main-Guard, as it were from behind the Brick meeting, and ≈øaid turn out, damn your bloods, turn out: A party of ≈øoldiers turned out, Montgomery was among≈øt them; I was going to Montgomery, to a≈øk what they were going to do?‚Äî They drew up in two files, I think there were eight men, Capt. Pre≈øton drew his ≈øword, and marched down with them, and I went down as far as Mr. Waldo's ≈øhop with them, I thought they were going to relieve guard. After that, I went up by the Main guard again, having left the ≈øoldiers on their march down from Waldo's ≈øhop, and pa≈ø≈øed round the Town Hou≈øe, came down the north ≈øide of it, and went down King ≈øtreet, and got within two yards of the right of them; I ≈øaw Capt. Pre≈øton ≈øtanding at the right of
the circle, I ≈øtaid there about four minutes, when I heard the word given, fire!‚ÄîThere was none fired then.‚ÄîThen I heard „Äà‚óä„Äâ your bloods, fire!‚ÄîIn≈øtantly one gun went off, I ≈øaw the fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh of every gun as they went off, one after another, like the clock ≈øtriking.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: A.
