sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at any of them before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øtood all the time they were there, and ≈øaw nothing thrown at all.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body knocked down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: You ≈øaw no ice nor ≈ønow balls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people round you ≈øeem to be pre≈ø≈øing on ≈øo as to injure the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; had I ≈øeen any thing thrown, I would have gone away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any blows given by any body, before or after the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Palmes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw a man talking with the officer?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Bli≈øs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzaing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, before the party marched down, there were two or three huzzas, but afterwards none at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you imagine were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: ≈øixty or ≈øeventy.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: From the time they went from the Main-Guard, till the firing, how long was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was not more than ten or twelve minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, White.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know either of the re≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes Wemms.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Do you know any other?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, Warren and Hartegan, I ≈øaw them there that night under arms. On Monday evening 5th of March, I was at work near Hancock's wharff, hearing a bell ring it cau≈øed me to leave the ≈øhop to make inquiry what the matter was; I heard the ≈øoldiers had ro≈øe on the inhabitants, and I got as far as Fanuiel-Hall. I ≈øaw ≈øeveral gentlemen, I a≈øked them what the matter was, they an≈øwered me, that, two young men had been abu≈øed by the ≈øoldiers, but that they had returned to their barracks. The bells ≈øtill ringing made me proceed up Royal-exchange lane with a number of other per≈øons: I out run them and came to the head of the lane, there being no per≈øon there but a ≈øoldier who was the Sentry, the other Inhabitants coming up, they cryed out there is a ≈øoldier and huzza'd. The ≈øoldier immediately repaired to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe door, he was at the we≈øt corner of the hou≈øe before; there, with a large bra≈øs knocker, gave three loud and remarkable ≈øtrokes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of per≈øons were there came up immediately after you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Five or ≈øix. Somebody came to the door and opened it, and ≈øpoke to the Sentry, and then ≈øhut the door again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was ≈øaid to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear. The ≈øoldier then turned about and loaded his gun, and knocked it twice very loud on the ≈øteps; then he went to the we≈øt corner of the hou≈øe where he had been before, the people gathered round him; I went with him, and I ca≈øt my eye up King-≈øtreet, and ≈øaw an officer and ≈øeven men, they came to the we≈øt corner of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any thing done to mole≈øt them then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nothing at all. The officer then cryed ≈øhoulder.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who that officer was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have ≈øeen him in the Court.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many ≈øoldiers were with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seven.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How did they ≈øtand then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ≈øtood in a circle. The officer then ≈øaid, handle your arms, ea≈øe your arms, ≈øecure your arms, ≈øupport your arms, ea≈øe your arms, prime and load.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are you certain he ≈øaid all that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am as certain, as I am of my own exi≈øtence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did Capt. Pre≈øton ≈øtand then?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: He ≈øtood a little behind the ≈øoldiers towards the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe. There were about fifteen or twenty inhabitants in the ≈øtreet, when the party came down.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the ≈øoldiers formed before they loaded?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: They were not really formed: they were in a kind of a circle, after they had loaded they formed more into a circle than they were before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know Capt. Pre≈øton before that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you there when the guns fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I went up to the officer, and ≈øaid for God's ≈øake do not fire on the≈øe people: he made me no an≈øwer at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was he then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was ≈øtanding behind the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you behind the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, a little before them, at the edge of the gutter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any per≈øon with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, none at all. I pu≈øhed through betwixt two of the men, and ≈øpoke to him that way, he had on a red cont, and laced hat. I ≈øaw no more of him. I went to ≈øome of the inhabitants, and ≈øaid, do not trouble the≈øe men, they are on duty. Some ≈øaid we will neither trouble them, not be drove off by them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any orders given for firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard, damn you fire: it ≈øeemed to me as it came from the Sentry-box where I left the Captain. I was then by Vernon the barber's ≈øhop; I had pa≈ø≈øed acro≈øs the ≈øtreet. I ≈øaw a man going to throw a club, I begged of him not to do it, for I ≈øaid if he did, the ≈øoldiers would certainly fire: he ≈øaid, he would not, and did not. I then ≈øaw a white club thrown at ≈øome di≈øtance from me towards the ≈øoldier's; immediately I heard the word pre≈øent, I ≈øtooped down, a little ≈øpace of time en≈øued, I heard damn you fire: two guns were di≈øcharged then as I judged.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did that club hit any body?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe it hit one of the ≈øoldiers guns, I heard it ≈øtrike.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that before the firing, or after?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Before the firing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near to the ≈øoldiers was the per≈øon that threw the club?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ten yards off. Three or four more guns were then di≈øcharged, which killed Attucks and Cray, I heard and ≈øaw them fall; then two more were di≈øcharged, one of them killed Mr Caldwell, who was about ten feet di≈øtance from me, the other ≈øtruck about five inches over my back.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øpace of time was there betwixt the ≈øecond gun and the third?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be about two or three ≈øeconds. Another gun was then fired, which wounded Mr. Patter≈øon in the arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long after the club was thrown, was it, before the fir≈øt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not above one or two ≈øeconds.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of a ≈øtick was it that was thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be a white birch cord-wood ≈øtick, an inch thick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What fort of a man, for heighth, was he that threw it!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He might be about five feet and an half.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How do you know what number of guns were fired together?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I judged by the report: I ≈øaw the fla≈øhes,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the per≈øons that were killed, that evening before they were killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Upon the oath you have taken, did that man throw the ≈øtick with con≈øiderable violence, or not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He threw it con≈øiderable hard, he threw it over hand.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any people ≈øtanding betwixt the ≈øoldiers and the man that threw that ≈øtick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ≈øome, but not many.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people make a great deal of noi≈øe and huzzaing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, con≈øiderable.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them ≈øay to the ≈øoldiers, bloody backs, come on you bloody backs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I heard no ≈øuch thing, but when the two fir≈øt guns were di≈øcharged, ≈øome one cryed murder, and by the voice I think it was Maverick. The≈øe guns killed nobody, unle≈øs Maverick was then ≈øhot.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the pri≈øoners the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not ≈øo as to know them again. That evening, at the cry of fire, I came out of my hou≈øe, and ≈øaw the people running down town, and I followed them; when I got by the Town-hou≈øe, I ≈øaw ≈øome going down King-≈øtreet, I went down al≈øo: At the Guard hou≈øe, I ≈øaw a number of the ≈øoldiers running; I a≈øked where was the fire, no body an≈øwered me. I went down to the middle of King-≈øtreet, and while I ≈øtood there, was pu≈øhed from behind me with a bayonet. I turned round and ≈øaw a party of ≈øoldiers coming down, I a≈øked one the rea≈øon of his pu≈øhing at me? he dumn'd my blood, and bid me ≈øtand out of their way, I ≈øaid I would not, I was doing no harm to any man, and would not ≈øtand a≈øide for any one; they pa≈ø≈øed me ≈øome on one ≈øide, ≈øome on the other. They came to the Sentry-box, faced round and formed a circle. I ≈øpoke to ≈øome of the inhabitants to ≈øpeak to Pre≈øton, to know what the matter was; ≈øome body ≈øpoke to him, but what was ≈øaid, I do not know. I ≈øaw Pre≈øton fall in betwixt the fourth and fifth man, the word was given fire! immediately the right hand man fired; after that I pu≈øhed in towards them, and they run a bayonet at me and wounded me in my arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was it ≈øtruck you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The ≈øecond man, the fir≈øt gun was th ‚Ä¢ fired, the ≈øecond was not; the guns went off pretty quick

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it the ≈øame ≈øoldier that ≈øtruck you, pu≈øhed you in the arm?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No. I was pu≈øhed twice in the arm by two different
bayonets; I knocked off one of them with my ≈øtick, with the other I was wounded in my brea≈øt, the wound an ≈øuch long, through a double brea≈øted jacket.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was no blows given before the guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not where I ≈øtood, and I ≈øaw two thirds of the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the occa≈øion of your ru≈øhing in upon them after the fir≈øt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: All my end was to know who they were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you wonder what was the occa≈øion of their firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did not know what their intention was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any in≈øults offered the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, none at all, I ≈øaw the right hand grenadier fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it before or after he had fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was after. He fell on his back≈øide.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the people that were killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw the Molatto, and cro≈ø≈øed to Quaker lane and there ≈øteped over two more.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did the Molatto man lay?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By the gutter on the ≈øouth ≈øide of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of them before they were killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not as I know of.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What do you think was the occa≈øion of the granadier's falling?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was occa≈øioned by his pu≈øhing at ≈øomebody that went in at Royal exchange-lane.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ≈øeveral, there is Killroy I know particularly well.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear Killroy make u≈øe of any threatning expre≈ø≈øions, again≈øt the inhabitants of this town?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, one evening I heard him ≈øay, he never would mi≈øs an opportunity, when he had one, to fire on the inhabitants, and that he had wanted to have an opportunity ever ≈øince he landed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long was that before the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A week or fortnight, I cannot ≈øay which.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any of the re≈øt threaten any thing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who was pre≈øent when this conver≈øation pa≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Mrs. Bouker, Mr. Apthorp's hou≈øe-keeper.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any body el≈øe pre≈øent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Only the Negroe boy.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What gave occa≈øion for this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He and I were talking about the town's people and the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he ≈øay it with any re≈øentment?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No otherways than he would not mi≈øs an opportunity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you remember what conver≈øation immediately preceded that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he in anger?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was Killroy in liquor or not?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Had there any angry words pa≈ø≈øed betwixt him and you at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it in jocular talk?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know. I ≈øaid he was a fool for talking ≈øo.‚Äî he ≈øaid he did not care.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had Killroy ≈øaid that evening, that he had been at the rope-walks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he ≈øaid nothing about the rope-walks.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was this conver≈øation before or after the affray at the rope-walks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you in King-≈øtreet at the time of the firing on the evening of the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What did you ob≈øerve?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I came there about fifteen minutes before the ≈øoldiers came, I ≈øtaid there till they came down, and remained there till the firing was over.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Narrate what happened in relation to the Sentry.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
I was at the North end of the town when the bells rung, when I come to the middle of the town, I was told there was no fire; but a rumpus betwixt the ≈øoldiers and the inhabitants. I pa≈ø≈øed on, the bells ≈øtill kept ringing, I came to Dock ≈øquare, and was informed much to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; there were ≈øome per≈øons there, who told me it was dangerous to go up; they ≈øeemed to be like people that were afraid to pa≈øs, becau≈øe of the danger, others were going up, I went up, when I got pa≈øt the ally, the ≈øtreet was very clear of people, I hardly ≈øaw any body.‚Äî
I came to the Town-hou≈øe, and ≈øaw a few lads, but no great number, I have often ≈øeen more collected for their diver≈øion.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From twenty to thirty. I ≈øaw the Sentry upon the ≈øteps of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe door, but I heard him ≈øay nothing, but he had his gun waving as if it was to defend him≈øelf, or to exa≈øperate the people. I thought to ≈øpeak to him, but I thought he might in≈øult me, and therefore I declined; I went in order to go away, and met the party coming down; that made me ≈øtop, becau≈øe when they got to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, there was a noi≈øe ≈øomething like what they call cheers, and the people went more to the middle of the ≈øtreet; after the ≈øoldiers had pa≈ø≈øed through them, I went down again, as I pa≈ø≈øed before them, there was very few people there, I pa≈ø≈øed without the people, and inclined more to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, the greate≈øt part of the ≈øoldiers were full to my view; the people that were there, were collected in a body at the end of Royal exchange lane, they did not go ≈øo high as Mr. Stone's hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was walking right before them. They had their guns re≈øted on their hips; when I pa≈ø≈øed the la≈øt man on the left, the fir≈øt gun was fired from the right; as I judged, the time might be twenty ≈øeconds before the fir≈øt gun was fired from the time they formed, in a ≈øhort ≈øpace there was another, and then very ≈øoon another, and then there was a ≈øhort ≈øpace of time again, before the la≈øt guns were fired. A little boy run along and cryed, fire! fire! fire! as people generally do when there is fire, a ≈øoldier pointed his gun to him and fired, but did not hit him, he was the la≈øt but one on the left.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people appear to be pa≈ø≈øing off after the fir≈øt gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I did not mind the fir≈øt gun, I thought it was only powder to ≈øcare them; but when the next was fired, they were a ≈øcattering. After the firing cea≈øed, a little boy came and told us ≈øome per≈øons were killed. I ≈øaw them lye in the ≈øtreet, but I did not imagine it was any body killed, but that they had been ≈øcared and run away, and left their great coat's behind them: I ≈øaw nothing like an attack that could produce any ≈øuch con≈øequences: I went to look at the Malatto man, and heard a noi≈øe like the cocking of firelocks,
but an officer pa≈ø≈øed before them, and ≈øaid, do not f ‚Ä¢ e on the inhabitants The ≈øtreet was in a manner clear, it was as bu≈øh as at twelve o'clock at night, the noi≈øe of the cocking ≈øeemed to come from the right, and pa≈ø≈øed on to the left.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Six was the lea≈øt, and one mi≈ø≈øed fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the la≈øt man on the left fire, or not?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: He did no fire, his gun ≈øeemed to mi≈øs fire, and he brought it down in „Äà‚óä„Äâ priming po≈øture, and a man, like an office ‚Ä¢ ≈øtepped up to him and ≈øpoke to him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee them load betwixt the firing and this noi≈øe you ≈øpeak of, like the cocking of firelocks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ≈øee them load, for I did not leave my ≈øtation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many ≈øoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Six or eight.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any blows given, or any thing thrown!

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No, and I was there the whole time.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee Palmes there, or Bli≈øs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body ≈øtrike the ≈øoldiers guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzaing, when the ≈øoldiers came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There ≈øeemed to be a huzza, but when I went down and pa≈ø≈øed them they were very ≈øtill, only talking together, but I heard nothing they ≈øaid: the ≈øhou ‚Ä¢ ing was fir≈øt when they went down, and it was not two minutes till they fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes, I know Warren and Killroy.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ever ≈øee them at the rope-walks?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes, they were both at the rope-walks

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How long was that before the 5th of March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the Friday before.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ever hear them make u≈øe of any expre≈ø≈øions of mi≈øchief towards the inhabitants?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No On Friday Mr. John Gray told me to go to his rope-walk to make ≈øome cables; I went and worked till about twelve, and then I ≈øaw a ≈øoldier coming down the out≈øide rope-walk, ≈øwearing, and ≈øaying he would have ≈øatisfaction. Before this there was one of our hands while I was coiling a cable, ≈øaid to a ≈øoldier do you want work, yes, lays the ≈øoldier I do faith; well ≈øaid he to the ≈øoldier, go clean
my little-hou≈øe, he damned us and made a blow at, and ≈øtruck me, when I knocked up his heels, his coat flew open and out dropt a naked cutle≈øs, which I took up and carried off with me. He went away, and came back with a dozen ≈øoldiers with him: the people that were attacked called to us for help. When they called to us, we came up; then we had ≈øeveral knocks among≈øt us, at la≈øt they went off. They all got armed with clubs, and in the afternoon they were coming again, but Mr. John Gray ≈øtopped them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When they came the ≈øecond time, ‚Ä¢ as Killroy with them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did they do the ≈øecond time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We had a battle, and they went to their barracks. On the 5th of March I went to Quaker lane, and met Samuel Gray; I ≈øaid where are you going, he ≈øaid to the fire. I went into King-≈øtreet, and ≈øaw nobody there, the Sentry was walking as u≈øual. We agreed to go home. I went towards home, and ≈øtopped at the bottom of Long lane, and while I was talking there, I heard guns go off. I went to King-≈øtreet, and was told ≈øeveral were killed, I then went home. Samuel Gray, when I ≈øaw him that night, was quite calm, and had no ≈øtick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the≈øe pri≈øoners in King-≈øtreet the night of the 5th of March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I can ≈øwear to as they are dre≈ø≈øed. I can recollect ≈øomething of their faces, but cannot ≈øwear to them. When I came to King ≈øtreet, I went immediately up to one of the ≈øoldiers, which I take to be that man who is bald on the head, (pointing to Montgomery) I a≈øked him if any of the ≈øoldiers were loaded, he ≈øaid yes. I a≈øked him if they were going to fire, he ≈øaid yes, by the eternal God, and pu≈øhed at me with his bayonet, which I put by with what was in my hand.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A Highland broad ≈øword.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What occa≈øion had you to carry it.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
A young man that boarded with me, and was at the Rope-walks, told me ≈øeveral of them had a ≈øpite at him, and that he believed he was in danger. I had ≈øeen two ≈øoldiers about my hou≈øe, I ≈øaw one of them hearkening at the window, I ≈øaw him again near the hou≈øe, and a≈øked him
what he was after; he ≈øaid he was pumping ≈øhip: Was it not you, ≈øays I, that was hearkening at my window la≈øt night? what if it was, he ≈øaid, I told him to march off, and he damned me, and I beat him till he had enough of it, and he then went off. The rea≈øon of carrying the ≈øword, was, they ≈øpyed the young man in the lane, and dogg'd him, for he had been very active in the affray at the Ropewalks, and they ≈øaid they would ≈øome time or other have ≈øatisfaction, and I looked upon my≈øelf to be liable to be in≈øulted likewi≈øe. When alarmed by the cry of fine, and I had got below the hou≈øe, my wife called after me, and ≈øaid it is not fire, it is an affray in King-≈øtreet, if you are going take this, ≈øo I took it, and run down, and I a≈øked the ≈øoldier what I ju≈øt now told you. I knocked the bayonet with what I had in my hand, another pu≈øhed at me, I ≈øtruck his gun; my face was now towards the ≈øoldiers. I heard the fir≈øt gun go off, and then the ≈øecond gun went off. As I was looking to ≈øee if any body was killed, I ≈øaw the tall man ≈øtanding in a line with me. I ≈øaw him fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabouts was you when you hit the gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nigh the gutter, about the middle of the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long had the bells been ringing before you came from home?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thought it was 9 o'clock, and did not think any thing el≈øe, till ≈øomebody cryed fire.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øtrike before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øtrike as hard as you could?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, and hit the look of his gun, and if I had ≈øtruck a little lower, I ≈øhould have left a mark that I could have ≈øwore to.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ≈øword in your hand drawn?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I drew it when the ≈øoldier pu≈øhed at me, and ≈øtruck at him as I have mentioned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which gun went off fir≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took it to be the right hand man.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did that ≈øoldier you ≈øtruck at ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe the fourth or fifth man from the corner of Exchange lane?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many ≈øoldiers were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not count them, it appeared to me there were fix or eight.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The man that ≈øaid he would fire by the eternal God, where did he ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was about the middle.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was you there when the fir≈øt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the immediate occa≈øion of that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know, I had only walked over from Quaker-lane till I came to the ≈øoldiers, that was all the time I had.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing extraordinary, to induce them to fire that gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nothing, but a ≈øtort ≈øtick was thrown, which ≈øeemed to go clear over all their heads. I heard a clattering of their guns, but what was the occa≈øion of it I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Might not their iron ramrods occa≈øion it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øuppo≈øe they knocked one gun again≈øt another in taking their places. When the Molatto man was dead, I went up, and met Dr. Gardner and Mr. Brindley. I a≈øked them to come and ≈øee the Molatto, and as we ≈øtooped to take up the man, the ≈øoldiers pre≈øented their arms again, as if they had been going to fire, Capt. Pre≈øton came, pu≈øhed up their guns, and ≈øaid ≈øtop firing, do not fire. I went to them to ≈øee if I could know their faces again; Capt. Pre≈øton looked out betwixt two of them, and ≈øpoke to me, which took off my attention from them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: From where was that ≈øtick thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: From Royal-exchange-lane, and it flew over their head almo≈øt as high as the ≈øign.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What did you take to be the occa≈øion of the ≈øoldiers an≈øwer to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know, without he was affronted at my a≈øking the que≈øtion of him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body ≈øtrike the ≈øoldiers before you ≈øtruck with the ≈øword?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I had not time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What di≈øtance of time was there betwixt the fir≈øt and ≈øecond gun?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A very ≈øhort ≈øpace, I cannot ≈øay exactly.

Coming from Corn hill I went down to Dock-≈øquare, I ≈øaw a number of people together; I heard there had been an affray by Murray's Barrack. Somebody ≈øaid you had better all go home; ≈øome went to the North end, ≈øome up Royal-exchange-lane, I came up to Corn hill: when I got to the Town pump, I heard the Main-Guard had drawn a party off
and gone to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, I run down the north ≈øide of the Town hou≈øe, and ≈øaw a number of people, twenty or thirty, collected. I tryed to pre≈øs into the mid≈øt of them to know what they were about; I could not get in; I therefore ≈øtepped over the gutter, and ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers, ≈øeven or eight of them, by the Sentry box. Some of the people were leaning on their ≈øticks, ≈øome ≈øtanding with their hands in their bo≈øoms, and ≈øome were whi≈øtling. Numbers were crouding to get in as I was. I had my eye on the right hand man. Somebody ≈øaid, do not pre≈øs on the ≈øoldiers, I repeated the ≈øame words, do not pre≈øs on the ≈øoldiers: when I ≈øaid that, I ≈øaw ≈øomething like a fla≈øh at my left, and heard the report of a gun, and the people opened from right to left; but I could not ≈øee where the gun was fired from; it made a noi≈øe like a pi≈øtol, and I imagined it was nothing but powder. As the people crouded to the lane, it took the view of the right hand ≈øoldiers from me, but I had a view of the left. I heard another gun go off, and ≈øaw a man fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where was the man when he fell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was about a foot over the ≈øouth ≈øide of the gutte ‚Ä¢

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he nearer to the right than to the left of the ≈øoldier?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They fired in a triangular manner.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How near did they ≈øtand together.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The width of a man a≈øunder. I dropped on my knees, and ≈øaw the third gun go off, and then I ≈øaw a man who ≈øeemed to come upon his heel, and wind round a little and then fall on his back. The people were moving off, and the guns ≈øeemed to move as the people run. The fourth gun went off quickly after.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the ≈øecond gun fired from the fir≈øt right hand man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The fla≈øh ≈øeemed to come from the ≈øecond man from the right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the huzzaing encrea≈øe, and a general pre≈ø≈øing in upon the fir≈øt gun being fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there many ≈øticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw but a few.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any ≈øticks thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I ≈øaw two or three ≈ønow balls, which ≈øeemed to come from a di≈øtance.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people ≈øtand clo≈øe in with the ≈øoldiers bayonets?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No, they appeared to be two feet from the bayonets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear a noi≈øe like ≈øtriking on the barrels of the guns.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear a cry of the people, kill them, knock them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I was not there above a minute, I ≈øaw no blows given by any body, ju≈øt before the firing there was a huzzaing and whi≈øtling.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you live the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At my ≈øi≈øter's Mrs. Torrey's, by the Town pump. I heard the bells ring after nine, and went to the front door, I was followed by my ≈øi≈øter and two others of the family; I ≈øtood there about five minutes, and ≈øaw a number of ≈øoldiers, about ten or a dozen, come towards the pump, they ≈øeemed to make a noi≈øe, one of them got nearly oppo≈øite to me, and hollowed, damn you, what do you do there? I made him no an≈øwer, he came up to me and pointed his naked bayonet at my brea≈øt, and held it there ≈øome time, and told me to get in, I told him to go along; he went towards the Po≈øt-office.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know what regiment he belonged to?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the Twenty-ninth.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he bid you get in when he a≈øked you what you did there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. In a little while I heard a volley of ≈ømall arms, which I took to be in King-≈øtreet.

On the evening of the 5th March I heard a very great noi≈øe, my wife ≈øaid you had better go to the door and ≈øee what the matter is; I went, and ≈øaw about twenty people I believe, coming through Boyl≈øton's alley, there was a terrible ≈øwearing, and they had clubs and ≈øwords and one thing and another; there came ≈øeven ≈øoldiers from the Main Guard without any coats on, driving along, ≈øwearing, cur≈øing and damning like wild creatures, ≈øaying where are they? Cut them to pieces, ≈ølay them all. They came up to my door, I ≈øhut my door and went in, they went round the
back lane to King-≈øtreet:‚Äîthis was after nine, before any guns were fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know if any of the≈øe pri≈øoners were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I cannot ≈øix on any man.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had they any of them pouches on?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay for the pouches; but they had no coats. Tho≈øe people below at the alley, cried fire! which I took to be a watch-word.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were tho≈øe you ≈øaw before, ≈øoldiers or town's people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They came from the Barracks, and they were both ≈øoldiers and town's people.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How long were they there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not two minutes, they went down towards the Market, and came up to King-≈øtreet by the back lane.

On the evening of the 5th March, a little after nine, I was ≈øitting in my hou≈øe, I heard a con≈øiderable noi≈øe in the ≈øtreet, I li≈øtened a little, and found it continued, I went to the door, I found the chief of the noi≈øe was at the bottom of the ≈øtreet, I enquired the rea≈øon, I was told the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants were fighting; I waited at the door a minute or two, people were running down in two's and three's at a time, at length the noi≈øe ≈øub≈øided, and ≈øeemed to be down by Dock-≈øquare; I heard the bells ring and heard the cry of fire, I a≈øked where it was? I was an≈øwered there was none, but the inhabitants and ≈øoldiers fighting. Deacon Mar≈øh came out, and there came a party of ≈øoldiers from the ≈øouthward, ten or twelve I think, they had ≈øhort cloths I think, I ≈øaw ≈øome white ≈ølieves among≈øt them with bayonets in their hands, but I apprehended no danger from them; I ≈øtood on the ≈øtep of the door, they appeared to be pu≈øhing right down the ≈øtreet, when they got a few rods from the door, their cour≈øe began to bend towards us, ≈øtill I apprehended nothing but that they were coming to walk on the ≈øide of the way, then they lifted up their weapons, and I began to apprehend danger, they ≈øaid ≈øomething. I do not know what it was, but I went in as fall as I could, and ≈øhut the door immediately. They were within half a foot of it, had it been open a ≈øecond longer they would have had the command of the door, but I was too quick for them and bolted my door, went up chamber, looked out of my window, and ≈øaw people flying here and
there like pidgeons, and the ≈øoldiers running about like mad men in a fury till they got to the bottom of the ≈øtreet.
sp.stage: John Appleton, a young Lad ≈øon to Nathaniel Appleton, ≈øworn.
sp.p: About nine I was ≈øent on an errand into King ≈øtreet, I had my little brother with me, I heard a noi≈øe, I run out of the ≈øhop where I was, to ≈øee what was the matter, I went into the middle of the ≈øtreet, and ≈øaw ≈øome talking to the Sentry, I thought they were going to quarrel and came away. Coming by Jenkins's alley my little brother with me, there came out about twenty ≈øoldiers with cutla≈ø≈øes in their hands, my brother fell and they run pa≈øt him, and were going to kill me, I ≈øaid ≈øoldiers ≈øpare my life, one of them ≈øaid no damn you, we will kill you all; he lifted his cutla≈øs and ≈øtruck at my head, but I dodged and got the blow on my ≈øhoulder.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the cutla≈øs drawn?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe it was not, for it ratled on my ≈øhoulder as if it had been ≈øheathed.

I was at Col Jack≈øon's a few minutes after nine on the 5th of March. When I came out into Dock ≈øquare, the ≈øquare was entirely quiet, I ≈øaw no per≈øons in the whole ≈øquare. I came up Royal exchange-lane, I ≈øaw nobody there. I ≈øaw the Sentry at the head of it in peace and quietne≈øs, nobody troubling him: I never ≈øaw King-≈øtreet more quiet in my life. I went into my hou≈øe, where was a kin≈øman of mine; I a≈øked him how he did, and while I was ≈øpeaking the young man in the ≈øhop knocked for me, I went into the ≈øhop, and in a half a minute, I heard the cry of murder once or twice; there is mi≈øchief ≈øaid I, at a di≈øtance, ≈øo there is ≈øaid he; I opened the front door to ≈øee, I ≈øaw nobody. I heard a ≈øad noi≈øe, which ≈øeemed to come from Rowe's barracks. I ≈øtopped a little ≈øpace, and the fir≈øt I ≈øaw enter King-≈øtreet, was a party from the Main-Guard, ten or twelve came ru≈øhing out violently, I ≈øaw their arms glitter by the moon light, hallowing damn them where are they, by Je≈øus let them come. Some of them turned into Pudding-lane, and ≈øome went by the Town-hou≈øe ≈øteps; I went in and told my family to keep them≈øelves ea≈øy, for there was no di≈øturbance near the hou≈øe. I went to the door again, and ≈øaw a party about the head of Quaker-lane, and they u≈øed much
the ≈øame expre≈ø≈øions as the afore≈øaid party, and hallowed fire. They pa≈ø≈øed over the way, and the ≈øhade of the moon light hindered me to ≈øee if they went down Royal-exchange-lane or went up towards the Town-hou≈øe Something ≈øtrikes my mind, I am not po≈øitive now, but I think it was that night, there were a few boys round the Sentry. I went and ≈øaid, boys you have no bu≈øine≈øs with the Sentry, go off, and they went off. I have often ≈øeen boys with the Sentry, and heard words often. The bells were then ringing, and the people began to collect as they do at the cry of fire, and I began to think it was fire. I had a mind to get my ≈øtaff and go out, but I had a reluctance, becau≈øe I had been warned not to go out that night: but while the people were collecting, I came to the door, and ≈øaw them gathering thick from all quarters, forty, fifty or ≈øixty. When the party came down, I thought it was no more than I had ≈øeen every day, I thought they had come to relieve the Sentry, they ≈øeemed to be in a po≈øture of defence, and came through the people. I ≈øaw no oppo≈øition. When they came up, they pa≈ø≈øed out of the moon light into the dark, ≈øo that I could not ≈øee them, but I wondered to find them tarry ≈øo long. I heard a gun go off, I thought it was an accident, but in a little time another gun went off, and a third and fourth, pretty quick, and then the fifth. There ≈øeemed to be a ≈ømall ≈øtop in their firing, I than had no concern, but before the ≈ømoke was well away, I ≈øaw the people dead on the ground. I ≈øaw no oppo≈øition when they were drawn up, the people were not near them; what oppo≈øition might be at the lane I could not perceive, becau≈øe the box covered that from my view.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain that the ≈øoldiers came from the Main-Guard?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I am certain of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You ≈øaw that party that fired, come from the Main-Guard, but the fir≈øt party of ten or twelve, did they come out from the Main-Guard?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How were they dre≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I could not ≈øee their dre≈øs, but I ≈øaw their arms glitter.

div.stage: SIX o'clock, P. M. the Court adjourned to Thur≈øday morning Nine o'clock.
div.p: Thur≈øday NINE o'clock the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.

Next morning after the 5th of March, in King-≈øtreet, before the ≈øoldiers were apprehended, I ≈øaw Killroy, I have known him by ≈øight almo≈øt ever ≈øince he hath been here, I ≈øaw his bayonet bloody, the blood was dryed on five or ≈øix inches from the point.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were you to the bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About the ≈øame di≈øtance I am from the Judges, viz: ≈øix feet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it ≈øhouldered?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I forget the po≈øture.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ≈øure it was blood.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It appeared to be covered from the point five or ≈øix inches, it appeared to me to be blood, and I thought then, it was blood dryed on.
The next morning I ob≈øerved the ≈øame with Mr. Cro≈øswell, I do not know his name, but that's the man, (pointing to Killroy) his gun was re≈øted on his right arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did it appear to you to be covered from the point with blood?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I am po≈øitive it was blood.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How nigh was you to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As nigh as I am to you, Sir, viz. three feet off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know young Maverick, who was killed by the firing in King-≈øtreet, on the 5th of March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee him that night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was at my hou≈øe that night at ≈øupper with ≈øome young lads, and when the bells rung, as we all thought for fire, he run out in order to go to it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing of the affray at the Rope-walks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I ≈øaw a party of the ≈øoldiers near the Rope-walks with clubs, ordered them to di≈øper≈øe, commanded the peace, told them I was in commi≈ø≈øion for the peace, they paid no
regard to me or my orders, but cut an old man who was coming by, before my face, and ≈øome of them ≈øtruck at me ‚Ä¢ but did not hit me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any of the pri≈øoners among them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know that they were.

div.p: The evidence for the Crown being clo≈øed, Samuel Quincy, E≈øq then addre≈ø≈øed the Court and Jury, as follows:

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe your Honours, and you Gentlemen of the Jury.

div.p: HAVING gone through the evidence on the part of the crown, it is my province to ≈øupport the charge again≈øt the pri≈øoners. The examination hath been lengthy, and from the nature of the tran≈øaction complex, and in ≈øome part difficult; I ≈øhall apply it as di≈øtinctly as I am able, without endeavouring to mi≈ørepre≈øent or aggravate any thing to the prejudice of the pri≈øoners on the one hand, or on the other to neglect any thing that ju≈øtice to the decea≈øed ≈øufferers, the laws of my country, or the pre≈øervation of the peace of ≈øociety demand.

There are two things nece≈ø≈øary to prove, which I mentioned in the fir≈øt opening of this cau≈øe, namely, the identity of the pri≈øoners, that is, that they were that party of men who on the 5th of March la≈øt were in King-≈øtreet, and that they committed the facts mentioned in the indictments, and farther gentlemen, the circum≈øtances attending and aggravating the commi≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe facts.
As to the fir≈øt point, to prove the identity of the pri≈øoners, all of them have been ≈øworn to, and mo≈øt of them by more than one witne≈øs.

To KILLROY gentlemen, you have Langford, Archibald and Brewer, who ≈øwear po≈øitively; and farther you have the evidence of Ferriter and Hemmingway. The one, of Killroy's being in the affray at the rope-walks, and the other to his uttering a number of malicious and threatning expre≈ø≈øions in regard to the inhabitants of the town of Bo≈øton.
To WHITE gentlemen, you have four more, Simp≈øon, Langford, Bailey and Clark.
To MONTGOMERY, you have Bailey, Palmes, Ba≈øs, Danbrook and Wilkin≈øon.
To HARTEGAN, you have Danbrook and Simp≈øon.
To WEMMS, you have Simp≈øon and Bridgham.
To CARROL, Bailey and Danbrook.
To WARREN, Bridgham, Dodge and Simp≈øon. Bridgham indeed expre≈ø≈øed ≈øome doubt, and gave his rea≈øons for it, which may be worthy notice hereafter.

But here, Gentlemen, we mu≈øt ≈øtop. If we pur≈øue this enquiry, at this time, and in this place, we ≈øhall be in danger of doing great inju≈øtice. We ≈øhall get beyond our limits. The right of quartering troops in this province mu≈øt be di≈øcu≈ø≈øed at a different tribunal. The con≈øtitutional legality, the propriety, the expediency of their appointment are que≈øtions of ≈øtate, not to be determined, nor even agitated by us, in this Court. It is enough for us, if the law takes notice of them when thus ≈øtationed; if it warrants their continuance; If it protects them in their quarters. They were ≈øent here by that authority, which our laws know; they were quartered here, as I take it, agreeable to an act of the Briti≈øh Parliament; they were ordered here, by your Sovereign, and mine. I expect hereafter, to be more particular on this head.
Let me here take a method very common, with another order of men. Let me remind you of what is not your duty.

Gentlemen, great pains have been taken by different men, with very different views, to involve the character, the conduct and reputation of the town of Bo≈øton, in the pre≈øent i≈ø≈øue. Bo≈øton and it's inhabitants have no more to do with this cau≈øe, than you or any other members of the community. You are, therefore, by no means to blend two things, ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially different, as the guilt or innocence of this town
and the pri≈øoners, together. The inhabitants of Bo≈øton, by no rules of law‚ñ™ ju≈øtice of common ≈øen≈øe, can be ≈øuppo≈øed an≈øwerable for the unju≈øtifiable conduct of a few individuals ha≈øtily a≈ø≈øembled in the ≈øtreets. Every populous city, in like circum≈øtances, would be liable to ≈øimilar commotions, i ‚Ä¢ not wor≈øe. No rational or hone≈øt man, will form any wor≈øe opinion of this metropolis, for the tran≈øactions of that melancholy night. Who can, who will, unnece≈ø≈øarily intere≈øt them≈øelves, to ju≈øtify the rude behaviour of a mixt and ungovernable multitude? May I not appeal to you, and all who have heard this trial, thus far, that things already wear a different a≈øpect from what we have been, heretofore, taught to expect? Had any one told you ≈øome weeks ago, that the evidence on the Crown-≈øide, would have appeared in it's pre≈øent light, would you have believed it? Can any one think it his duty, to e≈øpou≈øe the part acted, by tho≈øe a≈ø≈øembled in King-≈øtreet?‚ÄîI think not, but le≈øt my opinion ≈øhould not have any weight, let me remind you of an author, whom, I tru≈øt, and wi≈øh in the hands of all of you. One whom I tru≈øt you will credit. I am ≈øure you ought to love and rev ‚Ä¢ re him. I wi≈øh his ≈øentiments were ingraven in indelible characters on your hearts. You will not ≈øu≈øpect him of being unfriendly to liberty; if this cau≈øe and it's event mu≈øt, at all hazards, be held as interwoven with a matter ≈øo foreign to it. I allude to the third Letter of the FARMER of Penn≈øylvania to his countrymen.

p.q: The cau≈øe of liberty, ≈øays, that great and good writer, is a cau≈øe of too much dignity, to be fullied by turbulence and tumult. It ought to be maintained in a manner ≈øuitable to her nature. Tho≈øe who engage in it, ≈øhould breathe a ≈øedate, yet fervent ≈øpirit, animating them to actions of prudence, ju≈øtice, mode≈øty, bravery, humanity, and magnanimity.

div.p: What has there tran≈øpired on this trial, ≈øavouring of any of the≈øe virtues? Was it ju≈øtice or humanity to attack, in≈øult, ridicule and abu≈øe a ≈øingle Sentinel on his po≈øt? Was it either mode≈øt, brave or magnanimous to ru≈øh upon the points of fixed bayonets; and trifle, vapour, and provoke at the very mouths of loaded mu≈økets. It may be brutal rage, or wanton ra≈øhne≈øs, but not ≈øurely any true magnanimity.

p.q:
I hope, ≈øays the ≈øame eminent writer, my dear countrymen, that you will in every colony be upon your guard
again≈øt tho≈øe, who AT ANY TIME endeavour to ≈øtir you up, under pretences of patrioti≈øm, to any mea≈øures DISRESPECTFUL to your Sovereign and our mother country

div.p:
By this it ≈øhould ≈øeem, as though the Farmer never expected any period would arrive, when ≈øuch mea≈øures would be warrantable. Now what more di≈øre≈øpectful to our parent country, than to treat with contempt a body of men ≈øtationed mo≈øt certainly by the con≈øent of her ≈øupreme legi≈ølative, the parliament of Britain? What more di≈øre≈øpectful of our common ≈øovereign, than to a≈ø≈øume the ≈øword of ju≈øtice, and become the avengers of either public or private wrongs? Tho' the ≈øoldiers, who appeared in the earlier part of the evening, in Cornhill, acted like barbarians and ≈øavages, they had now retired, and were now confined in their barracks: what tho' an impertinent boy had received unju≈øtifiable correction from the Sentinel; the boy, and the per≈øons in Cornhill, mu≈øt have recour≈øe only to the law for their redre≈øs. Courts of law are ≈øtiled "
‚Ä¢ indices injuriarum," the avengers of injuries, and none others are to a≈ø≈øume this prerogative. The law erects it≈øelf as the ≈øupreme, dernier re≈øort, in all complaints of wrongs; and nothing could more e≈ø≈øentially ≈ø ‚Ä¢ p our mo≈øt important intere≈øts, than any countenance to ≈øuch dangerous encroachments on the domains of municipal ju≈øtice.

But finally, to fini≈øh with the ju≈øtly celebrated Farmer‚Äî
Hot, ra≈øh, di≈øorderly proceedings, injure the reputation of a people as to wi≈ødom, valour, and virtue, without procuring the lea≈øt benefit.
Thus have you the ≈øen≈øe of this great authority with us. And let me a≈øk all tho≈øe, who have thought the cau≈øe of their country connected with the agents of the a≈ø≈øembly in King-≈øtreet, whether the proceedings of that unhappy night, were hot, ra≈øh, or di≈øorderly? If they were, have they not, in the opinion of this great friend of liberty, injured our reputation, as to wi≈ødom, valour, and virtue; and that too, without procuring the lea≈øt benefit? Who then would ≈øacrifice his judgment and his integrity, to vindicate ≈øuch proceedings?

To what purpo≈øes the ≈øoldiers were ≈øent; whether it was a ≈øtep warranted by ≈øound policy or not, we ≈øhall not enquire; we are to con≈øider the troops, not as the in≈øtruments for wre≈øting our rights, but as fellow citizens, who being to be tried by a law, extending to every individual, claim a part in it's benefits‚Äîit's privileges‚Äîit's mercy. We
mu≈øt ≈øteel our≈øelves again≈øt pa≈ø≈øions, which contaminate the fountain of ju≈øtice. We ought to recollect, that our pre≈øent deci≈øions will be ≈øcann'd, perhaps thro' all Europe. We mu≈øt not forget, that we our≈øelves will have a reflective hour‚Äîan hour, in which we ≈øhall view things through a different medium‚Äîwhen the pul≈øe will no longer beat with the tumults of the day‚Äîwhen the con≈øcious pang of having betrayed truth, ju≈øtice, and integrity, ≈øhall bite like a ≈øerpent and ≈øting like an adder.

Con≈øider, Gentlemen, the danger which you, and all of us are in, of being led away by our affections and attachments.‚ÄîWe have ≈øeen the blood of our fellow men flowing in the ≈øtreets. We have been told that this blood was wrongfully ≈øhed. That is now the point in i≈ø≈øue. But let it be borne deep upon our minds, that the pri≈øoners are to be condemned by the evidence here in Court produced again≈øt them, and by nothing el≈øe. Matters heard or ≈øeen abroad, are to have no weight: in general they undermine the pillars of ju≈øtice and truth. It has been our misfortune, that a ≈øy≈øtem of evidence has appeared in the world again≈øt us. It is not our bu≈øine≈øs to blame any one for this. It is our misfortune, I ≈øay. It ≈øhould be remembered, that we were not pre≈øent to cro≈øs examine: and the danger which re≈øults from having this publication in the hands of tho≈øe who are to pa≈øs upon our lives, ought to be guarded again≈øt. We ≈øay we are innocent, by our plea, and are not to be denounced guilty upon a new ≈øpecies of evidence, unknown in the Engli≈øh ≈øy≈øtem of criminal law.

But as though a ≈øeries of ex parte evidence was not enough, all the colours of the canva≈øs have been touched in order to fre≈øhen the wounds, and by a tran≈øport of imagination, we are made pre≈øent at the ≈øcene of action. The prints exhibited in our hou≈øes have added wings to fancy, and in the fervour of our zeal, rea≈øon is in hazard of being lo≈øt. For as was elegantly expre≈ø≈øed, by a learned Gentleman at the late trial, "The pa≈ø≈øions of man, nay his very imaginations are contagious." The pomp of funeral, the horrors of death have been ≈øo delineated, as to give a ≈øpring to our ideas, and in≈øpire a glow incompatible with ≈øound, deliberative judgment. In this ≈øituation, every pa≈ø≈øion has alternately been predominant. They have each in it's turn, ≈øub≈øided, in degree, and they have ≈øometimes given place to de≈øpondence, grief and ≈øorrow. How careful ≈øhould
we be, that we do not mi≈øtake the impre≈ø≈øions of gloom and melancholy, for the dictates of rea≈øon and truth. How careful, le≈øt borne away by a torrent of pa≈ø≈øion, we make ≈øhipwreck of con≈øcience.

Perhaps, you may be told. Gentlemen, as I remember it was ≈øaid, at the late trial, that pa≈ø≈øions were like the flux and re≈øtux of the ≈øea‚Äîthe highe≈øt tides always producing the lowe≈øt ebbs. But let it be noticed, that the ‚Ä¢ de, in our political ocean, has yet never turned; certainly the current has never ≈øet towards the oppo≈øite quarter. However ≈øimilies may illu≈øtrate, they never go for proof. ‚ÄîThough I believe, that it will be found, that if the tide of re≈øentment has not ri≈øen of late, it has been becau≈øe, it had reached the ≈øummit.‚ÄîIn the ≈øame mode of phra≈øeology, if ≈øo homely an expre≈ø≈øion may be u≈øed; perhaps, as the ≈øeam ‚Ä¢ n ≈øay, it has been high-water ≈ølack‚Äîbut I am ≈øatisfied the current has not as yet altered it's cour≈øe, in favour of the pri≈øoners at the bar.

Many things yet exi≈øt ≈øufficient to keep alive the glow of indignation. I have aimed at ≈øecuring you again≈øt the catching flame. I have endeavoured to di≈øcharge my duty, in this re≈øpect:‚ÄîWhat ≈øucce≈øs will follow tho≈øe endeavours, depends on you, Gentlemen. If being told of your danger will not produce caution, nothing will. If you ‚Ä¢ e determined in opinion, it is in vain to ≈øay more, but if you are zealous enquirers after truth; if you are willing to hear with impartiality‚Äîto examine and judge for your≈øelves‚Äî enough has been ≈øaid to apprize you of tho≈øe avenues, at which the enemies of truth and ju≈øtice are mo≈øt likely to enter‚Äîand mo≈øt ea≈øily to be≈øet you.

I ≈øhall now, for argument's ≈øake only, take it for granted, that the fact of killing, had been proved upon all the pri≈øoners: you are ≈øen≈øible this is not really true; for as to this point, there are ≈øeveral of the pri≈øoners upon whom this fact is not fixed. But as I ≈øhall hereafter take occa≈øion to con≈øider the di≈øtinct ca≈øe of each pri≈øoner, as he is affected by the evidence, I at pre≈øent chu≈øe to avoid confu≈øion, and apply my≈øelf to the full ≈øtrength of the crown; and, upon a ≈øuppo≈øition, that all the pri≈øoners were an≈øwerable for the act of any one, ≈øee how the pri≈øoners are chargeable, by the evidence already offered, with the crime of Murder:‚Äîor rather endeavour to point out to you tho≈øe facts, appearing
by the evidence on the crown ≈øide, which will amount, in law, to a ju≈øtification, an excu≈øe, or, at lea≈øt, an extenuation of their offence.‚ÄîFor we ≈øay, that give the evidence for the king it's full ≈øcope and force, and our offence is reduced, at lea≈øt, to Man≈ølaughter: in which ca≈øe, we claim the privilege of that law, by the ≈øentence of which, if guilty, we mu≈øt ≈øuffer the pains of death:‚Äîa privilege we can never again claim‚Äîa privilege, that by no means implies exemption from all puni≈øhment: the offender becomes liable to impri≈øonment, for a year‚Äîincurs a forfeiture of all goods and chattels; and, till he receives the judgment of law, is to all intents a felon‚Äî≈øubject to all the di≈øabilities and other incidents of a ≈øelon. Without taking up time, in attending and di≈øcu≈ø≈øing points, no way pertinent to the pre≈øent i≈ø≈øue; without a tedious recapitulation of circum≈øtances, with which, I take it, we have no more concern, than either of you, Gentlemen; I ≈øay pa≈ø≈øing over all the≈øe matters as foreign to this trial:‚Äîlet us ≈øtate evidence appearing even from the crown witne≈ø≈øes.

The≈øe witne≈ø≈øes, (who≈øe te≈øtimony I ≈øhall not con≈øider in the order they were produced) inform you, that in the former part of the evening a number of ≈øoldiers ru≈øhed from ≈øome of the lanes near the Guard hou≈øe, or as Col. Mar≈øhall ≈øuppo≈øes, from the Guard hou≈øe it≈øelf. But ≈øome circum≈øtances he relates, as to their dre≈øs, may render it doubtful, whether he is right in this point. Soldiers on guard have a peculiar regimental habiliment, which they never dare put off; and if I am rightly in≈øtructed, no ≈øoldiers, but tho≈øe on duty, are ≈øuffered to be at the Guard-hou≈øe at tho≈øe hours. However thus much is certain, that being dre≈ø≈øed in ≈øhort jackets or working coa ‚Ä¢ s, proves them not to be of that particular party who had mounted guard at this time.

The cry was "where are they‚Äîdamn them where are they!" They brandi≈øh their weapons, and proceed to Corn-hill. What tho≈øe weapons were the witne≈ø≈øes ≈øay differently. But it ≈øhould be mentioned, as we go along, that the ≈øoldiers of the twenty-ninth, are never allowed to wear ≈øwords or cutla≈ø≈øes.

As the≈øe ≈øoldiers pa≈øs down Corn-hill, they a≈ø≈øualt, abu≈øe and attack people. The ≈øoldiers in their turn are beaten. One has his wri≈øt broke‚Äîand the general cry ≈øoon after was‚Äî "they are beaten‚Äîthey are drove into the barracks!"

Some part of this conduct may hereafter be accounted for,
and other parts of it may ≈øtand in a very different light. But we are ready to admit, that their behaviour was altogether unju≈øtifiable‚Äîfor we don't look upon our≈øelves as any way concerned in their conduct.‚ÄîConduct which, if ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes are not mi≈øtaken, ≈øeems more like that of madmen and barbarians, than like rea≈øonable creatures. If they acted like ≈øavages or ruffians, what is that to us? This evidence, therefore not applying to this ca≈øe, we are injured if it has any influence to our prejudice. Being foreign to the i≈ø≈øue, we humbly conceive it ought never to have been introduced;‚Äîor being introduced, it ought to be rejected, in our determining the guilt or innocence of the pri≈øoners.

‚òû Mr. Jo≈øiah Quincy then proceeded to a minute detail of the crown evidence, pointing out, as he went along, tho≈øe circum≈øtances that favoured the pri≈øoners; and commenting chiefly on tho≈øe facts, which ≈øerved to refute or invalidate the po≈øitions of the Council for the Crown; by ≈øhowing an a≈ø≈øult and attack upon the Sentry. He then reviewed tho≈øe parts of the evidence, which had a tendency either to prove in≈øult, abu≈øe, or a≈ø≈øault and battery of the party: he pointed out the various quarters, from which all the≈øe, but e≈øpecially the a≈ø≈øault and battery proceeded: and from the facts, time and circum≈øtances te≈øtified, inferred the attack to have been on various ≈øides at the ≈øame in≈øtant. From the noi≈øes, violence and rattling of the guns he drew other con≈øequences u≈øeful to his cau≈øe. From the inattention of ≈øome, and the forgetfulne≈øs of others; from the tumult, fright, confu≈øion and pa≈ø≈øions in the ≈øcene, he made ≈øuch deductions as might account for the contrariety and ≈øeeming incompatibility of the evidence.

He next very particularly ≈øtated the Evidence for the pri≈øoners, as he had been in≈øtructed it would turn out on examination; and as he opened his evidence, he carefully remarked its conformity to, and connection with, many parts of that already exhibited by the Council for the King.‚Äî He then called the witne≈ø≈øes, who ≈øwore as follow.]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ob≈øerve on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt, any of the inhabitants armed, or any commotions in the ≈øtreets before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the night of the 5th of March la≈øt, a little after dark, as I went home, I met uncommon numbers of people with ≈øticks; at Calef's corner there were more than a dozen inhabitants. I met ≈øome al≈øo in Quaker-lane, and by Mr. Dalton's, going towards King-≈øtreet. I looked upon it to be more than what was common. Their ≈øticks looked not to be common walking canes, but pretty large cudgels.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ob≈øerve any ≈øuch commotions at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Going over the Swing bridge, the evening of the 5th of March, I ≈øaw people running from all corners, with ≈øticks and in≈øtruments in their hands; I being a ≈øtranger was afraid to go home; when I came to Faneuil hall I met with a young man, he ≈øaid he would conduct me home: as I came to Green's lane, I met great numbers, twenty or thirty together, and the ≈øtreets were as full of commotion as ever I ≈øaw in my life.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of ≈øticks were they that they had?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Uncommon ≈øticks, like what are pulled out of hedges.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What part of the town was you in when you fir≈øt noticed the≈øe commotions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was cro≈ø≈øing the Swing bridge. This was before any bells rang.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Give the Court and Jury an account of the tran≈øactions in Dock ≈øquare, on the evening of the 5th March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On that evening I was in company with ≈øome gentlemen in Mr. William Hunter's hou≈øe near Dock ≈øquare, a certain gentleman came in, and a≈øked how we came to be ≈øitting there, ≈øo contented, when there was ≈øuch trouble betwixt the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants; this was betwixt 8 and 9 o'clock. Some of the company went and looked out of the window at the foot of Exchange-lane; I came into the Vendue-room and went to the balcony, there were ≈øo many in it I was afraid it would fall down; I withdrew from thence and looked ‚Ä¢ nt of the window; I ≈øaw a great number of people a≈ø≈øembled there before the bells rung; I ≈øaw a number of people come from the north end; they made two or three ‚Ä¢ dry attacks up that lane where the barracks which are called Murray's, or Smith's batracks were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How we ‚Ä¢ they armed that came from the North-end?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They had ≈øticks or ≈øtaves, I do not know what they are called.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was it a Moon-light night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not remember ≈øeeing the Moon, but it was very light.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Wat number of per≈øons did you ≈øee in Dock ≈øquare?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay, I judge there might be about two hundred in all; they left the ≈øquare and went three different ways, ≈øome up the main ≈øtreet, ≈øome up Royal-exchange-lane, and ≈øome up the other lane; they gave two or three cheers for the main guard; about the ≈øpace of five or ≈øix minutes after the cheers I withdrew from that hou≈øe, and went up Royal-exchange-lane; and when I was about the middle of the lane the guns went off. I turned, and came down the lane, and went home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the bells ring?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard the bells ring, but what time it was I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was it before you went up the lane?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did numbers cry for the main guard, or but one or two?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Numbers did. They al≈øo cryed fire. I ≈øaid it was very odd to come to put out a fire with ≈øticks and bludgeons.

I was in my own hou≈øe, and Mr. Wil≈øon, the former witne≈øs, with me; we heard a noi≈øe, and Mr. M√Æchal≈øon came in and told us there was a di≈øturbance among≈øt the inhabitants and ≈øoldiers; I went to the Vendue balcony, and ≈øaw great numbers coming up from the North-end, with large ≈øticks in their hands, mo≈øt of them I ≈øaw went in parcels up to the barracks, and then came down in numbers. This they did ≈øeveral times, as they gathered from the North end.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were the bells ringing?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I do not remember; a gentleman came up with a red cloak, they gathered round him, and he ≈øtood in the middle of them, and they were all very quiet; he ≈øpoke to them a little while, and then he went off, and they took off their hats, and gave three cheers for the Main guard; they went up Royal-exchange-lane as fa≈øt as they cou ‚Ä¢ d went after them, and ≈øome of the company at my hou≈øe went up the lane al≈øo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the man who ≈øpoke to the≈øe people a tall or ≈øhort man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Pretty tall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How was he dre≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He had a white wig and red cloak, and in≈øtantly after his talking a few minutes to them, they made huzzas for the main guard.

I am the per≈øon that came up ≈øtairs and told the witne≈øs examined before me, that there was a di≈øturbance in the ≈øtreet. The whole I have to ≈øay is this.‚ÄîComing home that evening from a friends hou≈øe in Fore-≈øtreet, I called at a hou≈øe in Union ≈øtreet. Turning the corner of Fore-≈øtreet, I heard a noi≈øe which drew my attention immediately, it ≈øeemed to come from the Po≈øt-Office, or thereabouts: Immediately I went to ≈øee what the matter was. At the bottom of Royal-exchange lane, I a≈øked a man that was at a di≈øtance what the matter was? He ≈øaid it was a ≈øquabble betwixt the inhabitants and ≈øoldiers; I then ≈øtood at the bottom of the lane, I had not ≈øtood long there, till I was obliged to go away, the party, engaged with the ≈øoldiers, having been routed as I thought, came ru≈øhing down towards where I ≈øtood. I went into Mr. Hunter's, found ≈øome gentlemen there; I told them they were very q ‚Ä¢ indeed, con≈øidering the≈øe was ≈øuch a number of people in the ≈øtreet. We went into the balcony and ≈øtood there, to ≈øee the tran≈øactions below; and the only thing material I can recollect, that pa≈ø≈øed, was this: I ≈øaw a pretty large number of people a≈ø≈øembled together, drawn together, I apprehended, by the noi≈øe of them that were fir≈øt engaged with the ≈øoldiers. It was propo≈øed by ≈øeverals of them, to call out fire!‚ÄîFire was called ≈øeveral times, and then the bells were ≈øet a ringing. This drew a great concour≈øe of people, not knowing but it was fire.‚ÄîThe greate≈øt part had ≈øticks of various ≈øorts; they made ≈øeveral attempts to get up a lane leading to Murray's barracks, but I ≈øuppo≈øe meeting with oppo≈øition there, they came down as if they had been pur≈øued. After making ≈øeveral ≈øuch attempts, they a≈ø≈øembled in various little knots, with various leaders, I ≈øuppo≈øe every party had a leader. I heard them propo≈øe, let us go up and attack the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Recollect the words as near as you can.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot recollect the preci≈øe words, but they were to that very effect. Some of them went up Royal-exchange-lane, part of them through the other lane (called Boyl≈øton's-alley,) and part up Cornhill.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who led the party that went up Cornhill?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it was not light enough, and the confu≈øion together, I could not tell which was leader, or which was follower.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did the bells ring then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What bells?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not know what bells they were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you notice if the large≈øt party went up Cornhill?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they did. After they went from that place of the ≈øtreet which I could ≈øee from the balcony, the ≈øtreet was then particularly clear of them, except the people coming from Union-≈øtreet and the other ≈øtreets. Anxiety to know what might happen in King-≈øtreet, led me to take my hat and go to ≈øee: When I was about half way up the lane, the guns were fired, and I ≈øaw the fla≈øhes of ≈øome of them. I then turned and came down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you imagine were a≈ø≈øembled in Dock-≈øquare, when the greate≈øt number was together?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I imagine two hundred.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee a man with a red cloak and white wig?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, he made a con≈øiderable figure there?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he in the attitude of ≈øpeaking, and they of attention?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you hear what he ≈øaid to them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, but after he had harrangued them about three minutes, they huzza'd for the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Give the Court and Jury an account of any commotions you ≈øaw that evening.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The evening of the 5th March, after the nine o'clock bell had rung, I heard the bells ring again, I ≈øuppo≈øed for fire, the people in the neighbourhood a≈øked where it was! I ≈øaid, I would go ≈øee; I went up as far as Faneuil Hall, and to Mr. Jack≈øon's ≈øhop, there were a number of people in Cornhill at the time; I immediately came down again, and went on board an oy≈øter-boat, ≈øtaid there about a quarter of an hour, and heard the guns go off.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body at the Market, take out the feet and break the ≈øtalls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any collection of people there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I a≈øked what was the matter? I was told, a ≈øoldier had hurt an oy≈øter man.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee a number of people with any body at their head?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Give the Court and Jury an account of what you ≈øaw that evening.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The evening of the 5th of March, I ≈øpent at the North End; a little after nine I left the hou≈øe to go home, I live in Green's lane, and my neare≈øt way lay through Dock ≈øquare; I heard a number of people and great noi≈øes. I ≈øoon found it was a quarrel, I ≈øtopped at the corner of Jenkins's-lane ≈øome time; I ≈øaw the people collected clo≈øe to Boyl≈øton's alley, I learned, that is was the town's people and ≈øoldiers a quarreling, I plainly heard that the ≈øound was like people fighting with clubs. Two young men came up to me, and ≈øaid, will you go and help us to fight the ≈øoldiers? I ≈øaid no, I do not intend to, one of them had a cloak, and threw it off into my arms, and then ≈øaid, if you will not go, hold my cloak, and went away with the other, enquiring where were any clubs or cordwood ≈øticks, they hollowed fire! fire! And that collected a few people, about one dozen or ≈øo, pre≈øently the little knots of people pa≈ø≈øed up the pa≈ø≈øage way by the pump, and there was a general run down the ≈øtreet as fa≈øt as they could run, I went into Mrs. Elliot's gate, and I ≈øaw ≈øeven, eight, or ten ≈øoldiers run up the alley that leads from her hou≈øe to King-≈øtreet, they had ≈øomething in their hands, whether it was clubs or other weapons, I cannot tell; whether the bells had begun to ring before that I cannot ≈øay, it was the Brick-meeting bell I fir≈øt heard; I ≈øtaid in Mrs. Elliot's till the bells were done ringing, I left the cloak with her.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which way were the≈øe nine or ten ≈øoldiers going?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
They came down from the alley by the barracks, and run up Jenkins's alley by Mrs. Elliot's hou≈øe, I pa≈ø≈øed through this alley and went into King-≈øtreet, and ≈øaw ≈øome with buckets, the engine was in King-≈øtreet, but nobody with it:‚Äî
I went up by the north ≈øide of the Town hou≈øe and they ≈øeveral knots of people collected, ≈øome a ‚Ä¢
Jack≈øon
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øome by the Town Hou≈øe, and all round in little „Äà‚óä„Äâ I went from one knot to another, to ≈øee if I could „Äà‚óä„Äâ what the matter was, I walked to the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Town Hou≈øe, and the next thing I heard, was hazzaing in King ≈øtreet, and then the≈øe little knots that were con ‚Ä¢ cted an≈øwered the huzza, and went down towards King ≈øtreet, I went by the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Town-Hou≈øe, and ≈øtopped at Mr. Price's office and had an opportunity of ≈øeeing what pa≈ø≈øed on the other ≈øide of the way. Col. Mar≈øhal I think, mu≈øt be mi≈øtaken in what he ≈øays relative to the ≈øhade of the moon's being on the north ≈øide, for I remember well, I went to the ≈øouth-≈øide of the Town-Hou≈øe, on purpo≈øe that I might be in the ≈øhade and ≈øee more clearly what was doing on the oppo≈øite ≈øide of the way. I ≈øaw the Sentinel ≈øtanding with his back to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe door, and a number of people round him, boys and men.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the Sentry in the ≈øhade?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw him very plain ≈øtanding on the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe ≈øteps, I heard a con≈øiderable noi≈øe, the boys were laughing and ≈øaying fire! and why do you not fire? I ≈øaw the Sentinel bring his piece upon a level as if to fire, and the people gave back, and he put it up again. I found the numbers were encrea≈øing, and, while I was ≈øtanding there, two men without hats on, came up to the Main Guard, and ≈øaid, you mu≈øt ≈øend a≈ø≈øi≈øtance directly, or the Sentry will be murdered, the officer I ob≈øerved was quite a young officer, and there were a number of ≈øoldiers ≈øtanding with their watch coats on, whether they or any ≈øoldiers went into the Main-Guard I cannot ≈øay, I heard very ≈øoon the word given, "Guard," and bid take off their watch coats; there came out about ≈øeven, I think their guns were not ≈øhouldered, but they had them in their right hands, walked acro≈øs the ≈øtreet, and took their ≈øtand near the Sentry-box, but whether in a half-moon or circle I cannot tell, the people crouded round them, I heard a great deal of confu≈øed no ‚Ä¢ , a general confu≈øion of noi≈øes, and there I ≈øtood till the guns were fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the≈øe men one of which gave you the cloak, go towards the Market?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear a noi≈øe like the breaking of the ≈øtalls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Give the Court and Jury an account of what you ≈øaw in the ≈øtreets, on the 5th of March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That night I ≈øpent the evening with an acquaintance near the Town-a ‚Ä¢ ok, ≈øitting in the room, the ma≈øter of the hou≈øe came into the room, and ≈øaid, fire was cried, and the bells a ringing: as I belonged to the engine, I was the fir≈øt out of the door, with my ≈øurtout and ≈øtick, when I came out, I ≈øaw a man running to where the Porters ≈øtand, I thought I ≈øhould met our engine coming down the lane or Corn-hill, and when I came round by the Market, I ≈øaw a cro≈øs the Market a number of people coming from the northward; I thought the fire was out, and that it had been at the North end. I ≈øtopt by Col. Jack≈øon's a con≈øiderable time, at la≈øt ≈øomebody came along; I a≈øked where is the fire, they ≈øaid there is no fire but a di≈øpute betwixt the inbitants and ≈øoldiers by Murray's barracks. I went up a little farther and ≈øaw nothing; I moved down again and ≈øtopped where I had been before; the ≈øtreet was middling full, as generally when fire is cryed: at la≈øt I ≈øaw a number of young people get foul of the ≈øtalls in the Market, pulling out the legs of them, I do not remember whether I ≈øaid any thing to them or not: I ≈øtayed there a while, I ≈øaw no di≈øturbance, nor heard no great noi≈øe; the man who was with me ≈øaid, we have no bu≈øine≈øs with the ≈øoldiers nor with their di≈øputes, and we returned to the place we came from, and ≈øtaid there till the guns were fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did they come from that got foul of the ≈øtalls?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some from the northward, and ≈øome by Hubbard's warehou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many were of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Six or ≈øeven.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you at Mr. Hunter's hou≈øe, the 5th of March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I was that evening there in company with ≈øome gentlemen, and to the be≈øt of my remembrance betwixt eight and nine o'clock, ≈øome of the company ≈øaid there is ≈øome noi≈øe in the ≈øtreet; Mr. Hunter ≈øaid it is an alley that there is noi≈øe enough in very often. A gentleman ≈øoon after came in and ≈øaid there is ≈øomething bad in the ≈øtreet, you had as good go and ≈øee what it is, three of the company went to the balcony, I went to the window fronting the ≈øtreet. I ≈øaw con≈øiderable numbers of people coming from the North-end,
all armed, or the greate≈øt part of them, in the ≈øame manner, with white ≈øticks. They made attacks on the barracks, and were always drove back; always as a new fre≈øh party came from the north part of the town, they made a new attack, there were about five or ≈øix different attacks made. In the middle of the ≈øtreet I ≈øaw a large man, with a red cloak and white wigg, they gathered round him, and he ≈øpoke two or three minutes, and they gave ≈øome different cheers for the Main-guard, and I think for the Nec ‚Ä¢
; they ≈øaid they would do for the ≈øoldiers; when they turned round that corner where the ≈øtone ≈øtore is, they beat the ≈øtone with their weapons, and ≈øaid they would do for the ≈øoldiers. Some went up Royal exchange lane, ≈øome went up Jenkin's lane, and ≈øome by the Po≈øt office.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you think there might be in the whole?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Betwixt two and three hundred.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the bells a ringing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I ≈øaw them all go away, I came down and found the gentlemen gone, I went into the alley and heard the fir≈øt gun fired, I then went home, and know no more of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that expre≈ø≈øion, we will do for the ≈øoldiers, uttered by a number or by a few?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By a great number, and they ≈øtruck their weapons again≈øt Simp≈øon's ≈øtone ≈øtore, as they ≈øaid it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you at Mr. William Hunter's on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes. That evening I was at his vendue-room, at the foot of the Royal-exchange-lane, I heard ≈øome noi≈øe; I cannot ≈øay who came up; but a little after dark there came up two gentlemen, who ≈øaid there was a di≈øturbance in the ≈øtreet. I immediately went to the front window, ≈øome of the company into the balcony, where I afterwards went, I ≈øaw numbers of people hallowing fire, fire, in different quarters. Numbers enquiring where the fire was; they gathered in a large body; ≈øome went up by way of the Po≈øt-office, ≈øome went up the lane by the pump, and ≈øome came down forcibly as if cha≈øed: they whi≈øtled through their fingers and cried fire: Among the re≈øt I ob≈øerved a Gentleman with a red cloack and white wigg, the croud gathered round
him, they ≈øtaid a little while with him, and then drew off and huzzaed for the Main-Guard, they then di≈øper≈øed, ≈øome went up Royal-exchange-lane, ≈øome went up Jenkin's alley, and ≈øome went up Cornhill, I ≈øaw no more of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there when they were talking with the gentleman?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay how many there were, there was a great number.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did they ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ≈øtood oppo≈øite Mr Lewis Deblois ≈øhop.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you ≈øee them ≈øtrike with their ≈øticks at Mr. Simp≈øons ≈øtore?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear them ≈øay they would do for the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you of the company at Mr. Hunter's?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I was there that evening; a gentleman came in and ≈øaid there was a di≈øturbance in the ≈øtreet, I went down to the lower room, and went to the balcony, and ≈øaw people going up that alley where the barracks are.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear the la≈øt witne≈øs examined, do you confirm all he mentioned?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not all of it, the people went up to the alley, and ran down quick as if they had met with oppo≈øition, they ≈øtood about the pump, they encrea≈øed from the North end to pretty large numbers, they gathered together in a croud oppo≈øite to where I ≈øtood, and huzzaed for the Main guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you certain they huzzaed for the Main guard?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I am certain of it, I went with one or two more into the lane, intending for King ≈øtreet, when we heard the guns, I turned and went home.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you know of any di≈øturbance or commotion that evening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
On the evening of the 5th of March I went from my own hou≈øe in Queen-≈øtreet, about ≈øeven o'clock, to ≈øpend the evening with ≈øome company at Mr. Slyve≈øter's at the South-end; in my way I met not le≈øs then fifty people, with white ≈øticks in their hands, in ≈ømall parcels, and the company all ob≈øerved they met with numbers of people, and ≈øaid they were apprehen≈øive of the con≈øequences. Somebody came
in and ≈øaid there was fire, Mr. Fleeming ≈øaid he would ≈øend his man to ≈øee where the fire was, and de≈øired us not to be unea≈øy, for he had heard it was only to gather people to fight the ≈øoldiers, or to this effect: I was unea≈øy however, and came away to go home. I met a good many people with ≈øticks, and bags, and ≈øome other things. I met Mr. Fleeming's man coming back, and he ≈øaid it was no fire, but the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants fighting: I ≈øaw two engines, and the people putting their buckets and bags in people's hou≈øes. I enquired where the fire was; I got the ≈øame an≈øwer, no fire, but the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants fighting. I heard ≈øome ≈øay come let us go back, others, ≈øaid no by God we will go and help them. I ≈øaw Mr. Knight ≈øtanding at his own door, I ≈øtopt but very little time, left him and came to the head of King-≈øtreet. I heard ≈øomebody ≈øay damn them why do not they break the gla≈øs. I imagined ≈øomebody had got into the Guard-hou≈øe, and that they wanted to break the gla≈øs to get them out. I went home, and in about ten minutes, I heard the guns go off.

sp.speaker: Q.
