sp.p: Was it ≈øoldiers or inhabitants that wanted to break the gla≈øs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was the inhabitants.

On the 5th of March I came up King-≈øtreet ≈øoon after the bells had rung for nine. I came by the Main-guard, ≈øaw the Sentinel as u≈øual, and ≈øaw no di≈øturbance; I went home, took up the news-paper, and read about half of an hour; by and bye I heard the bells ring, which I took for fire. I run to the door, when I came there, the people were pa≈ø≈øing pretty thick, ≈øome with buckets, ≈øome with bags, and numbers with ≈øticks and clubs; they ≈øaid there was no fire, but ≈øome di≈øturbance with the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants; I returned into the room ≈øometime, but feeling unea≈øy, I went to the door again, and ≈øaw ≈øeveral companies of people pa≈øs, ≈øix or eight in a company; one company con≈øi≈øting of eight or ten, had white ≈øticks or clubs in their hands; one of them hallowed out, damn their bloods lets go and attack the Main guard, and knock them to hell fir≈øt. There was one in the ≈øame company made a ≈øtop, and either ≈øaid I will go back and get my gun, or let us go back and get our guns, I cannot tell which.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was this before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes, this ≈øtopt my curio≈øity from going to King-≈øtreet.
I thought it was be≈øt to ≈øtay in the hou≈øe. I ≈øhut the door and went in; I told my wife if ≈øhe heard any firing not to be afraid, for I was apprehen≈øive there would be blood ≈øhed from what I had heard. I tarried about two or three minutes in the room; I felt very unea≈øy, and walked to the door again, and being there about a minute or two, I heard one gun fired, in about two ≈øeconds I heard another, and ≈øo on till five, ≈øix or ≈øeven were di≈øcharged. It was all in about twelve or fourteen ≈øeconds at the farther≈øt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was you at the Green Dragon, on the evening of the 5th of March, in company with ≈øome gentlemen there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ob≈øervation was made on the ringing of the bells, by any of the company?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some one in the room ≈øaid it was not fire, but a rumpus.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did any particular per≈øon of that company there, ≈øay it is no fire but a rumpus with the ≈øoldiers, and I am prepared for them, and immediately take a pi≈øtol or pair of pi≈øtols out of his pocket?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some one ob≈øerved there was a rumpus, but I ≈øaw no pi≈øtol.

div.stage: William Strong, Clerk in the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe, ≈øworn.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was you in King ≈øtreet on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
On the evening of the 5th of March I was at Mr. Mar≈øtons, ≈øeveral of us were ≈øtanding by the fire: we heard the cry of fire, ≈øome ≈øaid we will go out and ≈øee where the fire is. I went and I ≈øaw ≈øeveral people running to and fro, I a≈øked what the matter was, they ≈øaid a ≈øoldier had killed a boy. I was an≈øwered in that manner by another; ≈øome people ≈øaid we will go back again and get our ≈øticks: I did not ≈øee any number of people, but a few running up to King-≈øtreet, one of them ≈øtruck the ground with his ≈øtick and ≈øhivered it. I then went into King ≈øtreet and was coming away again, when I heard a huzza and a number of feet behind me, and I ≈øtood to let them pa≈øs; there might be about ninety; they run up King-≈øtreet huzzaing. I walked after them, when they came oppo≈øite the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, they ≈øtopped, and ≈øome ≈øaid that is the fellow that u≈øed the inhabitants ill; another contradicted them and ≈øaid it was
not him; upon that the people encroached on the Sentinel; I was in the mid≈øt of the people, and he retreated back and they went forward, at la≈øt I ≈øaw him go on the ≈øteps of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, and they went clo≈øer, and he ≈øet his back to the door and loaded. I heard the ball go down di≈øtinctly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ninety or more.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The generality of them were young men. He pre≈øented his gun, and ≈øaid keep of or I will fire upon you; the reply was, fire, God damn you fire, fire and be damn'd. I went about fifteen yards below, there was a man ≈øtanding by me, he had the butt end of a bat in his hand, and ≈øaid he would throw it at the Sentinel, I ≈øaid do not, for he will fire at whatever place it comes from. Whether he threw it or not I do not know, for I left him and went to Mr. Sherwin's door. I was ≈øaying it was imprudent to attack a Sentinel on his po≈øt, ≈øomebody ≈øaid he was di≈øarmed; I thought ≈øo too, for I ≈øaw the glittering of arms; I walked to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe ≈øteps, curio≈øity led me to ≈øee if they were ≈øo prudent as to fa≈øten the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe door; I tryed the latch, and it was fa≈øt; a fellow ≈øaid to one of the ≈øoldiers, damn you why do you turn your bayonet this way, turn it the other way. I thought I was not ≈øafe there, but went to my old place, and ≈øtood there a few minutes; I thought I heard two guns cock, immediately I heard one go off, ≈øoon after another, and I think four more. I think ≈øix in all. The people ≈øaid where I was ≈øtanding, they fired nothing but powder. I thought to go up to an acquaintance's hou≈øe, and went in the middle of the ≈øtreet, and coming oppo≈øite to the ≈øoldiers, I ≈øaw two men lay, one on the right and one on the left, on their backs; I concluded they were dead.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing hit the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe there were ≈ønow balls thrown, but they fell ≈øhort of him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The≈øe people that were round the Sentiel, had they clubs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ≈øome of them.

div.stage: FIVE o'Clock P. M. the Court adjourned till next morning, Friday, nine o'clock.
Friday, NINE o'Clock, the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of the proceedings at Murray's barracks on the evening of the 5th March la≈øt, previous to the firing in King-≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I live oppo≈øite the barrack-hou≈øe, and was at home that evening. A little after eight I heard a noi≈øe and di≈øturbance in the ≈øtreet, I went out to know what it was, and was told there was a difference between the towns people and ≈øoldiers. I ≈øaw ≈øeveral ≈øoldiers pa≈øs and repa≈øs, ≈øome with bayonets, ≈øome with clubs and one thing and another. I ≈øtood at my own door; I ob≈øerved the noi≈øe ≈øeemed to come from towards the market; I ≈øaw a number of people running to and fro acro≈øs the bottom of the ≈øtreet. I ≈øhut my door and went in about eight or ten minutes. I heard a noi≈øe like a ≈øingle per≈øon running thro' Boyl≈øton's alley with great violence; he ran as I took it towards the barrack gate, and cried out, town born turn out, town born turn out, then turned to the ≈øide of the lane, and ≈øaid town born turn out, town born turn out. I heard this repeated twenty or thirty times, I believe, it was the con≈øtant cry. I remember after coming out the ≈øecond time, to hear the voice of a per≈øon which I took to be En≈øign Maul, ≈øay, who is this fellow, lay hold of him. I did not hear a word pa≈øs betwixt the people that pa≈ø≈øed backwards and forwards, and the Sentinel at the barrack gate, nor from the Sentinel to them; this cry of town born turn out, was repeated for ≈øeven or eight mintes, when I heard the voice of a great many more.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were they ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I do not know, they might be ≈øoldiers; from the fir≈øt of that cry it might be a quarter of an hour or more, they ≈øeemed to retreat and come on again, and ≈øtruck their ≈øticks very hard again≈øt the corner of the hou≈øe. The collection of ≈øuch a number, with the noi≈øe of the clubs, induced me to lock my door, put out my light in the fore part of my hou≈øe, and to go up ≈øtairs into the chamber fronting the barracks; when there, I ob≈øerved four or five officers of the 29th, ≈øtanding on their own ≈øteps, and there might be betwixt twenty or thirty of the town's people ≈øurrounding the ≈øteps. About that time came a little man, who he was I do not know; he ≈øaid, why do you not keep your ≈øoldiers in their barracks, they ≈øaid they had done every thing they po≈ø≈øibly could, and would do every thing in their power,
to keep them in their barracks, on which he ≈øaid, are the inhabitants to be knocked down in the ≈øtreet, are they to be murdered in this manner; the officers ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted they had done their utmo≈øt, and would do it, to keep the ≈øoldiers in their barracks; the ≈øame per≈øon then ≈øaid, you know the country has been u≈øed ill, you know the town has been u≈øed ill, we did not ≈øend for you, we will not have you here, we will get rid of you, or we will drive you away; which of the la≈øt expre≈ø≈øions I cannot ≈øay, but it was one or the other: the officers ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted they had done their utmo≈øt, and would do it, to keep the ≈øoldiers in their barracks, and begged the per≈øon to u≈øe his intere≈øt to di≈øper≈øe the people, that no mi≈øchief might happen; whether he did addre≈øs the people or not, I cannot ≈øay, for the confu≈øion was ≈øo great I could not di≈øtingui≈øh.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How was that man dre≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was a little man, I think in a ≈øurtout; immediately the cry of home, home, was mentioned; I dont recollect ≈øeeing any per≈øon go away at the fir≈øt cry, and there was ≈øuch confu≈øion I could not tell what was ≈øaid, but in five minutes afterwards the cry home, home, was repeated, on which the greate≈øt part of them, po≈ø≈øibly two thirds, went up Boyl≈øton's alley towards the Town-hou≈øe, huzzaing for the Main Guard,

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
A con≈øiderable number. I then ob≈øerved more of the towns people come from towards the Market; there was a good deal of ≈øquabble and noi≈øe betwixt the people and the officers, but what was ≈øaid I could not bear. The next thing I recollect in the affair was, a little boy came down the alley, clapping his hand to his head, and cried he was killed, he was killed; on which one of the officers took hold of him, and damned him for a little ra≈øcal, a≈øking him what bu≈øine≈øs he had out of doors; the boy ≈øeemed to be about ≈øeven or eight year old. Some little time after that, I ≈øaw a ≈øoldier come out of the barrack gate with his mu≈øket, he went directly facing the alley, in the middle of the ≈øtreet, and kneeled down on one knee, and ≈øaid now damn your bloods, I will make a lane through you all; while he was pre≈øenting, Mr. Maul an En≈øign, with either Mr. Dixon or Mr. Minchin, I do not know which, came after him, immediately laid hold of him, and took the mu≈øket from him, ≈øhoved him towards the barrack, and I think gave him the
mu≈øket again, and charged him at his peril to come out again. I do not recollect any di≈øcour≈øe that pa≈ø≈øed between the towns people and officers, there was ≈øtill ≈øuch clamour and confu≈øion, that I could not hear what pa≈ø≈øed; but in a little time either the ≈øoldier who came out before, or another, came out again, he repeated much the ≈øame words as the other, he had his gun in his hand, he did not offer to kneel down, but u≈øed the ≈øame expre≈ø≈øions.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he pre≈øent his firelock?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was pre≈øenting when Mr. Maul knocked him down, took his mu≈økuet from him, drove him into the baracks, and I think the barrack gate was then ≈øhut; about this time I recollect I heard Dr. Cooper's bell ring, I heard ≈øome officer ≈øay, go and ≈øtop that bell from ringing, whether any body went or not, I cannot ≈øay, but it did not ring a great while: About this time I ≈øaw Capt. Goldfinch of the fourteenth, on the ≈øteps with the officers of the twenty-ninth; there came up another little man, who he was I do not know, but in a much different manner from what the other did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How was he dre≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He had on a great coat or ≈øurtout of a light brown, he reque≈øted the ≈øoldiers might be kept in their barracks, and that the officers would do every thing in their power to keep them there, the officers ≈øaid, they had, and would do ≈øo; and as the ≈øoldiers were in their barracks, begged the people might go away; this little man ≈øaid to the people, gentlemen, you hear what the officers ≈øay, that the ≈øoldiers are all in their barracks, and you had better go home; on which the cry was, home, home, home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you ≈øuppo≈øe this was after you heard the bell ring?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes: on which a great many went up the alley again, and I heard the expre≈ø≈øion, Let us go to the Main-Guard: Capt. Goldfinch was ≈øtill on the ≈øteps, and I heard his voice ≈øtill talking, and I think he de≈øired every per≈øon would go away; while he was talking, I heard the report of a mu≈øket.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long was that after the cry of home, home.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
It was not many minutes; in a few ≈øeconds I heard the report of a ≈øecond gun, pre≈øently after that a third; upon the firing of the fir≈øt gun, I heard Capt. Goldfinch ≈øay, I thought it would come to this, it is time for me to go.‚Äî I then ≈øaw a ≈øoldier come down the alley from Cornhill,
and went up to the ≈øteps where the officers ≈øtood, and ≈øaid, they fired from or upon the Main guard. I then heard the drum at the Main-Guard beat to arms, I came down ≈øtairs and did not go out till I was ≈øent for to ≈øome of the wounded people.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: At the time when the fir≈øt ≈øoldier came out, were there a body of people in the ≈øtreet before the barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were ≈øome, but I ≈øuppo≈øe the mo≈øt part were in the alley, there were ≈øeveral about the meeting-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they ≈øay or do any thing to the ≈øoldiers who came out with their mu≈økets?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The officers immediately took hold of them and turned them in.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: You was ≈øent for to Maverick?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did he ≈øay any thing to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, about two hours before his death, I a≈øked him concerning the affair, he went he ≈øaid up the lane, and ju≈øt as he got to the corner, he heard a gun, he did not retreat back, but went to the Town-Hou≈øe, as he was going along, he was ≈øhot: It ≈øeems ≈øtrange by the direction of the ball, how he could be killed by the firing at the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe; it wounded a portion of the liver, ≈øtomach and inte≈øtines, and lodged betwixt the lower ribs, where I cut it out, the ball mu≈øt have ≈øtruck ≈øome wall or ≈øomething el≈øe, before it ≈øtruck him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did he ≈øay he was when he was wounded?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was betwixt Royal exchange-lane and the Town-hou≈øe, going up towards the Town hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you at Murray's barracks that evening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The 5th of March, about nine in the evening, I was pa≈ø≈øing over Cornhill, I ≈øaw a number collected by the pa≈ø≈øage to the barracks, I went towards it and two or three people called me by name, and begged me to endeavour to ≈øend the ≈øoldiers to their barracks, or el≈øe there would be murder, with difficulty I got to the entrance of the pa≈ø≈øage, the people were pelting the ≈øoldiers with ≈ønow-balls, the ≈øoldiers were defending them≈øelves at the entrance.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had the ≈øoldiers cutla≈ø≈øes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No by no means, I think one of them had a fire-≈øhovel, as ≈øoon as the ≈øoldiers knew me, they with my per≈øua≈øion went to the bottom of the pa≈ø≈øage, when I got there,
I ≈øaw ≈øome officers of the twenty-ninth, I told tho≈øe officers I ≈øu≈øpected there would be a riot, and as I was the olde≈øt officer I ordered the men to the barracks, and they were immediately confined; the mob followed me and came to the gate of the barracks, and abu≈øed the men very much indeed, with bad language, ≈øo that the men mu≈øt have been enraged very much, but by the vigilence and activity of the officers, the men were kept within bounds; the mob ≈øtill in≈øulted the men, dared them to come out, called them a pack of ≈øcoundrels, that dared not come out to fight them, and it was with difficulty they were kept in their barracks, I never heard ≈øuch abu≈øe in my life, from one man to another. A little man came up and ≈øpoke to the people, and de≈øired them to go home, as they ≈øaw the officers u≈øed their be≈øt endeavours to keep the men in their barracks; immediately the be≈øt part made towards the pa≈ø≈øage to Cornhill, I ≈øuppo≈øe a body of about forty or fifty people. I thought it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øtay ≈øome time to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the officers in keeping the men in their barracks, in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after the people had moved off, I heard ≈øome guns fire, and the Main-Guard drum beat to arms; I told Mr. Dixon it was nece≈ø≈øary for me to move off, to join my own regiment. The ≈øame evening, about half an hour before this affair happened, I was in King-≈øtreet, and was acco≈øted by a barber's boy, who ≈øaid, there goes the fellow who hath not paid my ma≈øter for dre≈ø≈øing his hair, fortunately for me, I had his receipt in my pocket, the Sentinel ≈øaid, he is a gentleman, and if he owes you any thing he will pay it: I pa≈ø≈øed on without taking any notice of what the boy ≈øaid.
sp.stage: Benjamin Davis, jun. ≈øon to Mr. Davis a former witne≈øs ≈øworn.
sp.p:
On the evening of the 5th March la≈øt, near the bottom of Royal exchange-lane, I ≈øaw a mob by Mr. Greenleaf's, I went right along into King ≈øtreet, I ≈øaw the Sentinel; a barber's boy was there crying, and ≈øaid the Sentry had ≈øtruck him, and a≈øked him what bu≈øine≈øs he had to do it: I went home and ≈øtaid at the gate in Green's lane ≈øome time, Samuel Gray (one of the per≈øons killed that night in King-≈øtreet) came along, and a≈øked where the fire was? I ≈øaid there was no fire, it was the ≈øoldiers fighting, he ≈øaid, damn it, I am glad of it, I will knock ≈øome of them on the head; he ran off, I ≈øaid to him, take heed you do not get killed in the
a≈øtray your≈øelf, he ≈øaid, do not you fear, damn their bloods.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had he a ≈øtick in his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He had one under his arm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of a ≈øtick was it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not take notice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long was this before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not ≈øuppo≈øe he could have got into King-≈øtreet two minutes before the firing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did you hear or ≈øee pa≈ø≈øing through Quaker-lane or Green's lane, on the 5th of March la≈øt in the evening!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I came out of the Green Dragon tavern about nine o'clock, I went up to King-≈øtreet, I heard no noi≈øe, nor ≈øaw any per≈øon, I went through Quaker lane into Green's lane, had a per≈øon with me hand in hand, I met about fifteen per≈øons walking on different ≈øides of the ≈øtreet, and they had ≈øticks in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of ≈øticks were they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ≈øeemed to be pretty large ≈øticks, rather too large for walking-≈øticks, ju≈øt as they pa≈ø≈øed, I turned about and heard them ≈øay, we are rather too ≈øoon, I pa≈ø≈øed on and went on board a ve≈ø≈øel at Gri≈ø≈øin's wharf, when I came on board, I ≈øaid to the people, I believed there would be mi≈øchief that night, for I had met ≈øeveral people armed with ≈øticks, and what the con≈øequences would be I did not know, for they ≈øeemed to be after ≈øomething; ju≈øt as I ≈øpoke, we heard the bells ring, and ≈øome ≈øaid it could not be the u≈øual bell for nine o'clock, they had heard that ring before, they all went on deck, and hearing a noi≈øe and cry of fire, together with the bells, every per≈øon went off and left me alone.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were on board the ve≈ø≈øel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Four went away; I went aloft to ≈øee where the fire was, I heard the engines going along the ≈øtreet and then ≈øtop, I heard Mrs. Mar≈øton who keeps tavern at the head of the wharf, ≈øay, Good God! this is not fire, there will be murder committed this night; a little after I heard a huzzaing and guns go off in King ≈øtreet, I think ≈øeven.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you count them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes, I think there were ≈øeven, I think there were no more; I remained there till a per≈øon came down the wharf,
and I a≈øked him what was the matter? He told me there were ≈øome people killed in King-≈øtreet.

On the 5th of March, I was in Royal exchange lane, as the clock ≈øtruck nine I came up the lane, and at the head of the lane hearing ≈øome abu≈øive language by two boys, I ≈øtoped at Stone's tavern, they were abu≈øing the Sentinel; before the box ≈øtood about twelve or fourteen lads, I often ≈øaw the boys go towards them and back to the Sentinel with a fre≈øh repetition of oaths, they ≈øaid to him, damn you, you ≈øon of a bitch, called him lob≈øter and ra≈øcal, wi≈øhed he was in hell's flames, often and often lowly ra≈øcal; I neither heard, nor ≈øaw the Sentinel do any thing to them, only ≈øaid it was his po≈øt, and he would maintain it, and if they offered to mole≈øt him, he would run them through, upon his ≈øaying this, two boys made up ≈øome ≈ønow balls, and threw them at the Sentinel.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they hit him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot ≈øay, but on their throwing ≈ønow balls, the Sentinel called out guard, guard, two or three times.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did he call loud?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very loud, upon that, there were ≈øome ≈øoldiers came from towards the Main Guard, ≈øeven or eight I believe, they were not of the guard by their having ≈øurtout coats on, they came towards the Sentinel, ≈øome had bayonets, ≈øome ≈øwords, others ≈øticks in their hands, one had a large kitching tongs in his hand, on their approach, the≈øe people and the boys who ≈øtood before the box went up to the back of the Town Hou≈øe by the barber's ≈øhop; I then cro≈ø≈øed King-≈øtreet and intended to go in by Pudd ‚Ä¢ ng lane, and I heard a noi≈øe in the Main-≈øtreet, three or four of the≈øe ≈øoldiers came down to me, and damned me, and a≈øked who I was, I ≈øaid, I was going home peaceably, and interfered with neither one ≈øide or another, one of them with a bayonet or ≈øword gave me a light ≈øtroke over my ≈øhoulder, and ≈øaid, friend you had better go home, for by all I can fore-≈øee, there will be the devil to pay or blood ≈øhed this night: they turned and went towards the Sentinel at the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know the≈øe ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I did not; I then, in≈øtead of going by Pudding-lane, went up by the Guard hou≈øe, and when I had pa≈ø≈øed it a little
way, I ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers who went down before the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe returning back, with a mob before them, driving them up pa≈øt the Guard hou≈øe. I ≈øtepped on pretty quick and endeavoured to get into Mr. Jones ≈øhop the Apothecary:

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of people were there before the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sixteen or eighteen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they men or boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some of them were boys, but the mo≈øt of them were men from twenty to five and twenty years of age I believe; Jones's people ≈øhut the door and would not let me in; I went to the ≈øide of the Brick-meeting, and ≈øaw two or three boys or lads, pu≈øhing at the windows to get in and ring the bell. I went home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you take the ≈øtroke you received from the ≈øoldier to be in anger?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was not in anger, it was very light.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear a noi≈øe in the ≈øtreet at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I heard a great deal of noi≈øe, I took it to be about Queen-≈øtreet, and towards the Po≈øt ‚Ä¢ office.

On the evening of the 5th of March I was at my lodgings in Blind lane at the ≈øouth part of the town, I heard a bell ring, which I took at fir≈øt for nine o'clock, but recollecting I had heard the be≈øt ring for nine before, I thought it mu≈øt be for fire. I went to the top of the hou≈øe but could ≈øee no fire; hearing by this time ≈øeveral bells ring, I came down and found the family at the gate; I a≈øked what the matter was, I was an≈øwered, there was a riot in King-≈øtreet. I ≈øaw ≈øeveral men pa≈øs, not in a body, but in two's and ≈øingly; they walked fa≈øter than people generally do on bu≈øine≈øs, they went up Hogg-lane; I ob≈øerved that not a man pa≈ø≈øed but what had either a club, ≈øword, hanger, cutla≈øs, or gun; as I had rea≈øon to believe people in a military character were not agreable, I went in and ordered my ≈øervant not to go out. I went a ≈øecond time to the gate, and ≈øaw more men pa≈ø≈øing by in the ≈øame manner as before; pre≈øently after that, I heard the report of ≈øeveral guns. I heard the drum beat to arms, which I knew to be cu≈øtomary when a riot happens, but as the drum come nearer, I di≈øcovered a peculiarity in the beating, which made me imagine it was not a regular drum. I did not go from my lodgings that night.

On the evening of the 5th of March I was at my lodgings, I heard a noi≈øe, and went out towards Union-≈øtreet, and ≈øaw people coming from the North-end, with ≈øticks and clubs in their hands; it was about nine o'clock. I followed them to Dock-≈øquare, ≈øomebody a≈øked what was the matter, he was an≈øwered, that a boy and ≈øoldier had been foul of one another; they hallowed King-≈øtreet; I went up to the foot of Jenkin's lane, and there I ≈øaw a tall Molatto fellow, the ≈øame that was killed, he had two clubs in his hand, and he ≈øaid, here take one of them, I did ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of clubs were they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were cord wood ≈øticks; I went up to the head of the lane, and I dropt the ≈øtick in the ≈ønow; he went on cur≈øing and ≈øwearing at the ≈øoldiers, down towards where the people ≈øurrounded the ≈øoldiers; I ≈øtood by the ≈øtone ≈øteps at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, there were people coming from all parts, calling out bloody back, and one thing and another; I could not di≈øtingui≈øh what one half of them ≈øaid; I had not been long there 'till three or four guns went off, and I went home.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body ≈øtrike upon their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, but I heard the ≈øoldiers ≈øay keep off, keep off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of people was there in Dock ≈øquare?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About two hundred.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any body ≈øay kill them, kill them, knock them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the people appear to be pre≈ø≈øing o ‚Ä¢ the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they were as I thought.
sp.stage: William Davis, Serjeant-major of the 14th Regime ‚Ä¢ , ≈øworn.
sp.p: Monday evening the 5th of March, about eight o'clock, I was going towards the North-end in Fore-≈øtreet, near Wentworth's wharff, I ≈øaw a number of people in the ≈øtreet before me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About two hundred, I then ≈øtept a≈øide, and when they came up, I ≈øaw ≈øeveral armed with clubs, and large ≈øticks, and ≈øome had guns; they came down regularly in two's and three's a brea≈øt; they were a minute in pa≈ø≈øing me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they ≈øoldiers that had guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw no ≈øoldier in the ≈øtreet; I heard them ≈øaying damn the dogs knock them down, we will knock down the fir≈øt officer, or bloody backed ra≈øcal we ≈øhall meet this night; ≈øome of them then ≈øaid they would go to the ≈øouthward, and join ≈øome of their friends there, and attack the damned ≈øcoundrels, and drive them out of the town, for they had no bu≈øine≈øs here. Apprehending danger if I ≈øhould be in my regimentals, I went into a hou≈øe at the North end and changed my dre≈øs, and in my return from the North-end, about nine, coming near Dock ≈øquare, I heard a great noi≈øe a whi≈øtling and rattling of wood; I came near the Market place, and ≈øaw a great number of people there, knocking again≈øt the po≈øts, and tearing up the ≈øtalls, ≈øaying damn the lob≈øters, where are they now; I heard ≈øeveral voices, ≈øome ≈øaid let us kill that damned ≈øcoundrel of a Sentry, and then attack the Main-guard; ≈øome ≈øaid, let us go to Smith's barracks, others ≈øaid let us go to the rope-walks; they divided:‚ÄîThe large≈øt number went up Royal-exchange-lane, and another party up Fitch's alley, and the re≈øt through the main ≈øtreet, up Cornhill. I pa≈ø≈øed by the Golden-Ball, I ≈øaw no per≈øon there but a woman, per≈øuading a man to ≈øtay at home; he ≈øaid he would not, he would go among≈øt them, if he lo≈øt his life by it. I went into King-≈øtreet, looking towards the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, I ≈øaw a number of people ≈øeemingly in great commotion; I went towards my barracks, and near the fi≈øh ≈øtall at Oliver's dock, I met a great number of people coming towards King ≈øtreet, with clubs and large ≈øticks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What time was this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was pa≈øt nine, for I heard bells ring before. One of them was loading his piece by Oliver's dock, he ≈øaid he would do for ≈øome of the≈øe ≈øcoundrels that night. The people were u≈øing threats again≈øt the ≈øoldiers and Commi≈ø≈øioners, damn the ≈øcoundrels and villains of ≈øoldiers and Commi≈ø≈øioners, and damn the villain that fir≈øt ≈øent them to Bo≈øton, they ≈øhall not be here two nights longer. I went to my barracks; the roll had been called, and there was not a man ab≈øent, except ≈øome officers that quartered in the town, and their ≈øervants. Immediately after I heard as it were a gun fired in King-≈øtreet, and afterwards two or three more.

On the evening of the 5th March, betwixt nine and ten
o'clock, I was at my own hou≈øe and heard the bells ring, I run out to know where the fire was; I got from Byles's meeting down to the South meeting; I ≈øaw a number of men and boys armed with clubs, and fifteen or twenty more coming along, ≈øome were damning the ≈øoldiers that they would de≈øtroy them, and ≈øink them, and they would have revenge for ≈øomething or other I could not tell what, that they would drive ‚Ä¢ m before them: ≈øome of the people there ≈øaid they had been to Rowe's barracks, and had driven the ≈øoldiers or the Sentinel into the barracks. I went to the Town-hou≈øe, there I ≈øaw Mr. Cox; I ≈øaw a number of people with clubs; I ≈øaw at a di≈øtance, a parcel of ≈øoldiers at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe; I went down to the right of them, where Capt Pre≈øton ≈øtood; I had not been there a minute before the guns were fi ‚Ä¢ ed, previous to which, I ≈øaw ≈øeveral things but dont know what they were, thrown at the ≈øoldiers, as they ≈øtood in a circle by the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe. I was at the we≈øt of the ≈øoldiers; I was looking over the Molatto's ≈øhoulder: I ≈øaw Samuel Cray there. Upon the≈øe things being thrown, I intended to retreat as fa≈øt as I could; I had not got three yards before the guns were fired, fir≈øt one, then another, and ≈øo on, I think there were ≈øeven in all.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Before you turned, did you ≈øee any thing ≈øtrike the guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not ≈øee, but I heard ≈øomething ≈øtrike, and the guns clatter. There was a great noi≈øe, the cry was fire, damn you fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the cry general?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it was general.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you imagine were then gathered round the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fifty or ≈øixty able bodied men.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they crowd near the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So near, that I think you could not get your hat betwixt them and the bayonets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people do you think there might be in the whole?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About two hundred.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ≈øoldiers ≈øay any thing to the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
They never opened their lips; they ≈øtood in a trembling manner, as if they expected nothing but death. They fired fir≈øt on the right. I was looking on the whole body, no one between me and the ≈øoldiers that interrupted my
≈øight; I ≈øaw no blows given, or any of the ≈øoldiers fall.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Might not their trembling proceed from rage as well as fear?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It might proceed from both.
Note. This witne≈øs was called on the part of the Crown, if invalidate the te≈øtimony of Ru≈ø≈øel the former witne≈øs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you come down from the South end with Mr. Ru≈ø≈øel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I met him at the Town-hou≈øe. I ≈øaw three ≈øoldiers, two belonging to the Neck, and one to the MainGuard, by Liberty tree, I was at Mr. Gore's ≈øhop oppo≈øite the Tree; one ≈øaid to the other, bring half your guard, and we will bring half ours, and we will blow up this damned pole; I ≈øaid, ≈øo ≈øure as you offer ye ≈øcound ‚Ä¢ els to blow up that pole, you will have your brains blown out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How were the≈øe ≈øoldiers dre≈ø≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In their regimentals, one was a drummer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he a black man?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he was a white man.

I was at the North-end, and heard the bells ring, I thought it was fire; I came up as u≈øual to go to the fire; I heard it was not fire, but the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants were fighting; I came by Cornhill, and there were a number of people an hundred and fifty, or two hundred; I a≈øked them what was the matter, they ≈øaid a number of ≈øoldiers had been out with bayonets and cutla≈ø≈øes, and had attacked and cut the people all down Cornhill, and then retreated to their barracks; a fellow ≈øaid they had been cutting fore and aft. The people fell gradually down to Dock-≈øquare. I came up Cornhill, and went down King ≈øtreet, I ≈øaw the Seninel at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe ≈øteps loading his piece; coming up to the people, they ≈øaid the Sentinel was going to fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many per≈øons were there at that time round the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About fifteen or twenty, he was waving his piece about, and held it in the po≈øition that they call charged bayonets. I told him if he fired he mu≈øt die for it, he ≈øaid damn them, if they mole≈øted him he would fire; the boys were hallowing fire and be damned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How old were the≈øe boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Seventeen or eighteen years old. I endeavoured to keep one fellow off from the Sentinel, I either ≈øtruck him or pu≈øhed him away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear one of the per≈øons ≈øay, God damn him, we will knock him down for ≈ønapping?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear a young fellow, one U≈øher, about eighteen years of age ≈øay this.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the party come down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the manner of their coming down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They came down in a kind of a trot, or a very fa≈øt walk.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they come down in a threatening po≈øture?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Very threatening, at lea≈øt their countenances looked ≈øo, they ≈øaid make way, damn you make way, and they pricked ≈øome of the people.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the Corporal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw a per≈øon with the party, whom I took to be the Corporal.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had he a ≈øurtout on?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, he had.
sp.stage: John Bulkely, Clerk to Mr. Jo≈øiah Quincey, ≈øworn.
sp.p: Hearing the bells ring I went out, and imagined it had been for fire, but found I was mi≈øtaken. I went to Mr. Quincy's office near the Main Guard, there was a prodigious noi≈øe in King-≈øtreet. I apprehended the Sentinel was in danger, and ≈øtood in expectation of ≈øeeing the guard turned out. Capt. Pre≈øton was before the office, and appeared in a great flutter of ≈øpirit. I knew not he was Captain of the day. A very young officer commanded the guard, I pitied his ≈øituation.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What induced you to believe the guard would be turned out?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: By the Sentinel's being ≈øurrounded, and the noi≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number was about him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About fifty or ≈øixty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øtand in the ≈øhade, or was the ≈øhade on the other ≈øide of the way?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I did ≈øtand in the ≈øhade. A per≈øon came to Capt. Pre≈øton and ≈øaid they were killing the Sentinel; Capt. Pre≈øton ≈øaid damn you why do you not turn out; he ≈øpoke roughly to
them, then ≈øome ≈øoldiers came out, and he and they went down to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who it was came up to Capt. Pre≈øton?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you expect they would carry off the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not know what would be the con≈øequence, I thought if he came off with his life he would do very well.

On the 5th of March there were four of us in a hou≈øe together, I heard that there was fire; I went to Dock ≈øquare, when I came there I heard ≈øome in the crowd ≈øay, that the towns people had been fighting with the ≈øoldiers, and then they huzzaed for King-≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there in Dock-≈øquare at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Between fifty and ≈øixty. I went up Royal exchange-lane and came to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you go alone?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, ≈øeveral went up be≈øide me, they went up as thick as they could, and ≈øome went up the next lane, and ≈øome went up Cornhill. As I ≈øtood by the Sentinel, there was a barber's boy came up and pointed to the Sentinel, and ≈øaid there is the ≈øon of a bitch that knocked me down; on his ≈øaving this, the people immediately cried out kill him, kill him, knock him down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of people was there then?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I believe there were as many as in this Court, ≈øome boys, ≈øome men; the Sentinel went up the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe ≈øteps and knocked at the door with the butt of his gun, but could not get in; then he primed and loaded, and levelled it with his hip, and de≈øired the people to ≈øtand off, and then called to the Main-Guard to come down to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he call loud?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, pretty loud.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the expre≈ø≈øion he u≈øed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Turn out Main-Guard.‚ÄîThen Capt. Pre≈øton and nine or ten ≈øoldiers came down, and ranged them≈øelves before the Sentry-box.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Had the≈øe people that ≈øtood round the Sentinel clo ‚Ä¢ or ≈øticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw no clubs, ≈øome had ≈øticks, ≈øuch as people generally walk with.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear the people hollow or ≈øhout?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They whi≈øtled with their fingers and huzzaed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you meet ≈øome boys that evening, who ≈øaid they had drove ≈øome ≈øoldiers to their barracks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In Dock ≈øquare ≈øome people ≈øaid ≈øo, and huzzaed for King-≈øtreet. I went up there, and ≈øaw a barber's boy, who ≈øaid this is the ≈øon of a bitch that knocked me down; the people crowded in upon the Sentinel, and he drew back to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe ≈øteps.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at the Sentinel.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he knocked at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe door with the butt end of his gun, as I thought to get in, and then I ≈øaw him prime and load his piece, and level it with his hip.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were they pre≈ø≈øing on him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes they were, they ≈øaid fire, damn you fire, you dare not fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About fifty or ≈øixty young men and boys.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How old were the≈øe young men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About twenty or twenty two.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What do you call boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Such as my≈øelf, about eighteen.

I was at the Market and went up Royal-exchange lane, I ≈øaw no ≈øoldier but one, and he was the Sentinel, he got on the ≈øteps and loaded, by and by I ≈øaw a party come down from the Main-guard, and all that ≈øtood round cried fire! fire!‚Äî by and by they did fire, as ≈øoon as I ≈øaw a man drop, I went away.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ice thrown at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw ≈ønow balls, but no ice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing ≈øtrike upon their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear their guns rattle?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw ≈ønow balls thrown both at the Sentinel and at the party.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any clubs thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of people were there about the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Near two hundred boys and men.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe door opened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I minded, they hollowed fire! fire! you dogs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was any con≈øiderable number of ≈ønow balls thrown at the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: A dozen before the party came down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And when they came down, did they throw?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, as fa≈øt as ever.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any huzzaing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not in particular.

On the 5th March I was in King-≈øtreet at the Main-Guard, I ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers going down to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, I ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers very much mole≈øted by the people of the town throwing ≈ønow balls, ≈øticks, and more rubbi≈øh than I can mention, I ≈øaw al≈øo the Sentinel mole≈øted at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe door; when the party came down, he fell in among≈øt the re≈øt of the ≈øoldiers; I ≈øaw a ≈øoldier knocked down, but who he was I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Betwixt the ≈øoldiers and the Sentry-box.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who knocked the ≈øoldier down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I do not, I am not certain whether it was a ≈øtick that ≈øtruck him down, or a brick bat.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did his firelock fly out of his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, the firelock flew out of his hand, and he took it up again and fired, and I think he was the fir≈øt that fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Which way did the ≈øtick or bick batt come that knocked him down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It came as if thrown from towards the Town-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did the people ≈øtand to the ≈øoldiers, when the fir≈øt gun was fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The mighe≈øt might be about ten or a dozen yards from the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you ≈øtood there, did you ≈øee any one ≈øtrike at any ≈øoldier with a ≈øtick in his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the pri≈øoners there that night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw Hartegan, I was acquainted with him in Halifax, and I kept my eye upon him more than upon any of the re≈øt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Whereabout did he ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I came up the Royal-exchange-lane, and he was then the neare≈øt man to me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns did you hear fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe about ≈øeven.

On the evening of the 5th March I was in Milk-≈øtreet, I heard the bells ring, and ran down to the Town-hou≈øe, I ≈øaw diver≈øe of the inhabitants there, I enquired the rea≈øon of the bells ringing? A young man told me, a ra≈øcally ≈øoldier had ≈øtruck one of the inhabitants with a cutla≈øs, I replied, where is the damned villain gone? He gave me no an≈øwer, pre≈øently they turned round and gave two or three cheers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About thirty or forty: They went to the alley leading to Murray's barracks, ≈øome were for going down the alley, ≈øome were not, I ≈øtaid at the head of the alley, pre≈øently they went to the bottom of Royal-exchange-lane, and huzzaed and went up the lane, I my≈øelf went up the main-≈øtreet, the bell at this time had ≈øtopped; as I got to the Town hou≈øe, they had all got into King-≈øtreet, I went down to ≈øee what they would do, there were ≈øeveral gentlemen per≈øuading them to go off, and I believe they would all have gone in a few minutes, had not the ≈øoldiers come.‚Äî I ≈øaw them throwing oy≈øter ≈øhells and ≈ønow balls at the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe door, he was on the ≈øteps.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you ≈øure you ≈øaw them throw oy≈øter-≈øhells at him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: One or two, or a number?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think two or three.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they hit him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do not think they did. Some were hollowing out, let us burn the Sentry-box, let us heave it over-board, but they did neither; I ≈øtood then oppo≈øite the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe door, pre≈øently I ≈øaw a party of ≈øoldiers come down, who placed them≈øelves before the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Before the party came down, did you hear any per≈øon ≈øay, kill him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No. I ob≈øerved Capt. Pre≈øton ≈øtanding by the Sentry-box, I ≈øaw him talking with a man, I do not know who he was, I went to hear what they ≈øaid, but I could not; in the ≈øpace of two or three minutes, I heard a ≈øtick, club, or
≈øomething el≈øe ≈øtrike a ≈øoldier's gun, immediately the gun went off, and then I run.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing rattle on the pavements?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I heard a bayonet, or ≈øomething like it, rattle on the pavements.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many people were there, when the ≈øoldiers came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I believe ≈øixty or ≈øeventy.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where did you ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øtood at the head of Royal-exchange-lane, about three yards and a half from the Sentry box.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you ≈øee all the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No: ju≈øt before they fired, I heard the people ≈øay, Damn you fire, you bloody backs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear the expre≈ø≈øions, Ru≈øh on, knock them over, knock them over?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long was you there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About ≈øeven or eight minutes.

As I went home that evening, I met a number of boys with clubs, they went ≈øo for ≈øeveral months before, they chu≈øed to do ≈øo, becau≈øe they had been ≈øo often knocked down by the ≈øoldiers, ≈øome ≈øaid the ≈øoldiers were going to fight with the people.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number did you meet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were in two's or three's, three's or four's in a bunch, in the whole there might be about twenty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What time of night was that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About eight o'clock.

When the bells rung I was at my own hou≈øe, I run to the door and heard the cry of fire, I put on my ≈øhoes, and went our, and met two or three men, a≈øked them where the fire was; they ≈øaid it was ≈øomething better than fire. I met ≈øome with clubs, ≈øome with buckets and bags, and ≈øome running before me with ≈øticks in their hands; I went to the Town-hou≈øe, looked down the ≈øtreet, and ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers come out with their guns and bayonets fixed: I ≈øaw Capt. Pre≈øton with them; there were a number of people by the we≈øt door of the Town-hou≈øe, they ≈øaid lets go and attack the Main-Guard, ≈øome ≈øaid for God's ≈øake do not meddle
with them; they ≈øaid by God we will go, others again ≈øaid do not go. After a while they huzzaed and went down King-≈øtreet; there was a number of people came down Pri≈øon-lane, and ≈øome from the Po≈øt office; they went down to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, and I went down. The ≈øoldiers were all placed round in a circle with their guns brea≈øt high. I ≈øtood on the right wing, when the Captain came the people crouded in to him to ≈øpeak to him, and I went behind them, I went next to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe door, there were people all round the ≈øoldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near were the people to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About three or four feet from the point of their bayonets, the thicke≈øt part was by Capt. Pre≈øton. When I got to the corner I ≈øaw people with ≈øticks ≈øtriking on their guns at the right wing. I apprehended danger and that the guns might go off accidentally. I went to get to the upper end towards the Town hou≈øe, I had not got to the center of the party, before the guns went off; as they went off I run, and did not ≈øtop till I got to the upper end of the Town-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many did you ≈øee ≈øtrike upon their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell how many of them did it.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear at that time they were ≈øtriking, the cry of fire, fire?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they ≈øaid fire, fire damn you fire, fire you lob≈øters, fire, you dare not fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any thing thrown at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nothing but ≈ønow balls, flung by ≈øome young≈øters.

Ju≈øt after the bell rung nine, hearing the bell ring again, I went out thinking it was fire; I ≈øaw numbers of people running from the South-end ≈øome had buckets, the principal number had clubs in their hands. I a≈øked where is the fire, I received for an≈øwer, at the Rope-walks and in King-≈øtreet. Numbers were coming with buckets, and the re≈øt ≈øaid Damn your bloods do not bring buckets, bring clubs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was this before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

On the evening of the 5th of March I was at home, I heard the bells ring, and went to the gate; I ≈øtaid there a little and ≈øaw Mr. Lovell coming back with his buckets, I a≈øked
him where was the fire, he ≈øaid it was not fire; after that I went into the ≈øtreet, and ≈øaw one of my acquaintances and we run down to the end of the lane and ≈øaw another acquaintance coming up, holding his arm; I a≈øked him what's the matter, he ≈øaid the ≈øoldiers were fighting, had got cut la≈ø≈øes, and were killing every body, and that one of them had ≈øtruck him on the arm, and almo≈øt cut it off; he told me I had be≈øt not go down; I ≈øaid a good club was better than a cutla≈øs, and he had better go down and ≈øee if he could not cut ≈øome too. I went to the Town-hou≈øe, ≈øaw the Sentinels placed at the Main-Guard ≈øtanding by Mr. Bowes's corner; numbers of boys on the other ≈øide of the way were throwing ≈ønow balls at them; the Sentinels were enraged and ≈øwearing at the boys; the boys called them lob≈øters, bloody backs, and hallowed who buys lob≈øters; one of my acquaintance came and told me that the ≈øoldiers had been fighting, and the people had drove them to Murray's barracks; I ≈øaw a number of people coming from Murray's barracks who went down by Jack≈øon's corner into King-≈øtreet; pre≈øently I heard three cheers given in King-≈øtreet, I ≈øaid we had better go down and ≈øee what's the matter; we went down to the Whipping-po≈øt and ≈øtood by Waldo's ≈øhop, I ≈øaw a number of people round the Sentinel at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, there were al≈øo a number of people who ≈øtood where I did, and were picking up pieces of ≈øea coal that had been thrown out thereabout, and ≈ønow balls, and throwing them over at the Sentinel. While I was ≈øtanding there, there were two or three boys run-out from among the people, and cried we have got his gun away; and now we will have him; pre≈øently I heard three cheers given by the people at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe; I ≈øaid to my acquaintance I would run up and ≈øee whether the guard would turn out. I pa≈ø≈øed round the Guard hou≈øe, and went as far as the we≈øt door of the Town-hou≈øe. While I ≈øtood there one of my acquaintance ≈øaid he would go round the corner of the Town-hou≈øe, and ≈øee if the guard had turned out; he went to the corner and called me, and told me the guard was come out. I went and looked down the ≈øtreet, I ≈øaw a file of men, with an officer with a laced hat on before them; upon that we all went to go towards him, and when we had got about half way to them, the officer ≈øaid ≈øomething to them, and they filed off down the ≈øtreet: upon that I went in the ≈øhade towards the Guard-hou≈øe, and followed them down as far as Mr. Peck's corner; I ≈øaw them
pa≈øs through the croud, and plant them≈øelves by the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe. As ≈øoon as they got there the people gave three cheers. I went to cro≈øs over to where the ≈øoldiers were, and as ≈øoon as I got a glimp≈øe of them, I heard ≈øomebody huzza and ≈øay here is Old-Murray with the riot-act, and they began to pelt ≈øhow balls; a man ≈øet out and run, and I followed him as far as Philips's corner, and I do not know where he went. I turned back and went through the people until I got to the head of Royal-exchange-lane, right again≈øt the ≈øoldiers; the fir≈øt word I heard was a Grenadier ≈øay to a man by me, Damn you ≈øtand back.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How near was he to him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was ≈øo near that the Grenadler might have run him through if he had ≈øtept one ≈øtep forward. While I ≈øtopt to look at him, a per≈øon came to get through betwixt the Grenadier and me, and the ≈øoldier had like to have pricked him; he turned about and ≈øaid, You damn'd lob≈øter, bloody back, are you going to ≈øtab me, the ≈øoldier ≈øaid by God will I; pre≈øently ≈øomebody took hold of me by the ≈øhoulder, and told me to go home; or I ≈øhould be hurt; at the ≈øame time there were a number of people towards the Town-hou≈øe, who ≈øaid, come away and let the guard alone, you have nothing at all to do with them. I turned about and ≈øaw the officer ≈øtanding before the men, and one or two per≈øons engaged in talk with him. A number were jumping on the backs of tho≈øe that were talking with the officer, to get as near as they could.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear what they ≈øaid?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. Upon this I went to, go as clo≈øe to the officer as I could; one of the per≈øons who was talking with the officer turned about quick to the people, and ≈øaid, Damn him he is going to fire; upon that they gave a ≈øhout, and cryed out Fire and be damn'd, who ca ‚Ä¢ es, damn you, you dare not fire, and began to throw ≈ønow balls, and other things, which then flew pretty thick.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they hit any of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes, I ≈øaw two or three of them hit, one ≈øtruck a Grenadier on the hat, and the people who were right before them had ≈øticks; and as the ≈øoldiers were pu≈øhing with their guns back and forth, they ≈øtruck their guns, and one hit a Grenadier on the fingers. At this time, the people up at the Town-hou≈øe called again come away, come way; a ≈øtout man who ≈øtood near me, and right before the Grenadiers,
as they pu≈øhed with their bayonets the length of their arms, kept ≈øtriking on their guns. The people ≈øeemed to be leaving the ≈øoldiers, and to turn from them, when there came down a number from Jack≈øon's corner, huzzaing and crying, Damn them they dare not fire, we are not afraid of them; one of the≈øe people, a ≈øtout man with a long cord wood ≈øtick, threw him≈øelf in, and made a blow at the officer; I ≈øaw the officer try to ≈øend off the ≈øtroke, whether he ≈øtruck him or not I do not know: the ≈øtout man then turned round, and ≈øtruck the Grenadier's gun at the Captain's right hand, and immediately fell in with his club, and knocked his gun away, and ≈øtruck him over the head, the blow came either on the ≈øoldiers cheek or hat. This ≈øtout man held the bayonet with his left hand, and twitched it and cried kill the dogs, knock them over; this was the general cry; the people then crouded in, and upon that the Grenadier gave a twitch back and relieved his gun, and he up with it and began to pay away on the people. I was then betwixt the officer and this grenadier, I turned to go off, when I had got away about the length of a gun, I turned to look towards the officer; and I heard the word fire; at the word fire I thought I heard the report of a gun, and upon my hearing the report, I ≈øaw the ≈øame grenadier ≈øwing his gun, and immediately he di≈øcharged it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who this ≈øtout man was, that fell in and ≈øtruck the grenadier?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thought, and ≈øtill think, it was the Molatto who was ≈øhot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the grenadier who was thus a≈ø≈øaulted and fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I then thought it was Killroy, and I told Mr. Quincy ≈øo the next morning after the affair happened, I now think it was he from my be≈øt ob≈øervation, but I can't po≈øitively ≈øwear it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ≈øoldiers of that party, or any of them, ≈øtep or move out of the rank in which they ≈øtood to pu≈øh the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, and if they had they might have killed me and many others with their bayonets.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you, as you pa≈ø≈øed through the people towards Royal-exchange-lane and the party, ≈øee a number of people take up any and every thing they could find in the ≈øtreet, and throw them at the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I ≈øaw ten or fifteen round me do it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you your≈øelf pick up every thing you could find, and throw at them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: After the gun fired, where did you go?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I run as fa≈øt as I could into the fir≈øt door I ≈øaw open, which I think was Mr. Dehones, I was very much frightened.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is the witne≈øs la≈øt examined your ≈øervant?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes¬∑

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long has he lived in your family?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Above ten years.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is his general character for truth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is good, I have heard his te≈øtimony and believe it to be true, he gave the ≈øame relation of this matter to me on the ≈øame evening, in a quarter of an hour after the affair happened; and I then a≈øked him whether our people were to blame, he ≈øaid they were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can Andrew read and write?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, very well, he has been well educated.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Pray Sir, is it not u≈øual for Andrew to amplify and embelli≈øh a ≈øtory?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He is fellow of a lively imagination, and will ≈øometimes amu≈øe the ≈øervants in the kitchen, but I never knew him tell a ≈øerious lye.
sp.stage: FIVE o'Clock, P. M. the Court adjourned till next morning, Saturday, nine o'Clock.
Saturday, NINE o'Clock, the Court met according to adjournment, and proceeded.
sp.p:
I was in King-≈øtreet a quarter after nine o'clock on the 5th of March, and two others with me, I cro≈ø≈øed King-≈øtreet at Oliver's-Dock, and I met a few people, but did not mind them, and the people with me did not; in a little time I heard the bells ring, and I made a ≈øtop and a≈øked what was the matter? They ≈øaid fire, I ≈øaw ≈øeveral people with buckets, &c. and I a≈øked them where they were going? They ≈øaid there is fire ≈øomewhere. I came up by Pudding-lane, and went in betwixt the guard and Guard hou≈øe, for at this time the Main-Guard was turned out, I ≈øaw Mr. Ba≈ø≈øet the officer, and Capt. Pre≈øton, while I was ≈øtanding there, ≈øome per≈øon in the croud fronting the ≈øoldiers, cried out to the
guard, will you ≈øtand there and ≈øee the Sentinel murdered at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe? Capt. Pre≈øton and Mr. Ba≈ø≈øet were both together, Mr. Ba≈ø≈øet ≈øaid to Capt. Pre≈øton, what ≈øhall I do in this ca≈øe? Said Pre≈øton, take out ≈øix or ≈øeven of the men, and let them go down to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Sentry; I think there were ≈øix men ordered out of the ra ‚Ä¢ ks, they formed them≈øelves by files, the Corporal marched in the front, and the Captain in the rear, I was at this time on the out≈øide of the ≈øoldiers on the left hand, and I kept on the out≈øide from the time they marched from the parade till they came to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, but how they formed them≈øelves when they came there I did not ≈øee, but when I ≈øaw them they were formed in a half circle, I was about two or three yards di≈øtance from them, I heard Capt. Pre≈øton u≈øe many intreaties to the populace, begging they would di≈øper≈øe and go home, but what they ≈øaid I cannot tell; but I heard them hollow, damn you fire! You dare not fire, we know you dare not fire: Capt. Pre≈øton de≈øired them to go home many times; I departed and ≈øaw no more of them, and went to Wheelwright's wharf.

On the evening of the 5th March I heard the bells ring, I was in Mr. Hall's hou≈øe, I went out in order to ≈øee where the fire was, I heard the drum beat, I went to the ≈øhop and got a ≈øtick, and went down to the Conduit, I ≈øaw thirty or forty people with ≈øticks in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Were they walking ≈øticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some were ≈øhort clubs, ≈øome were walking ≈øticks.‚Äî Then they hollowed, King-≈øtreet forever, and huzzaed, ≈øome went up Royal-exchange lane, I went with a number up Jenkin's-alley, I went towards the Sentinel, he was walking backwards and forwards with his firelock on his ≈øhoulder; ≈øome of the people ≈øaid, kill him; I had not been there long, before the party came down, and then a good many more people gathered round before the Sentinel-box, ≈øome from Quaker-lane, ≈øome from the Town-hou≈øe, and ≈øome from the bottom of King-≈øtreet, ≈øome with ≈øticks, ≈øome without, they came clo≈øe to the Sentinel, the bells were ringing, I had not been there long before they loaded, I was clo≈øe to them when they loaded.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Who gave orders to load?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I did not hear, there was ≈øuch huzzaing, hollowing
and whi≈øtling, that I could not hear, they had their bayonets about brea≈øt high, ≈øhoving and pricking with their bayonets to make the way clear, then the people hollowed fire! why do you not fire? Damn you fire! you bloody backs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they tell the people to keep off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did the people go back when de≈øired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, they pre≈ø≈øed more upon them, while the people were thus pre≈ø≈øing on the party, they fired, I did not hear any orders given.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did you ≈øtand to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I fell back to the middle of the ≈øtreet when the fir≈øt gun was fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: To which wing did you fall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the center, I was right facing th√®m.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think ≈øix or ≈øeven, I did not count them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the people come clo≈øe up to the ≈øoldiers, and ≈øtrike on their guns?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, they held their ≈øticks up over their heads, flouri≈øhing and brandi≈øhing them, ≈øaying, damn you fire? you dare not fire.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ≈øticks thrown?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, nor any thing el≈øe, Samuel Gray who was ≈øhot that night, clapped me on the ≈øhoulder, and ≈øaid, do not run my lad, they dare not fire, and he ran back and forth among the people and clapped others al≈øo on the back as he did me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had he any thing in his hand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think he had not; I looked to my left ≈øoon after the guns were fired, and ≈øaw him upon the ground, and with the help of ≈øome others, carried him to Dr. Loring's ≈øhop, but could not get in, and left him there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Langford in this town?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any body go up to Gray, and thru≈øt at him with a bayonet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No I did not ≈øee it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did he fall to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was in the middle of the ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of the ≈øoldiers move out of the ranks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near was you to Gray?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About three or four yards di≈øtance.

That evening upon returning home, I ≈øaw a number of people round the Sentinel, making u≈øe of opprobious language and threatnings, I de≈øired them to go off, and ≈øaid the con≈øequence would be fatal if they did not; ≈øome few ≈ønow balls were thrown, and abu≈øive language continued, they ≈øaid damn him, let him fire, he can fire but one gun.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were they men or boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were a mixture, about eighteen or nineteen years old, and ≈øome men.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many were there of them?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There might be from ≈øeventy to an hundred, I did not particularly ob≈øerve; when I could not prevail to take them off, I went to Mr, Pain's, in a little while the party came down, I ≈øaw nothing afterwards; ≈øoon after I heard the guns fired, and Mr. Pain was wounded with one of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the Sentinel call out for the guard?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not hear him, he retreated to the ≈øteps of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you ≈øtanding at Mr. Pain's door when the guns were fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was, but was not looking that way, nor did I ob≈øerve when the party came down; I told the people, the Sentinel was on duty, that was his po≈øt, and that he had a right to walk there, and that he could have enough to relieve him, if he ≈øtood in need of it, as he was ≈øo near the Main Guard,

I know nothing worth the telling; I was not in King≈øtreet, I heard there was no fire, but I heard the ≈øoldiers were fighting. I went to Dock ≈øquare, and ≈øaw a number of people there, I came up Royal-exchange-lane, and ≈øaw the firing, but was not near enough to ≈øee any thing the people did.

That evening I was at home, and heard the bells ring, I went into the ≈øtreet and a≈øked the occa≈øion, I was told it was not fire, but the ≈øoldiers fighting with the inhabitant; I went into the hou≈øe and could find no ≈øtick, but I cut the handle of my mother's broom off, with this I came to King≈øtreet, but there were no ≈øoldiers; ≈øome people were coming
from Royal-exchange-lane, ≈øome from the Town-hou≈øe, ≈øome ≈øaid, damn it, they are only making fools of us, it is be≈øt to go home: I went to the head of Royal exchange lane, and ≈øaw a clu≈øter of people there, and I ≈øaw a boy who ≈øaid that the Sentry had knocked him down with the but-end of his gun; I ≈øaw the Sentry on the ≈øteps, and the people after he loaded, ≈øaid, fire! Damn you fire! Pre≈øently after the party came down, I ≈øtood clo≈øe to them, they were ≈øwinging their bayonets, telling the people to make way, I ≈øaw a man talking with Capt. Pre≈øton, I went to hear what he ≈øaid, I could not hear, the grenadier on the right was ≈øtruck ≈øome where on his right ≈øide, but I do not know with what, but directly he fired.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was that the right hand man? A. Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was you clo≈øe to the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I was quite clo≈øe to them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any ≈ønow balls thrown before this?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think I ≈øaw two or three.

Betwixt eight and nine o'clock of the 5th March, I was in my own hou≈øe near Murray's barracks, the people were running backwards and forwards, and there was a great mob and riot by the barrack gate; I heard the people as they went along declare, if the ≈øoldiers did not come out and fight them, they would ≈øet fire to the four corners of the barracks, and burn every damned ≈øoul of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was ≈øtanding at my own door, I ≈øaw them pa≈øs and repa≈øs me, but I knew none of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any di≈øturbance before that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there was a di≈øturbance half an hour before that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of a di≈øturbance was it before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw a good number of towns people had cutla≈ø≈øes, clubs, and ≈øwords, there was knocking down, riot and di≈øturbance, and this declaration of theirs was after that, and before the bells rung.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was that ≈øaid by one, two, or a number?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I cannot tell indeed how many ≈øaid ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you at that time keep a victualling-hou≈øe!

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ≈øoldiers frequent your hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they did.

On the evening of the 5th March, I was at Mr. Coleman's at the north ≈øide of the Market, I came from thence through the Market on the ≈øouth ≈øide, I ≈øaw ≈øeven or eight people, the chief were boys, three or four of them were on the in≈øide the rails, pulling the butchers ≈øtalls to pieces.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How old did the≈øe boys appear?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About a dozen of years old, or ≈ømaller, ≈øome about eighteen, I went up to them and ob≈øerved they were geting ≈øticks; about half a minute after, came along a ≈øoldier, I took him to be an officer's ≈øervant, ≈øome ≈øaid here is a damned ≈øoldier, and got ≈øoul of the man, and I got the ≈øoldier away from them, and he went off, and I went towards home round by the Golden-ball, and up into King-≈øtreet; I met one Mr. James Bayard he and I walked together, and I did not ≈øee a ≈øingle ≈øoul in the ≈øtreet; we pa≈ø≈øed the Sentinel (I think that was he pointing to White) it was cold under foot, and we ≈øtood upon Stone's ≈øteps; in a few minutes there were three or four boys round the Sentinel, they got ≈øoul of him; one of them ≈øaid the Sentinel had ≈øtruck him with his gun, and they kept pu≈øhing one another again≈øt him, and pu≈øhed him into the box; I ≈øaid to Mr. Bayard there will be trouble by and bye. About two minutes after there came a parcel of boys and young fellows together, in number about fifteen or ≈øixteen, the chief of them with ≈øticks in their hands.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øort of ≈øticks were they?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They looked like the ≈øticks they took at the Market, like pieces of the ≈øtalls ≈øplit. When they got the head of the lane, there was a little talking and whi≈øtling among≈øt them, and they ≈øaid lets go up to the Main guard, and they went up by the foot of the Town-Hou≈øe; about one minute after there were five or ≈øix boys made their appearance out of Royal-exchange-lane, from that I went to go up round Jack≈øon's corner, when I came to the watch-hou≈øe, I met a number of people coming round by Jack≈øon's corner.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Twenty or thirty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had they ≈øticks?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some had ≈øticks, ≈øome had none, ≈øome had ≈øhort ≈øticks ≈øome had walking canes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øized people were the≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
They were a mixture of men and boys running together;
I a≈øked them what had been the matter, they ≈øaid there had been a ≈øquabble by Murray's barracks, and they had drove the ≈øoldiers in; they ≈øaid it was all over; then I left Mr. Bayard and they all came down into King-≈øtreet, and betwixt Quaker-lane and Royal-exchange-lane they made a ≈øtop, and met in a elu≈øter, and not long afterwards di≈øper≈øed; I did not leave above twelve or fifteen in King-≈øtreet, when I came out of it. I went down Quaker-lane, and a number that lived that way went down with me; as I got home and li≈øted the latch of the door I heard ≈øome bell ring, and I heard a gun and then another, I heard them all fired, I came back as far as the bottom of the lane and no further.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What ≈øaid the boy ‚Ä¢ in the Market to the ≈øoldier who pa≈ø≈øed by?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They ≈øaid here is a damned ≈øoldier, ≈øome ≈øaid they are all a like, this is as bad as any of them. I believe they would have bent him if I had not re≈øcued him; he was pa≈ø≈øing quietly along.

On the evening of the 5th of March, I pa≈ø≈øed my time at the Bunch of Grapes in King-≈øtreet, in company with three gentlemen of the town; betwixt the hours of nine and ten we were alarmed with the bells, and a cry of fire, they ≈øaid to me come Gridley we had better go and enquire where the fire is, I ≈øaid I had rather ≈øit where I was, there might be ≈øome di≈øturbance, and I did not want to be in it; however, I agreed, and we went. I ≈øaw Mr. Davis particularly, he ≈øaid to me what do you make of this, I told him I believed there was no fire, but rather a tumult. I ≈øaid to Mr. Davis I will go up the ≈øtreet and ≈øee what the matter is, and return again and let him and the re≈øt that were on the ≈øteps of the door know what the matter was. I went up the ≈øtreet into the middle of it, and I ≈øtopt ju≈øt before the Sentinel placed at the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe, there were a large number of boys, and ≈øome men among≈øt them, about ten young men, the boys were in the front, and the men in the rear; I believe about twenty five, boys men and all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How big were the≈øe boys?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Little tri≈øling boys. The Sentinel had his gun and bayonet charged, levelled with his hip. I went from thence
up to the ≈øouth end of the Town-hou≈øe oppo≈øite to the Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was the Sentinel at that time in the box or on the ≈øteps?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was retreating towards the ≈øteps with his bayonet charged. I then found the Main-guard to be in confu≈øion. I went up to the head of the Town-hou≈øe, where were a number of gentlemen collected together, I a≈øked them what was the matter, they told me that the ≈øoldiers had ru≈øhed from Murray's barracks, and had cut ≈øeveral of the inhabitants with their cutla≈ø≈øes; ≈øeveral people were running about the ≈øtreets, and the cry was God damn the ra≈øcals. Some ≈øaid this will never do, the readie≈øt way to get rid of the≈øe people is to attack the Main guard, Strike at the root, there is the ne≈øt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was this particularly ≈øpoken by one or two only?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was general, they joined in with one another as they met. I went to the north-≈øide of the Town-hou≈øe, with a view to return to the place from whence I came: I ≈øtopt at Mr. Kent's door, and while I was ≈øtanding there, aparty of the guard came down from the Main guard a cro≈øs King-≈øtreet. I turned round and ≈øaw a non commi≈ø≈øioned officer (as I took him to be by his appearance) leading the party, which I at fir≈øt thought was to relieve the Sentinel at the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe as u≈øual, but perceiving this guard was going down to ≈øupport the Sentinel, I thought it time to go where I came from, to tell the gentlemen what I had ≈øeen according to promi≈øe. I proceeded down ≈øtreet on the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe ≈øide, on the flat ≈øtones; the ≈øoldiers were drawn up in two ranks front and rear, as I thought it, they had not had time to form as I came down; I walked betwixt the two ranks, they were then loading their pieces.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Did you hear any orders given for loading?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
No. Pa≈ø≈øing betwixt the ranks, their guns being on a loading po≈øition, I pa≈ø≈øed lei≈øurly through, and they put their guns and bayonets up to let me go through. I returned to the Bunch of Grapes from whence I came, I ≈øaw Mr. Davis and the other gentlemen on the ≈øteps, Mr. Davis a≈øked me to give an account of this matter, I told him „Äà‚óä„Äâ could give no account, except a general one, that the ≈øoldiers had come out of their barracks, and that they had been a quarreling, and the Sentinel had been inturrup ‚Ä¢ in his duty. Mr. Davis a≈øked me what was that collection
of people „Äà‚óä„Äâ fore the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe, who did they con≈øi≈øt of; they are nothing ≈øaid he, but a parcel of boys; I ha≈øtily replied, yes, Mother Tapley's boys.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did you mean by that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I meant boys as big as I am.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you pa≈ø≈øed betwixt the ≈øoldiers, was any thing thrown at them; or did any body ≈øtrike them.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not that I ≈øaw. When I was at the Bunch of Grapes, I ≈øaw ≈øome ≈ønow balls thrown, ≈øome from the rear, ≈øome from the middle of the ≈øtreet, and ≈øome from Quakerlane, all thrown towards the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any noi≈øe ju≈øt before the ≈øtring?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As I ≈øtood on the ≈øteps of the Bunch of Grapes tavern, the general noi≈øe and cry was why do you not fire, damn you, you dare not fire, fire and be damned. The≈øe words were ≈øpoke very loud, they might be heard to the Long wharff. The noi≈øe was very great indeed. There was about fifty before the ≈øoldiers, and about half the number before the Sentinel, before the party joined him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know Patrick Car, who was killed by the firing in King ≈øtreet on the 5th of March la≈øt? A. Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he in your hou≈øe that evening? A Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing he ≈øaid, when he was told there was an affray with the ≈øoldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the bells rung, he went up ≈øtairs and put his ≈øurtout on, and got a hanger and put it betwixt his coat and ≈øureout; my hu≈øband coming at that time, gave him a pu≈øh and felt the ≈øword; he wanted to take it from him, but he was unwilling to let it go, my hu≈øband told him he ≈øhould not take it with him. I do not know what he ≈øaid, but one of the neighbours was in the hou≈øe and coaxed the ≈øword out of his hand, and he went out without it. He Said on his death bed, he ≈øaw a parcel of boys and negroes throwing ≈ønow balls at the guard. He thought the fir≈øt or ≈øecond man from the Sentinel box was the man that ≈øhot him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Patrick Carr?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes. On the night of the 5th of March, when the bells rung he would go out; I per≈øuaded him much to ≈øtay
at home, he did not mind me but took his ≈øword betwixt his coat and ≈øurtout. Mr. Field coming in felt it, and ≈øaid he ≈øhould not take it out with him; with much coaxing a woman who lived next door got it from him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear any acknowlegement by him on his death bed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was often at his bed ≈øide, and all that I ever heard him ≈øay, was, he thought he knew the man that ≈øhot him, but he never made it known to me.

sp.speaker: Q,
sp.p: Was you Patrick Carr's ≈øurgeon?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I was, in company with others. I was called that evening about eleven o'clock to him, I was engaged with Mr. Paine and could not go; next morning I went; after dre≈ø≈øing his wounds, I advi≈øed him never to go again into quarrels and riots; He ≈øaid he was very ≈øorry he did go.‚Äî Dr. Lloyd who was pre≈øent, turned round to me and ≈øaid, Jeffries, I believe this man will be able to tell us how the affair was, we had better a≈øk him: I a≈øked him then how long he had been in King-≈øtreet when they fired? He ≈øaid he went from Mr. Field's when the bells rung, when he got to Walker's corner, he ≈øaw many per≈øons coming from Cornhill, who he was told had been quarreling with the ≈øoldiers down there, that he went with them as far as the ≈øtocks, that he ≈øtopped there, but they pa≈ø≈øed on: While he was ≈øtanding there he ≈øaw many things thrown at the Sentry. I a≈øked him if he knew what was thrown?
