He ≈øaid he heard the things ≈øtrike again≈øt the guns, and they ≈øounded hard, he believed they were oy≈øter ≈øhells and ice; he heard the people huzza every time they heard any thing ≈øtrike that ≈øounded hard: that he then ≈øaw ≈øome ≈øoldiers going down towards the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, that he ≈øaw the people pelt them as they went along, after they had got down there, the cro≈øed over towards Warden and Vernon's ≈øhop, in order to ≈øet what they would do, that as he was pa≈ø≈øing he was ≈øhot,‚Äî that he was taken up and carried home to Mr. Field's by ≈øome of his friends. I a≈øked him whether he thought the ≈øoldiers would fire? He told me he thought the ≈øoldiers would have fired long before. I then a≈øked him whether he thought the ≈øoldiers were abu≈øed a great deal, after they went down there? He ≈øaid, he thought they were. I a≈øked him whether he thought the ≈øoldiers would have been
hurt, if they had not fired? He ≈øaid, he really thought they would, for he heard many voices cry out, kill them. I a≈øked him then, meaning to clo≈øe all, whether he thought they fired in ≈øelf defence, or on purpo≈øe to de≈øtroy the people? He ≈øaid, he really thought they did fire to defend them≈øelves; that he did not blame the man whoever he was, that ≈øhot him. This conver≈øation was on Wedne≈øday. He always gave the ≈øame an≈øwers to the ≈øame que≈øtions, every time I vi≈øited him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was he apprehen≈øive of his danger?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was told of it. He told me al≈øo, he was a native of Ireland, that he had frequently ≈øeen mobs, and ≈øoldiers called upon to quell them: whenever he mentioned that, he always called him≈øelf a fool, that he might have known better, that he had ≈øeen ≈øoldiers often fire on the people in Ireland, but had never ≈øeen them bear half ≈øo much before they fired in his life.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How often did he repeat this conver≈øation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Almo≈øt every day I ≈øaw him, though he was more particular, the day but one after he was ≈øhot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long did he live after he received his wound?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ten days.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When had you the la≈øt conver≈øation with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About four o'clock in the afternoon, preceeding the night on which he died, and he then particularly ≈øaid, he forgave the man whoever he was that ≈øhot him, he was ≈øatisfied he had no malice, but fired to defend him≈øelf.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you your≈øelf ≈øee any of the tran≈øactions at Murray's barracks on that evening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
On the evening of the 5th March, I was at my father's, oppo≈øite Mr. Cooper's meeting; about nine, one of the neighbours run in, (a woman) ≈øhe ≈øaid to my father, pray „Äà‚óä„Äâ come out, there will be murder, the ≈øoldiers and people are fighting: I went directly towards Murray's barracks, before I got to them I found the pa≈ø≈øage way ≈øtopped up ≈øo that I could not pa≈øs; by a number of people of all ≈øorts, I ≈øaw no ≈øoldiers ju≈øt at that minute; I got upon Dr. Hyron's ≈øteps, I ≈øaw ≈øeveral ≈øoldiers towards Mr. Greenleaf's, I think there were three, one of them had a pair of tongs in his hand, another had a ≈øtick I think, he was the ≈øecond, he that had the tongs was the fir≈øt, behind them were ≈øeveral officers driving the ≈øoldiers towards the barrack gate, ordering them to go in, I ≈øaw them ≈øtrike them, they turned
them into the gate, they then ≈øhut the barrack gate intirely, I think the officers did that them≈øelves; as they, were putting them in, there were a great many ≈ønow balls thrown at them, they were called cowards, cowardly ra≈øcals, and that they were afraid ‚Ä¢ ght.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What number of people do you think were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There were as many as could ≈øtand betwixt the ≈øteps and the ≈øide of the way; I took the alley to be as full as it could be, for others were pre≈ø≈øing to get into that ≈øtreet and could not; I judge not le≈øs than ≈øeventy or eighty could ‚Ä¢ ill that ≈øpace of ground: the office is told the people not a ≈øoldier ≈øhould come out, at that time I ≈øaw a gentleman ≈øpeak to ≈øome of the officers, who I then took to be Mr. Palmes, I a≈øked the per≈øon next me if he knew the names of either of the officers? He pointed to one, and ≈øaid that was Capt. Goldfinch; while the gentleman was talking with Capt. Goldfinch (it was ≈øome time, about ≈øeven or eight minutes I ≈øtood on the ≈øame ≈øpot) there was a great deal of abu≈øive language given to them, they were repeatedly called lob≈øters; they promi≈øed the gentleman who was ≈øpeaking to them, that if any body had been injured, enquiry ≈øhould be made next day, and the per≈øons ≈øhould be puni≈øhed, I heard this repeated four or five different times, they ≈øpoke al≈øo to the people in general; while they were talking I ≈øaw ≈ønowballs thrown at the officers, which ≈øtruck the door before which they ≈øtood; they begged the people would go away; they ≈øaid they would not; the officers ≈øaid, they had done all they could, they had turned the ≈øoldiers in and ≈øhut the gate, that no ≈øoldiers ≈øhould come out that evening; ≈øome body replied, you mean they dare not come out, you dare not let them out; many per≈øons cried let us go home, others ≈øaid no, we ≈øhall find ≈øome ≈øoldiers in King ≈øtreet, a number of them then pa≈ø≈øed up the alley; as they went up they hazzaed and made a noi≈øe again≈øt the fences and ≈øide of the walls; I then pa≈ø≈øed up the alley my≈øelf into Cornhill, as ≈øoon as I go ‚Ä¢ out of the alley I heard the Old-Brick bell ring.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear Dr Cooper's bell ring before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I think not, I heard it afterwards. There were many in the ≈øtreet running, ≈øome with buckets enquiring when the fire was? There were many an≈øwers given in the ≈øtreet it is not fire, it is the ≈øoldiers fighting, I do not know from who, but from ≈øeveral quarters behind and before me; I
went up Cornhill and ≈øaw a number of per≈øons collected betwixt Mr. Jack≈øon's ≈øhop and the Town-hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About twenty, I thought many of them were the per≈øons that had ju≈øt left the alley, I had followed them with my eye and ≈øaw them ≈øtop there, many of them had ≈øticks, they did not u≈øe them to walk with, as they went up they flouri≈øhed them about.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What number of ≈øticks did you ≈øee flouri≈øhing in that manner?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I thought about two-thirds of them had ≈øticks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there a general cry?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No, the chief was huzz ‚Ä¢ ng. As they went up ≈øeveral of them ≈øtruck again≈øt Jack≈øon's ≈øhop windows and ≈øaid, dam ‚Ä¢ it, bere lives an importer, o ‚Ä¢ here ran more towards the Town hou≈øe and took up pieces of ice and threw at Jack≈øon's windows and broke four pa ‚Ä¢ es of gla≈øs, I ≈øtood and counted them; at that time Mr. Caz ‚Ä¢ eau came up and ≈øaid, do not meddle with Mr. Jack≈øon, let him alone, do not break his windows, and they left of throwing; the bigger part of them immediately pu≈øhed down King-≈øtreet by the north ≈øide of the Town hou≈øe, others of them went betwixt the we≈øt door of the Town-hou≈øe and Cornhill, and ≈øaid, we will go to the guard; I then went over to the opening betwixt the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Town-hou≈øe and the Guard hou≈øe, to look down to ≈øee if they did ≈øtop there, at that time I heard a huzz; I thought lower down King-≈øtreet, it was not from any of the people I had then view, the≈øe per≈øons did not ≈øtop by the Guard hou≈øe, but run directly down King-≈øtreet; I then turned back, and returned by Cornhill through B ‚Ä¢ yl≈øton's-alley, I found a ≈ømall circle of people talking with the officers on the ≈øteps, about twelve; at that time Dr. Cooper's bell began to ring, one of the officers immediately cried out, pray ≈øtop that bell, I then left them and went to my father's.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any per≈øon ring the bell?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I ≈øaw no per≈øon, but I ≈øaw a window open.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Was any thing done to ≈øtop it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw nothing done, I had been but a little while in the hou≈øe, I had ju≈øt took off my cloak when the girl ran in from the kitchen, and ≈øaid there is a gun fired, I replied to the company, I did nor believe it, for I had ≈øeen the officers put in the ≈øoldiers and ≈øhut the gate.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: By whom is the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe placed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Sentinel at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe is placed by order of a commanding officer, the commanding officer was then Lieut. Col. Dalrymple, by his order a Sentry was placed at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe to take care of the money in the Ca≈øhier's office, books, &c. that is the duty of a Sentinel ≈øtationed at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Had a Sentry alternatly been placed there for ≈øome months before the 5th March?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, for many months before, ever ≈øince I came to the town, and the Sentinel there cannot ≈øtir till the commanding officer relieves him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee the fir≈øt order for placing the Sentinel at the commi≈ø≈øioners office when they kept at Concert-hall?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not, I was not then in the country.

div.stage: ‚ÅÇ Produced on the part of the Crown.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know any of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, White, Killroy, Wemms, and Carrol.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did White ≈øay any thing to you on the 5th of March la≈øt?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I went down King-≈øtreet ju≈øt after the bells began to ring, and he ≈øaid Hall, I am mole≈øted and impo≈øed on on my po≈øt, I cannot keep my po≈øt clear; Hall take care of your≈øelf, there will be ≈øomething done by and bye. I moved away to the corner of Stone's hou≈øe and there ≈øtood.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any number of people about the Sentinel at that time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there were about twenty, he ≈øaid he could not keep his po≈øt clear. They ≈øaid he dared not fire. He cocked his gun on the ≈øteps, then he pre≈øented his gun, and they drew off again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What did he ≈øay to the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He de≈øired them to keep off. Some were throwing ≈ønow balls, ≈øome oy≈øter ≈øhells at him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ≈øee any of them hit the Sentinel?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No; I ≈øaw them hit his gun two or three times; then he hollowed for the guard, and the guard came down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What expre≈ø≈øion did he u≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He hollowed ≈øoldiers come here, and they came ≈øeven men and the officer.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What followed upon that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As ≈øoon as they c ‚Ä¢ me down the people pre≈ø≈øed in upon them; and they pu≈øhed with their bayonets to keep them off, but did not move out of their ranks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any ≈ønow balls, ≈øticks, or ≈øtones, thrown at the party after they came down?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the ≈øoldiers tell them to keep off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes; but they ≈øtill pre≈ø≈øed on. Then one man fired, and ‚Ä¢ run down Royal exchange lane as fa≈øt as I could.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How near did you ≈øtand to the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: About twelve or fourteen feet off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there people between you and the party?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ten or twelve.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the general cry?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Fire, fire, you dare not fire, fire and be damned.

Betwixt eight and nine o'clock on the 5th of March as I was going home to Green's lane, I met five or ≈øix men with ≈øticks in their hands, about the middle of it I met with much the ≈øame number, and at the end of it of it I met with much the ≈øame number.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Which way were they going?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were going into town towards King ≈øtreet.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know Carrol one of the pri≈øoners?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have known him the≈øe four years by a particular circum≈øtance. I landed at a battery where he was on duty, and entered into conver≈øation with him; and I have took particular notice of him ever ≈øince.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is his general character?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That of a di≈øcreet ≈øober orderly man.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know If a Sentinel was con≈øtantly placed at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, for ≈øeveral months before la≈øt March, by order from the Commanding officer.

On the evening of the 5th of March I was in my own hou≈øe, betwixt nine and ten I heard the bells ring for fire, I went out of the hou≈øe and came into King-≈øtreet; I there ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers and the officer. I went to the officer and a≈øked
him if his men were loaded, he ≈øaid they were; I a≈øked him if they were loaded with ball he made me no an≈øwer, I a≈øked if they were going to fire, he ≈øaid they could not fire without his orders; directly I ≈øaw a ≈ønow ball and ≈øtick come from behind me which ≈øtruck the grenadier on the right, which I took to be Warren, he fended in off with his mu≈øket as well as he could, and immediately he fired.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Where did he ≈øtand?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He was the fir≈øt man on the right, and the third man from the officer; immediately after the fir≈øt gun, the officer turned to the right and I turned to the left and went down the lane; I heard the word fire given, but whether it was the town's people or the officer, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any blows given to the ≈øoldiers before the firing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I ≈øaw none.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were any blows given after the fir≈øt and before the ≈øecond gun fired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q

sp.p: On the evening of the 5th of March I left my hou≈øe in Winter ≈øtreet, and went to ≈øee a friend in the neighbourhood of Dr. Cooper's meeting. I went down the main-≈øtreet, and coming near Boyl≈øton's alley, I ≈øaw a number of boys and children from twelve to fifteen years old, betwixt Mr. Jack≈øon's and the alley; ≈øome of them had walking canes. sp.p: Yes, it was a very bright night, the≈øe lads came down, ≈øome of them came to the Market ≈øquare, one got a ≈øtave, others pieces of pine, they were very ≈ømall, I do not know whether any of the lads were cut.‚ÄîI turned and then ≈øaw an oy≈øter-man, who ≈øaid to me, damn it here is what I have got by going up; (≈øhowing his ≈øhoulder wounded) I put my finger into the wound and blooded it very much.‚ÄîThis oy≈øter man made a ≈øtand, and ≈øeveral people got round him a≈øking him que≈øtions.

I pa≈ø≈øed up Royal-exchange-lane by the Sentinel, quite near him, I ≈øuppo≈øe there were not above fifteen per≈øons in King-≈øtreet, very few for ≈øuch a plea≈øant night; it was then about fifteen minutes after nine.

sp.speaker: A.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time when you ≈øaw the ≈øoldiers run out of the alley, did you hear any body ≈øay there had been a great number of people at the barracks?

sp.p:
On Monday evening the 5th March I went to Mr. Amory's, while I was there the bell rung, which I ≈øuppo≈øed was for nine o'clock, Mrs. Amory ≈øaid ≈øhe imagined it was fire, I looked at the clock, it was twenty minutes after nine; I was going out to enquire where the fire was, Mr. Taylor came in, he ≈øaid there was no fire, but he under≈øtood the
≈øoldiers were coming up to cut down Liberty-tree; I then went out to make enquiry, when I came out of the door, before I had got into King-≈øtreet, I met Mr. Walker the ≈øhip carpenter, I a≈øked him what the matter was? He ≈øaid the ≈øolers had ≈øallied out from Smith's barracks, and had fell on the inhabitants, and had cut and wounded a number of them, but that they were drove into the barracks: I then went to my hou≈øe to ‚Ä¢ form Mrs. Payne that it was not fire, apprehending ≈øhe m ‚Ä¢ t be frightned; I immediately went out again, and whe ‚Ä¢ came into the ≈øtreet, there was nobody in the ≈øtreet at all; the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe was walking by him≈øelf as u≈øual nobody pear him; I went up towards the Town hou≈øe, and ≈øtood by the watch-hou≈øe, where were a number of people, I enquired of them what the matter was? While I ≈øtood there, I heard a con≈øiderable noi≈øe in Cornhill, and pre≈øently I heard a noi≈øe of ≈øome people coming up Sil≈øby's-alley, at fir≈øt I imagined it was ≈øoldiers coming up that alley, and had ≈øome thoughts of retiring up the Townhou≈øe ≈øteps, but ≈øoon found they were inhabitants, I ≈øtood till they came up to me, I believe there might be twenty at the extent, ≈øome of the per≈øons had ≈øticks, ≈øome had not, I believe there were as many with ≈øticks as without, they made a con≈øiderable noi≈øe, and cried, where are they?‚Äî Where are they? At this time there came up a barber's boy and ≈øaid the Sentry at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe had knocked down a boy belonging to their ≈øhop; the people then turned about and went down to the Sentry; I then was left as it were alone: I proceeded towards my own hou≈øe, when I had got about half way, I met Mr. Spear the cooper, he ≈øaid, Mr. Payne do not go away, I am afraid the Main-guard will come down; I told him I was more afraid of tho≈øe people that had ≈øurrounded the Sentry, and de≈øired him if he had any influence over them to endeavour to take them off; I then proceeded towards my own hou≈øe, and when I got as far as Mr. Davis's, directly oppo≈øite to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe; I ≈øaw a number of per≈øons going up the ≈øteps at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, and heard a violent knocking at the door, the Sentry ≈øtood by the box as I took it, I ≈øtopt to ≈øee if they opened the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe door to let them in, I found they did not open the door; I then retired to my own hou≈øe, and ≈øtood on the fill of my door.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Yes. Mr. Gray and I were talking of the fooli≈øhne≈øs of the people in calling the Sentry to fi ‚Ä¢ e on them; in about a minute after, I ≈øaw a number „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øoldiers come down from the Main guard, and it appeare ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ o me they had their mu≈økets in a horizontal po≈øture, they went towards the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, and ≈øhoved the people from the hou≈øe, I did not ≈øee in what manner they drew up: at this time Mr. Beth ‚Ä¢
joined us on my ≈øteps at the door, and the noi≈øe in the ≈øtreet continued much the ≈øame as before, fire! fire! Damn you, fire! why do you not fire? Soon after this, I thought I heard a gun ≈ønap, I ≈øaid to Mr. Gray, there is a gun ≈ønapped, did you not hear it? He ≈øaid yes; immediately a gun went off, I reached to ≈øee whether it was loaded with powder, or any body lying dead, I heard three more, then there was a pau≈øe, and I heard the iron rammers go „Äà‚óä„Äâ their guns, and then there was three more di≈øcharged, one after another; it appeared to me there were ≈øeven in all, as ≈øoon as the la≈øt gun was di≈øcharged I perceived I was wounded, and went into the hou≈øe.

div.head: Mr. JOSIAH QUINCY, junr.

div.p:
WE have at length gone through the evidence in behalf of the pri≈øoners. The witne≈ø≈øes have now placed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
fore
you, that ≈øtate of facts, from which re≈øults our defence. The examination has been ≈øo lengthy, that I am afraid ≈øome painful ≈øen≈øations ari≈øe, when you find that you are now to fit and hear the remarks of council. But you ≈øhould reflect, that no more indulgence is ≈øhown to the Pri≈øoners now on trial, than has ever been ≈øhown in all capital can ≈øee: the trial of one man has often taken up ≈øeveral days, when you con≈øider, therefore, that there are eight li ‚Ä¢ es „Äà‚óä„Äâ i≈ø≈øue, the importance of the trial will ≈øhow the nece≈ø≈øity of its length. To each of the pri≈øoners different evidence applies, and each of them draw their defence from different quarters.

I ≈øtated to you, Gentlemen, your duty, in opening this mu≈øe‚Äîdo not forget the di≈øcharge of it. You are paying a debt you owe the community for your own protection‚ñ™ and ≈øafety: by the ≈øame mode of trial are your own rights to receive a determination; and in your turn, a time may come, when you will expect and claim a ≈øimilar return from ≈øome other jury of your fellow ≈øubjects.

In opening, I pointed out the dangers to which you were expo≈øed; I tru≈øt your own recollection will now preclude a recapitulation of them. The rea≈øons of what I then ≈øaid, I tru≈øt have in ≈øome mea≈øure appeared: the propriety of ≈øome of tho≈øe ob≈øervations has been corroborated by ≈øucceeding evidence; and you mu≈øt have traced your≈øelves, ≈øome of the≈øe con≈øequences, turning out in evidence, which have had an intimate relation, if not their origin, with ≈øome or all of tho≈øe opinions, notions, ≈øentiments or pa≈ø≈øions (call them what you will) which I too ‚Ä¢ occa≈øion to ob≈øerve, as clues, aids, and leading ≈øtrings, in our intended examination and deci≈øion.

How much need was there for my de≈øire, that you ≈øhould ≈øu≈øpend your judgment till the witne≈ø≈øes were all examined? How different is the complexion of the cau≈øe? Will not all this ≈øerve to ≈øhow every hone≈øt man, the little truth to he attained in partial hearings? We have often ≈øeen communities complain of ex parte te≈øtimonies: individuals, as well as ≈øocieties, of men, are equally ≈øu≈øceptible of injuries of this kind: this trial ought to have another effect‚ñ™ it ≈øhould ≈øerve to convince us all, of the impropriety, nay inju≈øtice, of giving a latitude in conver≈øation upon topicks, likely to come under a judicial deci≈øion; the criminality of this conduct is certainly inhanced, when ≈øuch loo ‚Ä¢ e ≈øallies
and di≈øcour≈øes are ≈øo prevalent as to be likely to touch the life of a citizen. Moreover there is ≈øo little certainty to be obtained by ≈øuch kind of methods, I wonder we ≈øo often find them practiced. In the pre≈øent ca≈øe, how great was the pr ‚Ä¢ po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion again≈øt us? And I appeal to you, Gentlemen, what cau≈øe there now is to alter our ≈øentiments‚ñ™ Will any ≈øober, prudent man countenance the proceedings of the people in King-≈øtreet‚Äîcan any one ju≈øtify their conduct‚Äîis there any one man, or any body of men, who are intere≈øted to e≈øpou≈øe and ≈øupport their conduct? Surely no. But our enquiry mu≈øt be confined to the legality of their conduct‚ñ™ and here can be no difficulty. It was certainly illegal, unle≈øs many witne≈ø≈øes are directly perjured: Witne≈ø≈øes who have no apparent intere≈øt to fal≈øify‚Äîwitne≈ø≈øes, who have given their te≈øtimony with candor and accuracy‚Äîwitne≈ø≈øes, who≈øe credibility ≈øtands untouched‚Äîwho≈øe credibility, the council for the king, do not pretend to impeach; or hin ‚Ä¢ a ≈øugge≈øtion to their di≈øadvantage.

I ≈øay, Gentlemen, by the ≈øtandard of the law are we to judge the actions of the people who were the a≈ø≈øailants, and tho≈øe who were the a≈ø≈øailed, and ‚Ä¢ hen on duty. And here‚ñ™ Gentlemen, the rule, we formerly laid down, takes place. To the facts, Gentlemen, apply your≈øelves. Con≈øider them as te≈øtified: weigh the credibility of the witne≈ø≈øes‚Äî balance their te≈øtimony‚Äîcompare the ≈øeveral parts of it‚Äî ≈øee the amount of it:‚Äîand then according to your oaths ‚Äî"Make true deliverance according to your evidence." That is Gentlemen, having ≈øettled the facts‚Äîbring them truely to the ≈øtandard of the law; the king's judges who are acquainted with it, who are pre≈øumed be≈øt to know it, will then in≈øpect this great ≈øtandard of right and wrong, truth and ju≈øtice; and they are to determine the degree of guilt to which the fact ri≈øes.

But before we come to tho≈øe divi≈øions of enquiry, under which I intend to con≈øider the evidence, let me once more carefully di≈øtingui≈øh between the tran≈øactions in Cornhill and tho≈øe by the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe.

The conduct of the ≈øoldiers in Cornhill may well be ≈øuppo≈øed to have exa≈øperated the minds of all who beheld their behaviour. Their actions accumulated guilt as it flew ‚Äîat lea≈øt, we may well ≈øuppo≈øe, the incen≈øed people who related them, added new colours to the ≈øcene. The flame of re≈øentment imperceptibly enkindles, and a common acquaintance
with human nature will ≈øhew, that it is no extravagant ≈øuppo≈øition, to imagine many a moderate man might at ≈øuch a ≈øea≈øon, with ≈øuch ≈øentiments, which I have more than once noticed;‚Äîhearing ≈øuch relations and complaints; I ≈øay do I injure any one, in ≈øuppo≈øing, that under all the≈øe circum≈øtances, a very moderate per≈øon, who in ordinary matters acted with ≈øingular di≈øcretion, ≈øhould now be drawn imperceptibly away, or rather tran≈øported into mea≈øures, which in a future moment he would condemn and lament. What more natural ≈øuppo≈øition, than to ≈øuppo≈øe many an hone≈øt mind might at this time fluctuate thus.‚ÄîThe ≈øoldiers are here‚Äîwe wi≈øh them away: we did not ≈øend for them‚Äîthey have cut and wounded the peaceable inhabitants, and it may be my turn next. At this in≈øtant of time, he has a fre≈øh detail of injuries‚Äîre≈øentment redoubles every ≈øucce≈ø≈øive moment‚Äîhuzza! for the Main-guard: we are in a moment before the Cu≈øtom-Hou≈øe. No time is given for recollection. We find, from the king's evidence, and from our own, the cry was "Here is a ≈øoldier!" Not here is the ≈øoldier who has injured us‚Äîhere is the fellow who wounded the man in Cornihll. No, the rea≈øoning or rather ferment ≈øeems to be, the ≈øoldiers have committed an outrage, we have an equal right to inflict puni≈øhment‚Äîor rather revenge, which they had to make an a≈ø≈øault.‚ÄîThey ≈øaid right, but never con≈øidered, that, tho≈øe ≈øoldiers had no right at all. The≈øe are ≈øentiments natural enough to per≈øons in this ≈øtate of mind‚Äîwe can ea≈øily ≈øuppo≈øe even good men thinking and acting thus. Very ≈øimilar to this is the force of Dr. Hirons's te≈øtimony, and ≈øome others. But our enquiry is‚ÄîWhat ≈øays the law? We mu≈øt calmly enquire, whether this, or any thing like it, is countenanced by the law. What is natural to the man, what are his feelings are one thing: what is the duty of the citizen is quite another. Rea≈øon mu≈øt re≈øume her ≈øeat‚Äîand then we ≈øhall hear, and obey the voice of the law.

The law indulges no man in being his own avenger.‚Äî Early, in the hi≈øtory of juri≈øprudence, we find the ≈øword taken from the party injured, and put into the hands of the magi≈øtrate. Were not this the ca≈øe, puni≈øhment would know no bounds in extent or duration. Be≈øides, it ≈øaps the very root of di≈øtributive ju≈øtice, when any individual invades the prerogative of law, and ≈ønatches from the civil magi≈øtrate the balance and the rod. How much more are the
pillars of ≈øecurity ≈øhaken, when a mixt body, a≈ø≈øembled as tho≈øe in King-≈øtreet, a≈ø≈øume the province of ju≈øtice, and invade the rights of the citizen? For it mu≈øt not be forgot, that the ≈øoldier is a citizen, equally intitled with us all to protection and ≈øecurity. Hence all are alike obliged to pay obedience to the law: For the price of this protection is that of obedience.

Let it not be apprehended, that I am advancing a doctrine, that a ≈øoldier may attack an inhabitant, and he not allowed to defend him≈øelf. No Gentlemen! if a ≈øoldier ru≈øh violently through the ≈øtreet and pre≈øents a weapon of death, in a ≈øtriking po≈øture; no doubt the per≈øon a≈ø≈øailed may defend him≈øelf, even to taking the life of the a≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ lant. Revenge and a ≈øen≈øe of ≈øelf pre≈øervation in≈øtantly take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the per≈øon thus attacked; and the law goes not upon the ab≈øurd ≈øuppo≈øition, that a per≈øon can in the≈øe circum≈øtances, unman him≈øelf. Hence we find a hu≈øband, taking his wife in the act of adultery, in≈øtantly ≈øeizes a deadly weapon and ≈ølays the adulterer;‚Äîit is not murder. Nay a fillip upon the no≈øe or forehead, in anger, is ≈øuppo≈øed by the law to be ≈øufficient provocation to reduce killing to Man≈ølaughter. It is, therefore, upon principles like the≈øe, principles, upon which tho≈øe, who now bear the harde≈øt again≈øt us, at other times, ≈øo much depend; it is, I ≈øay, upon the right of ≈øelf-defence and ≈øelf-pre≈øervation we rely for our acquittal.

Here again it ≈øhould be kept in view, that whenever the party injurying has e≈øcaped by flight, and time ≈øufficient for the pa≈ø≈øions to cool, in judgment of law, hath elap≈øed; however great the injury, the injured party mu≈øt have recour≈øe to law for his redre≈øs. Such is the wi≈ødom of the law; of that law, than which we are none of us to pre≈øume our≈øelves wi≈øer;‚Äîof that law, which is ≈øonned in the experience of ages, and which in conde≈øcen≈øion to the infirmities of fle≈øh and blood (but to nothing el≈øe) extenuates the offence. For no man, ≈øays the learned Judge Fo≈øter, under the protection of the law is to be the avenger of his own wrongs. If they are of ≈øuch a nature for which the laws of ≈øociety will give him an andequate remedy, thither he ought to re≈øort. But be they of what nature ≈øoever, he ought to bear his lot with patience, and remember, that vengeance belongeth to the Mo≈øt High.
Crown Law 296.

Now, Gentlemen, tho≈øe, whoever they were, who committed
the outrage in Cornhill, had ab≈øconded‚Äîthe ≈øoldiers, who are ≈øuppo≈øed to have done them, were confined in their barracks. People were repeatedly told this, and a≈ø≈øured by the military officers, that they ≈øhould not go unpuni≈øhed. But what followed? Are all pre≈øent appea≈øed? We are con≈øtrained, by the force of the evidence, to affirm they were not. I am for the pri≈øoners at the bar, and ≈øhall apologize for it only in the words of the Marquis Beccaria: "If I can but be the in≈øtrument of pre≈øerving one life, his ble≈ø≈øing and tears of tran≈øport, ≈øhall be a ≈øufficient con≈øolation to me, for the contempt of all mankind." As the pri≈øoners ≈øtand before you for their lives, it may be proper, to recollect with what temper the law requires we ≈øhould proceed to this trial. The form of proceeding at their arraignment, has di≈øcovered that the ≈øpirit of the law upon ≈øuch occa≈ø≈øions, is

We find, in the rules laid down by the greate≈øt Engli≈øh Judges, who have been the brighte≈øt of mankind;‚ÄîWe are to look upon it as more beneficial, that many guilty per≈øons ≈øhould e≈øcape unpuni≈øhed, than one innocent per≈øon ≈øhould ≈øuffer. The rea≈øon is, becau≈øe it's of more importance to community, that innocence ≈øhould be protected, than it is, that guilt ≈øhould be puni≈øhed; for guilt and crimes are ≈øo frequent in the world, that all of them cannot be puni≈øhed; and many times they happen in ≈øuch a manner, that it is not of much con≈øequence to the public, whether they are puni≈øhed or not. But when innocence it ≈øelf, is brought to the bar and condemned, e≈øpecially to die, the ≈øubject will exclaim, it is immaterial to me, whether I behave well or ill; for virtue it≈øelf, is no ≈øecurity. And if ≈øuch a ≈øentiment as this, ≈øhould take place in the mind of the ≈øubject, there would be an end to all ≈øecurity what≈øoever. I will read the words of the law it≈øelf.

The rules I ≈øhall produce to you from Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Hale, who≈øe character as a lawyer, a man of learning and philo≈øophy, and as a chri≈øtian, will he di≈øputed by nobody living; one of the greate≈øt and be≈øt characters, the Engli≈øh nation ever produced: his words are the≈øe. 2. H. H. P. C. Tutius ≈øemper e≈øt errare, in acquietando, quam in puniendo, exparte mi≈øericerdioe, quam ex parte ju≈øtifioe, it is always ≈øafer to err in acquitting, than puni≈øhing, on the part of mercy, than the part of ju≈øtice: The next is from the ≈øame authority, 305 Tutius erratur ex parte mitiori, it is always ≈øafer to err on the milder ≈øide, the ≈øide of mercy, H. H. P. C. 509, the be≈øt rule in doubtful ca≈øes, is, rather to incline to acquital than conviction: and in page 300 Quod dubitas ne feceris, Where you are doubtful never act; that is, if you doubt of the pri≈øoners guilt, never declare him guilty; this is always the rule, e≈øpecially in ca≈øes of life. An other rule from the ≈øame Author, 289, where he ≈øays, In ≈øome ca≈øes, pre≈øumptive evidence go far to prove a per≈øon guilty, though there is no expre≈øs proof of the fact, to be committed by him; but then it mu≈øt be very warily pre≈ø≈øed, for
it is better, five guilty per≈øons ≈øhould e≈øcape unpuni≈øhed, than one innocent per≈øon ≈øhould die.

The next authority ≈øhall be from another Judge, of equal character, con≈øidering the age wherein he lived; that is Chancellor Forte≈øcue, in prai≈øe of the laws of England, page 59, this is a very ancient writer on the Engli≈øh law: his words are, "Indeed one would rather, much rather, that twenty guilty per≈øons e≈øcape the puni≈øhment of death, than one innocent per≈øon be condemned, and ≈øuffer capitally." Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Hale, ≈øays, It is better five guilty per≈øons e≈øcape, than one innocent per≈øon ≈øuffer. Lord Chancellor Forti≈øcue, you ≈øee, carries the matter farther, and ≈øays, Indeed one had rather, much rather, that twenty guilty per≈øons ≈øhould e≈øcape, than one innocent per≈øon ≈øuffer capitally. Indeed this rule is not peculiar to the Engli≈øh law, there never was a ≈øy≈øtem of laws in the world, in which this rule did not prevail; it prevailed in the ancient Roman law, and which is more remarkable, it prevails in the modern Roman law, even the Judges in the Courts of Inqui≈øition, who with racks, burnings and ≈øcourges, examine criminals, even there, they pre≈øerve it as a maxim, that it is better the guilty ≈øhould e≈øcape puni≈øhment, than the innocent ≈øuffer. Satius e≈ø≈øe nocentem ab≈øolvi quam in≈øentem damnari, this is the temper we ought to ≈øet out with; and the≈øe the rules we are to be governed by. And I ≈øhall take it for granted, as a fir≈øt principle, that the eight pri≈øoners at the bar, had better be all acquitted, though we ≈øhould admit them all to be guilty, than, that any one of them ≈øhould by your verdict be found guilty, being innocent.
I ≈øhall now con≈øider the ≈øeveral divi≈øions of law, under which the evidence will arrange it≈øelf.

The action now before you, is homicide; that is the killing of one man by another, the law calls it homicide, but it is not criminal in all ca≈øes, for one man to ≈ølay another. Had the pri≈øoners been on the Plains of Abraham, and ≈ølain an hundred Frenchmen a piece, the Engli≈øh law would have con≈øidered it, as a commendable action, virtuous and prai≈øworthy: ≈øo that every in≈øtance of killing a man, is not a crime in the eye of the law; there are many other in≈øtances which I can not enumerate, an officer that executes a per≈øon under ≈øentence of death, &c. So that Gentlemen, every in≈øtance of one man's killing another, is not a crime,
much le≈øs a crime to be puni≈øhed with death. But to de≈øcend to ≈øome more particulars.

The law divides homicide into three branches; the fir≈øt, is ju≈øtifiable, the ≈øecond excu≈øable, and the third felonious; felonious homicide, is ≈øubdivided into two branches; the fir≈øt is murder, which is killing with malice aforethought, the ≈øecond is man≈ølaughter, which is killing a man on a ≈øudden provocation: here Gentlemen, are four ≈øorts of homicide, and you are to con≈øider, whether all the evidence amounts to the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, third, or fourth, of the≈øe heads. The fact, was the ≈ølaying five unhappy per≈øons that night; you are to con≈øider, whether it was ju≈øtifiable, excu≈øable, or felonious; and if felonious, whether it was murder or man≈ølaughter. One of the≈øe four it mu≈øt be, you need not divide your attention to any more particulars. I ≈øhall however, before I come to the evidence, ≈øhow you ≈øeveral authorities, which will a≈ø≈øi≈øt you and me in contemplating the evidence before us.

I ≈øhall begin with ju≈øtifialbe homicide; if an officer a ≈øheriff execute a man on the gallows, draws and quarters him, as in ca≈øe of high trea≈øon, and cuts off his head, this is ju≈øtifiable homicide, it is his duty. So al≈øo, Gentlemen, the law has planted fences and barriers around every individual; it is a ca≈øtle round every man's per≈øon, as well as his hou≈øe.‚Äî As the love of God and our neighbour, comprehends the whole duty of man, ≈øo ≈øelf-love and ≈øocial, comprehend all the duties we owe to mankind, and the fir≈øt branch is ≈øelf-love, which is not only our indi≈øputable right, but our cleare≈øt duty, by the laws of nature, this is interwoven in the heart of every individual; God almighty, who≈øe laws we cannot alter, has implanted it there, and we can annihilate our≈øelves, as ea≈øily as root out this affection for our≈øelves. It is the fir≈øt, and ≈øtronge≈øt principle in our nature, Ju≈øtice Black≈øtone calls it, "The primary cannon in the law of nature." That precept of our holy religion which commands us to love our neighbour as our≈øelves doth not command us to love our neighbour better than our≈øelves, or ≈øo well, no Chri≈øtian Divine hath given this interpretation. The precept enjoins, that our benevolence to our fellow men, ≈øhould be as real and ≈øincere, as our affections to our≈øelves, not that it ≈øhould be as great in degree. A man is authori≈øed therefore by common ≈øen≈øe, and the laws of Egland, as well as tho≈øe of nature, to love
him≈øelf better than his fellow ≈øubject: If two per≈øons are ca≈øt away at ≈øea, and get on a plank, (a ca≈øe put by Sir Francis Bacon,) and the plank is in≈øufficient to hold them both, the one hath a right to pu≈øh the other of ‚Ä¢ to ≈øave him≈øelf. The rules of the common law therefore, which authorize a man to pre≈øerve his own life at the expence of another's, are not contradicted by any divine or moral law. We talk of liberty and property, but, if we cut up the law of ≈øelf-defence, we cut up the foundation of both, and if we give up this, the re≈øt is of very little value, and therefore, this principle mu≈øt be ≈øtrictly attended to, for what≈øoever the law pronounces in the ca≈øe of the≈øe eight ≈øoldiers will be the law, to other per≈øons and after ages, all the per≈øons that have ≈ølain mankind in this country, from the beginning to this day, had better have been acquitted, than that a wrong rule and precedent ≈øhould be e≈øtabli≈øhed.

I ≈øhall now, read to you a few authorities on this ≈øubject of ≈øelf-defence. Fo≈øter 273 in the ca≈øe of ju≈øtifiable ≈øelf-defence, "The injured party may repell force with force in defence of his per≈øon, habitation, or property, again≈øt one who manife≈øtly intendeth and endeavoureth with violence, or ≈øurprize, to commit a known felony upon either."‚ÄîIn the≈øe ca≈øes, he is not obliged to retreat, but may pur≈øue his adver≈øary, till he findeth him≈øelf out of danger, and if in a conflict between them he happeneth to kill, ≈øuch killing is ju≈øtifiable." I mu≈øt intreat you, to con≈øider the words of this authority, the injured per≈øon may repell force by force again≈øt any who endeavours to commit any kind of felony on him or his, here the rule is, I have a right to ≈øtand on my own defence, if you intend to commit felony; if any of the per≈øons made an attack on the≈øe ≈øoldiers, with an intention to rob them, if it was but to take their hats feloniou≈øly, they had a right to kill them on the ≈øpot, and had no bu≈øine≈øs to retreat; if a robber meets me in the ≈øtreet, and commands me to ≈øurrender my pur≈øe, I have a right to kill him without a≈øking que≈øtions; if a per≈øons commits a bare a≈ø≈øault on me, this will not ju≈øtify killing, but if he a≈ø≈øaults me in ≈øuch a manner, as to di≈øcover an intention, to kill me, I have a right to de≈øtroy him, that I may put it out of his power to kill me. In the ca≈øe you will have to con≈øider, I do not know there was any attempt to ≈øteal from the≈øe per≈øons; however,
there were ≈øome per≈øons concerned, who would probably enough have ≈øtolen, if there had been any thing to ≈øteal; and many were there who had no ≈øuch di≈øpo≈øition, but this is not the point we aim at, the que≈øtion is, are you ≈øatisfied, the people made the attack in order to kill the ≈øoldiers? If you are ≈øatisfied that the people, who ever they were, made that a≈ø≈øault, with a de≈øign to kill or maim the ≈øoldiers, this was ≈øuch an a≈ø≈øault, as will ju≈øtify the ≈øoldiers killing in their own defence. Further it ≈øeems to me, we may make another que≈øtion, whether you are ≈øatisfied that their real intention was to kill or maim or not? if any rea≈øonable man, in the ≈øituation of one of the≈øe ≈øoldiers, would have had rea≈øon to believe in the time of it, that the people came with an intention to kill him, whether you have this ≈øatisfaction now, or not in your own minds, they were ju≈øtifiable, at lea≈øt excu≈øable in firing; you and I, may be ≈øu≈øpicious that the people who made this a≈ø≈øault on the ≈øoldiers, did it to put them to the flight, on purpo≈øe that they might go exulting about the town afterwards in triumph; but this will not do, you mu≈øt place your≈øelves in the ≈øituation of Wemms or Killroy‚Äîcon≈øider your≈øelves, as knowing that the prejudices of the world about you, were again≈øt you; that the people about you, thought you came to dragoon them into obedience to ≈øtatutes, in≈øtructions, mandates and edicts, which they thoroughly dete≈øted; that many of the≈øe people were thoughtle≈øs and incon≈øiderate, old and young, ≈øailors and landmen, negroes and molattos; that they, the ≈øoldiers had no friends about them, the re≈øt were in oppo≈øition to them; with all the bells ringing, to call the town together to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the people in King-≈øtreet; for they knew by that time, that ‚Ä¢ re was no fi ‚Ä¢ e; the people ≈øhouting, huzzaing, and making the mob whi≈øtle as they call it, which when a boy makes it in the ≈øtreet, is no formidable thing, but when made by a multitude, is a mo≈øt hideous ≈øhriek, almo≈øt as terrible as an Indian yell; the people crying Kill them! Kill them! Knock them over! heaving ≈ønow-balls, oy≈øter ≈øhells, clubs, white birch ≈øticks three inches and an half diameter, con≈øider your≈øelves, in this ≈øituation, and then judge, whether a rea≈øonable man in the ≈øoldiers ≈øituation, would not have concluded they were going to kill him.‚ÄîI believe, if I was to rever≈øe the ≈øcene, I ≈øhould bring it home to our own bo≈øoms; ≈øuppo≈øe Colonel Mar≈øhall, when he came out of his own door, and ≈øaw the≈øe grenadiers coming
down with ≈øwords, &c. had thought it proper to have appointed a military watch; ≈øuppo≈øe he had a≈ø≈øembled Gray and Attucks that were killed, or any other per≈øons in town, and applanted them in that ≈øtation as a military watch, and there had come from Murray's barracks, thirty or forty ≈øoldiers, with no other arms than ≈ønow-balls, cakes of ice, oy≈øter-≈øhells, cinders and clubs, and attacked this military watch in this manner, what do you ≈øuppo≈øe would have been the feelings and rea≈øonings of any of our hou≈øeholders; I confe≈øs I believe they would not have borne the one half of what the witne≈ø≈øes have ≈øworn the ≈øoldiers bore, till they had ≈øhot down as many as were nece≈ø≈øary to intimidate and di≈øper≈øe the re≈øt; becau≈øe, the law does not oblige us to bear in≈øults to the danger of our lives, to ≈øtand ≈øtill with ≈øuch a number of people round us, throwing ≈øuch things at us, and threatening our lives, until we are di≈øabled to defend our ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ves.

"Where a known felony, is attempted upon the per≈øon, be it to rob, or murder, here the party a≈ø≈øaulted may repel force with force, and even his own ≈øervant then attendant on him, or any other per≈øon pre≈øent, may interpo≈øe for preventing mi≈øchief, and if death en≈øues, the party ≈øo interpo≈øing will be ju≈øtified.‚ÄîIn this ca≈øe nature and ≈øocial duty co-operate." Hawkins P. C. Chap. 28, ¬ß 25. towards the end, "Yet it ≈øeems that a private per≈øon, a fortiori, an officer of ju≈øtice, who happens unavoidably to kill another in endeavouring to defend him≈øelf from, or ≈øuppre≈øs dangerous rioters, may ju≈øtify the fact, in as much as he only does his duty in aid of the public ju≈øtice." "And I can ≈øee no rea≈øon why a per≈øon, who without provocation is a≈ø≈øaulted by another in any place what≈øoever, in ≈øuch a manner „Äà‚óä„Äâ plainly ≈øhews an intent to murder him, as by di≈øcharging a pi≈øtol, or pu≈øhing at him with a drawn ≈øword, &c. may not ju≈øtify killing ≈øuch an a≈ø≈øailant, as much as if he had attempted to rob him: For is not he who attempts to murder me, more injurious than he who barely attempts to rob me? There is no occa≈øion for the Magi≈øtrate to read the Riot. act.‚Äî In the ca≈øe before you, I ≈øuppo≈øe you will be ≈øati≈øfied when you come to examine the witne≈ø≈øes, and compare it with the rules of the common law, ab≈øtracted from all mutiny-acts and articles of war, that the≈øe ≈øoldiers were in ≈øuch a ≈øituation, that they could not help them≈øelves; people were coming from Royal exchange-lane, and other parts of the town, with clubs, and cord wood ≈øticks; the ≈øoldiers were planted by the wall of the Cu≈øtom Hou≈øe; they could not retreat, they were ≈øurrounded on all ≈øides, for there were people behind them, as well as before them; there were a number of people in Royal-exchange lane; the ≈øoldiers were ≈øo near to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, that they could not retreat, unle≈øs they had gone into the brick wall of it. Ld. C. J. HOLT, in Mawgrige's Ca≈øe, Keyling 128, ≈øaye, "Now it hath been held, that if A of his malice prepen≈øed

It is not rea≈øonable for any man that is dangerou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted, and when he perceives his life in danger from his adver≈øary, but to have liberty for the ≈øecurity of his own life, to pur≈øue him that maliciou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted him; for he that hath manife≈øted that he hath malice again≈øt another, is not fit to be tru≈øted with a dangerous weapon in his hand. And ≈øo re≈øolved by all the Judges when they met at Seargeant's inn, in preparation for my Lord Morley's trial."

In the ca≈øe here, we will take Montgomery, if you plea≈øe, when he was attacked by the ≈øtout man with the ≈øtick, who aimed it at his head, with a number of people round him, crying out, Kill them! Kill them! had he not a right to kill the man. It all the party were guilty of the a≈ø≈øault made by the ≈øtout man, and all of them had di≈øcovered malice in their hearts, had not Montgomery a right, according to Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Holt, to put it one of their power to wreak their malice upon him. I will not at pre≈øent, look for any more authorities in the point of ≈øelf-defence; you will be able to judge from the≈øe, how far the law goes, in ju≈øtifying or excu≈øing any per≈øon in defence of him≈øelf, or taking away the life of another who threatens him, in life or limb: the next point is this, That in ca≈øe of an unlawful a≈ø≈øembly, all and every one of the a≈ø≈øembly is guilty of all and every unlawful act, committed by any one of that a≈ø≈øembly, in pro≈øecution of the unlawful de≈øign they ≈øet out upon.

Rules of law ≈øhould be univer≈øally known, what ever effect they may have on politics; they are rules of common law, the law of the land, and it is certainly true, that where ever there is an unlawful a≈ø≈øembly, let it con≈øi≈øt of many per≈øons or a few, every man in it is guilty of every unlawful act of committed by any one of the whole party, be they more or be they le≈øs, in pur≈øuance of their unlawful de≈øign. This is the policy of the law: to di≈øcourage and prevent riots, in≈øurrections, turbulence and tumults.

In the continual vici≈ø≈øitudes of human things, amid≈øt the
≈øhocks of fortune and the whirls of pa≈ø≈øion, that take place at certain critical ≈øea≈øons, even in the milde≈øt government, the people are liable to run into riots and tumults.‚ÄîThere are Church-quakes and ≈øtate-quakes, in the moral and political world, as well as earthquakes, ≈øtorms and tempe≈øts in the phy≈øical‚ÄîThus much however mu≈øt be ≈øaid in favour of the people and of human nature, that it is a general, if not univer≈øal truth, that the aptitude of the people to mutinies, ≈øeditions, tumults and in≈øurrections, is in direct proportion to the de≈øpoti≈øm of the government.‚Äî In governments compleatly de≈øpotic, i.e. where the will of one man, is the only law, this di≈øpo≈øition is mo≈øt prevalent. ‚ÄîIn Ari≈øtocracies, next‚Äîin mixed Monarchies, le≈øs than either of the former‚Äîin compleat Republick's the lea≈øt of all ‚Äîand under the ≈øame form of government as in a limited monarchy, for example, the virtue and wi≈ødom of the admini≈øtration, may generally be mea≈øured by the peace and order, that are ≈øeen among the people.‚ÄîHowever this may be, ≈øuch is the imperfection of all things in this world, that no form of government, and perhaps no wi≈ødom or virtue in the admini≈øtration, can at all times avoid riots and di≈øorders among the people."

Now it is from this difficulty, that the policy of the law hath framed ≈øuch ≈øtrong di≈øcouragements, to ≈øecure the people again≈øt tumults; becau≈øe when they once begin, there is danger of their running to ≈øuch exce≈ø≈øes, as will overturn the whole ≈øy≈øtem of government.‚Äî There is the rule from the reverend ≈øage of the law, ≈øo often quoted before.

I ye≈øterday afternoon produced from the be≈øt authorities, tho≈øe rules of law which mu≈øt govern all ca≈øes of homicide, particularly that which is now before you; it now remains to con≈øider the evidence, and ≈øee whether any thing has occured, that may be compared to the rules read to you; and I will not trouble my≈øelf nor you with laboured endeavours to be methodical, I ≈øhall endeavour to make ≈øome few ob≈øervations, on the te≈øtimonies of the witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øuch as will place the facts in a true point of light, with as much brevity as po≈ø≈øible; but I ≈øuppo≈øe it would take me four hours to read to you, (if I did nothing el≈øe but read) the

The witne≈ø≈øes are confident that they know the pri≈øoners at the barr, and that they were pre≈øent that night, and of the party; however, it is apparent, that witne≈ø≈øes are liable to make mi≈øtakes, by a ≈øingle example before you. He ≈øwears po≈øitively, that he not only ≈øaw ice or ≈ønow thrown, but ≈øaw the gus ≈øtruck ≈øeveral times; if you
believe this witne≈øs, of who≈øe credibility you are wholly the Judges, as you are of every other; if you do not believe him, there are many others who ≈øwear to circum≈øtances in favour of the pri≈øoners; it ≈øhould ≈øeem impo≈ø≈øible you ≈øhould di≈øbelieve ≈øo great a number, and of crown witne≈ø≈øes too, who ≈øwear to ≈øuch variety of circum≈øtances that fall in with one another ≈øo naturally to form our defence; this witne≈øs ≈øwears po≈øitively, there were a dozen of per≈øons with clubs, ≈øurrounded the party; twelve ≈øailors with clubs, were by much an overmatch to eight ≈øoldiers, chained there by the order and command of their officer, to ≈øtand in defence of the Sentry, not only ≈øo, but under an oath to ≈øtand there, i. e. to obey the lawful command of their officer, as much, Gentlemen of the Jury, as you are under oath to determine this cau≈øe be law and evidence; clubs they had not, and they could not defend them≈øelves with their bayonets again≈øt ≈øo many people; it was in the power of the ‚Ä¢ ailors to kill one half or the whole of the party if they had been ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed; what had the ≈øoldiers to expect, when twelve per≈øons armed with clubs, (≈øailors too, between whom and ≈øoldiers, there is ≈øuch an antipathy, that they fight as naturally when they meet, as the elephant and Rhinoc ‚Ä¢ ros) were daring enough, even at the time when they were loading their guns, to come up with their clubs, and ≈ømite on their guns; what had eight ≈øoldiers to expect from ≈øuch a ≈øet of people? He ≈øays, the ≈øoldiers were loading their guns, when the twelve ≈øurrounded them, the people went up to them within the length of their guns, and before the firing; be≈øides all this he ≈øwears, they were called cowardly ra≈øeals, and dared to fire; he ≈øays the≈øe people were all dre≈ø≈øed like ≈øailors; and I believe, that by and bye you will find evidence enough to ≈øati≈øfy you, the≈øe were ≈øome of the per≈øons that came out of Dock≈øquare, after making the attack on Murray's barracks, and who had been arming them≈øelves with ≈øticks from the butchers ≈øtalls and cord wood piles, and marched up round Cornhill

The next witne≈øs is Dodge, he ≈øays, there were fifty people near the ≈øoldiers pu≈øhing at them; now the witne≈øs before ≈øay, there were twelve ≈øailors with clubs, but now here are fifty more aiding and abetting of them, ready to relieve them in ca≈øe of need; now what could the people expect? It was their bu≈øine≈øs to have taken them≈øelves out of the way; ≈øome prudent people by the Town-hou≈øe, told them not to meddle with the guard, but you hear nothing of this from the≈øe fifty people; no, in≈øtead of that, they were huzz ‚Ä¢ ing and whi≈øtling, crying damn you, fire! why don't you fire? were thrown, and I heard ice rattle on their guns, there were ≈øome clubs thrown from a con≈øiderabl di≈øtance acro≈øs the ≈øtreet. This witne≈øs ≈øwears he ≈øaw ≈ønow-balls thrown clo≈øe before the party, and he took them to be thrown on purpo≈øe, he ≈øaw oy≈øter-≈øhells likewi≈øe thrown.‚Äî Mr. Langford the watchman, is more particular in his te≈øtimony, and de≈øerves a very particular con≈øideration, becau≈øe it is intended by the council for the crown, that his te≈øtimony ≈øhall di≈øtingui≈øh Killroy from the re≈øt of the pri≈øoners, and exempt him from tho≈øe pleas of ju≈øtification, excu≈øe or ex ‚Ä¢ en ‚Ä¢ tation, which we rely upon for the whole party, becau≈øe he had previous malice, and they would from hence conclude, he aimed at a particular per≈øon; you will con≈øider all the evidence with regard to that, by it≈øelf.

Hemmingway, the ≈øheriff's coachman, ≈øwears he knew Killroy, and that he heard him ≈øay, he would never mi≈øs an opportunity of ≈øi ‚Ä¢ ing upon the inhabitants: this is to prove that Killroy had preconceived malice in his heart, not indeed again≈øt the unhappy per≈øons who were killed, but again≈øt the inhabitants in general, that he had the ≈øpirit not only of a Turk or an Arab, but of the devil; but admitting that this te≈øtimony is litterally true, and that he had all the malice they would wi≈øh to prove, yet, if he was a≈ø≈øaulted that night, and his life in danger, he had a right to defend him≈øelf as well as another man; if he had malice before, it does not take away from him the right of defending him≈øelf again≈øt any unju≈øt aggre≈ø≈øor. But it is not at all improbable, that there was ≈øome mi≈øunder≈øtanding about the≈øe loo≈øe expre≈ø≈øions; perhaps the man had no thoughts of what his words might import; many a man in his cups, or in anger, which is a ≈øhort fit of madne≈øs, hath uttered the ra≈øhe≈øt expre≈ø≈øions, who had no ≈øuch ≈øavage di≈øpo≈øition in general: ≈øo that there is but little weight in expre≈ø≈øions uttered at a kitching fire, before a maid and a coachman, where he might think him≈øelf at liberty to talk as much like a bully, a fool, and a madman as he plea≈øed, and that no evil would come of it. peril; but ≈øtill what he ≈øaid, amounts in ≈øtrictne≈øs, to no more than this, "If the inhabitants make an attack on me, I will not bear from them what I have done already;" or I ill bear no more, than what I am obliged by law to bear. No doubt it was under the fret of his ≈øpirits, the indignation, mortification, grief and ≈øhame, that he had ≈øuffered a defeat at the Rope-walks; it was ju≈øt after an account of an aff ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y was publi≈øhed here, betwixt the ≈øoldiers and inhabitants at New York. There was a little before the 5th of March, much noi≈øe in this town, and a pompuous account in the news papers, of a victory obtained by the inhabitants there over the ≈øoldiers; which doubtle≈øs excited the re≈øentment of the ≈øoldiers here, as well as exultations among ≈øome ≈øorts of the inhabitants: and the ringing of the bells here, was probably copied from New York, a wretched example in this, and in two other in≈øtances at lea≈øt: the defeat of the ≈øoldiers at the Rope-walks, was about that time too, and if he did, after that, u≈øe ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øions, it ought not to weigh too much in this ca≈øe. Some of the witne≈ø≈øes, have ≈øworn that Gray was active in the battle at the Rope walks, and that Killroy was once there, from whence the Council for the Crown would infer, that Killroy; in King ≈øtreet, on the 5th of March in the night, kenw Gray whom he had ≈øeen at the Rope-walks before, and took that opportunity to gratify his preconceived malice; but if this is all true, it will not take away from him his ju≈øtification, excu≈øe, or extenuation, if he had any.‚Äî The rule of the law is, if there has been mallice between two, and at a di≈øtant time afterwards they met, and one of them a≈ø≈øaults the other's life, or only a≈ø≈øaults him, and he kills in con≈øequence of it, the law pre≈øumes the killing was in ≈øelf defence, or upon the provocation, not on account of the antecedent malice. Witne≈ø≈øes have ≈øworn to the condition of Killroy's bayonet, that it was bloody the morning after the 5th of March. ‚ÄîThe blood they ≈øaw, if any, might be occa≈øioned by a wound given by ≈øome of the bayonets in the affray, po≈ø≈øibly in Mr. Po≈ødick's arm, or it might happen, in the manner mentioned by my brother before.‚ÄîOne bayonet at lea≈øt was ≈øtruck off and it might fall, where the blood of ≈øome per≈øon ≈ølain afterwards flowed.‚ÄîIt would be doing violence to every rule of law and evidence, as well as to common ≈øen≈øe and the feelings of humanity, to infer from the blood on the bayonet, that it had been ≈øtabbed into the brains of Mr. Gray after he was dead, and that by Killroy him≈øelf who had killed him.

Langford "heard the rattling again≈øt the guns, but ≈øaw nothing thrown."‚ÄîThis rattling mu≈øt have been very remarkable, as ≈øo many witne≈ø≈øes heard it, who were not in a ≈øituation to ≈øee what cau≈øed it‚ÄîThe≈øe things which hit the guns made a noi≈øe, tho≈øe which hit the ≈øoldiers per≈øons, did not‚ÄîBut when ≈øo many things were thrown and ≈øo many hit their guns, to ≈øuppo≈øe that none ≈øtruck their per≈øons is incredible.‚ÄîLangford goes on "Gray ≈øtruck me on the ≈øhoulder and a≈øked me what is to pay? I an≈øwered, I don't know but I believe ≈øometh ‚Ä¢ ng will come of it, by and bye."‚ÄîWhence could this apprehen≈øion of mi≈øchief ari≈øe, it L'angford did not think the a≈ø≈øault, the ≈øquabble, the affray was ≈øuch as would provoke the ≈øoldiers to fire?‚Äî" a bayonet went through my great coat and jacket," yet the ≈øoldier did not ≈øtep out of his place‚ÄîThis looks as if Langford was nearer to the party than became a watchman.
