Brewer ≈øaw Killroy, &c. ≈øaw Dr. Young &c. "he ≈øaid the people had better go home." It was an excellent advice, happy for ≈øome of them had they followed it but it ≈øeems all advice was lo≈øt on the≈øe per≈øons, they would harken to none that was given them in Dock ≈øquare, Royal exchange lane or King ≈øtreet, they were bent on making this a≈ø≈øault, and on their own de≈øtruction.

The next witne≈øs that knows any thing was, James Bailey, he ≈øaw Carrol, Montgomery and White, he ≈øaw ≈øome round the Sentry, heaving pieces of ice, large and hard enough to hurt any man, as big as your fi≈øt: one que≈øtion is whether the Sentinel was attacked or not.‚ÄîIf you want evidence of an attack upon him there is enough of it, here is a witne≈øs an inhabitant of the town, ≈øurely no friend to the ≈øoldiers, for he was engaged again≈øt them at the Ropewalks; he ≈øays he ≈øaw twenty or thirty round the Sentry, pelting with cakes of ice, as big as one's fi≈øt; certainly cakes of ice of this ≈øize may kill a man, if they happen to hit ≈øome part of the head.‚ÄîSo that, here was an attack on the Sentinel, the con≈øequence of which he had rea≈øon to dread, and it was prudent in him to call for the Main Guard: he retreated as far as he could, he attempted to get into the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, but could not; then he called to the Guard, and he had a good right to call for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; "he did not know, he told the witne≈øs, what was the matter," "but he was afraid there would be mi≈øchief by and bye;" and well he might, with ≈øo many ≈øhavers and genius's round him‚Äîcapable of throwing ≈øuch dangerous things. Bailey ≈øwears, Montgomery fired the fir≈øt gun, and that he ≈øtood at the right, "the next man to me, I ≈øtood behind him, &c" This witne≈øs certainly is not prejudiced in favour of the ≈øoldiers, he ≈øwears, he ≈øaw a man come up to Montgomery with a club, and knock him down before he fired, and that he not only fell him≈øelf, but his gun flew out of his hand, and as ≈øoon as he ro≈øe he took it up and fired. If he was knocked down on his ≈øtation, had he not rea≈øon to think his life in danger, or did it not rai≈øe his pa≈ø≈øions and put him off his guard; ≈øo that it cannot be more than man≈ølaughter.

When the multitude was ≈øhouting and ‚Ä¢ uzza ‚Ä¢ ng, and threatning life, the bells all ringing, the mob whi≈øtle ≈øcreaming and rending like an Indian yell, the people from all quarters throwing every ≈øpecies of rubbi≈øh they could pick up in the ≈øtreet, and ≈øome who were quite
on the other ≈øide of the ≈øtreet throwing clubs at the whole party, Montgomery in particular, ≈ømote with a club and knocked down, and as ≈øoon as he could ri≈øe and take up his firelock, another club from a far ≈øtruck his b ‚Ä¢ ea≈øt or ≈øhoulder, what could he do? Do you expect he ≈øhould behave like a Stoick Philo≈øopher lo≈øt in Apathy? Patient as Epictatus while his ma≈øter was breaking his leggs with a cudg ‚Ä¢ ?‚ÄîIt is impo≈ø≈øible you ≈øhould find him guilty of murder. You mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe him dive≈øted of all human pa≈ø≈øions, if you don't think him at the lea≈øt provoked, thrown off his guard, and into the ≈øurer brevis, by ≈øuch treatment as this.

Bailey "Saw the Molatto ≈øeven or eight minutes before the firing, at the head of twenty or thirty ≈øailors in Cornhill, and he had a large cordwood ≈øtick." So that this Attucks, by this te≈øtimony of Bailey compared with that of Andrew, and ≈øome others, appears to have undertaken to be the hero of the night; and to lead this army with banners, to form them in the fir≈øt place in Dock ≈øquare, and march them up to King-≈øtreet, with their club ‚Ä¢ ; they pa≈ø≈øed through the main ≈øtreet up to the Main guard, in order to make the attack. If this was not an unlawful a≈ø≈øembly, there never was one in the world. Attucks with his myrmidous comes round Jock≈øon's corner, and down to the party by the Sentry-box; when the ≈øoldiers pu≈øhed the people off, this man with his party cried, do not be afraid of them, they dare not fire, kill them! kill them! knock them over! And he tried to knock their brains out. It is plain the ≈øoldiers did not have their ≈øtation, but cried to the people, ≈øtand off: now to have this reinforcement coming down under the command of a ≈øtout Molatto f ‚Ä¢ llow, who≈øe very looks, was enough to terrify any per≈øon, what had not the ≈øoldiers then to fear? He had hardine≈øs enough to fall in upon them, and with one hand took hold of a bayonet, and with the other knocked the man down: This was the behaviour of Attucks;‚Äîto who≈øe mad behaviour, in all probability, the dreadful carnage of that night, is chiefly to be a≈øcribed. And it is in this manner, this town has been often treated; a Carr from Ireland, and an Attucks from Framingham, happening to be here, ≈øhall ≈øully out upon their thoughtle≈øs enterprizes, at the head of ≈øuch a rabble of Negroes, &c. as they can collect together, and then there are not wanting, per≈øons to a≈øcribe all their doings to the good people of the town.

Mr. Adams proceeded to a minute con≈øideration of every witne≈øs produced on the crown ≈øide; and endeavoured to ≈øhew, from the evidence on that ≈øide, which could not be conte≈øted by the council for the crown, that the a≈ø≈øault upon the party, was ≈øufficiently dangerous to ju≈øtify the pri≈øoners; at lea≈øt, that it was ≈øufficiently provoking, to reduce to man≈ølaughter the crime, even of the two who were ≈øuppo≈øed to be proved to have killed. But it would ≈øwell this publication too much, to in≈øert his ob≈øervations at large, and there is the le≈øs nece≈ø≈øity for it, as they will probably occur to every man who re ‚Ä¢ ds the evidence with attention He then proceeded to con≈øider the te≈øtimonies of the witne≈ø≈øes for the pri≈øoners, which mu≈øt al≈øo be omitted: And concuded,

I will enlarge no more on the evidence, but ≈øubmit it to you.‚ÄîFacts are ≈øtubborn things; and whatever may be our wi≈øhes, our inclinations, or the dictates of our pa≈ø≈øions, they cannot alter the ≈øtate of facts and evidence: nor is the law le≈øs ≈øtable than the fact; if an a≈ø≈øault was made to endanger their lives, the law is clear, they had a right to kill in their own defence; it it was not ≈øo ≈øevere as to endanger their lives, yet if they were a≈ø≈øaulted at all, ≈øtruck and abu≈øed by blows of any ≈øort, by ≈ønow-balls, oy≈øter-≈øhells, cinders clubs, or ≈øticks of any kind; this was a provocation, for which the law reduces the offence of killing, down to man≈ølaughter, in con≈øideration of tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øions in our nature, which cannot be eradicated. To your candour and ju≈øtice I ≈øubmit the pri≈øoners and their cau≈øe.

The law, in all vici≈ø≈øitudes of government, fluctuations of the pa≈ø≈øions, or flights of enthu≈øia≈øm, will pre≈øerve a ≈øteady undeviating cour≈øe; it will not bend to the uncertain wi≈øhes, imaginations, and wanton tempers of men. To u≈øe the words of a great and worthy man, a patriot, and an hero, an enlightned friend of mankind, and a martyr to liberty: I mean ALGERNOON SIDNEY, who from his earlie≈øt infancy ≈øought a tranquil retirement under the ≈øhadow of the tree of liberty, with his tongue, his pen, and his ≈øword, The law, (≈øays he,) no pa≈ø≈øion can di≈øturb. 'Tis void of de≈øire and fear, lu≈øt and anger. 'Tis means ≈øine affectu; written rea≈øon; retaining ≈øome mea≈øure of the divine perfection. It does not enjoin that which plea≈øes a weak, frail man, but without any regard to per≈øons, commands that which is good, and puni≈øhes evil in all, whether rich, or poor, high or low,‚Äî'Tis deaf, inexorable, inflexible.
On the one hand it is inexorable to the cries and lamentations of the pri≈øoners; on the other it is deaf, deaf as an adder to the clamou ‚Ä¢ s of the populace.

[The cau≈øe was then clo≈øed by Robert Treat Paine, E≈øq on the part of the crown: In his argument, he endeavoured to ≈øettle the principal facts, by comparing the evidence as well on the part of the crown as of the pri≈øoners; and al≈øo to ≈øh ‚Ä¢ w, that the many undeniable rules of law, which had been produced, did not apply to the cau≈øe at bar. And further, that even upon a ≈øuppo≈øition, the party had a right to go to the relief of the Sentry, in the manner te≈øtified by the witne≈ø≈øes; yet from their conduct in going down to the Sentry, and behaviour while there, the law would con≈øider them as an unlawful a≈ø≈øembly. But as the per≈øon who wrote the trial in ≈øhort hand, was ≈øo fatigued, that he could not take down what Mr. Paine ≈øaid, we are not able to in≈øert his argument in this publication.]
TUESDAY, half pa≈øt FIVE o'Clock, P. M. (Mr. Paine not having gone through his argument) the Court adjourned to Wedne≈øday morning, Eight o'Clock.
WEDNESDAY morning‚ñ™ Eight o'Clock, the court met according to Adjournment, when Mr. Paine fini≈øhed clo≈øing, and the Court proceeded to ≈øum up the cau≈øe to the Jury.

div.head: JUDGE TROWBRIDGE.
div.p:
William Wemms, James Hartegan, William M'Cauley Hugh White, Matthew Killroy, William Warren, John Carrol and Hugh Montgomery, pri≈øoners at the bar, are charged by the Grand Jurors for the body of this county, with having feloniou≈øly and of their malice aforethought, ≈øhot and thereby killed and murdered Samuel Maverick Samuel Gray, James Caldwell, Patrick Carr, and Cri≈øpus Attucks, again≈øt the peace, crown and dignity of our Sovereign Lord the King; altho' it is laid in each indictment that ≈øome one of the pri≈øoners in particular gave the mortal wound, yet as all the re≈øt of them are charged with being pre≈øent aiding and abetting him to do it, they are all charged as principals in the murder; and therefore, if upon con≈øideration of the evidence given in this ca≈øe, it ≈øhould appear to you that all the pri≈øoners gave the mortal wound, or that any one of them did it, and that the re≈øt were pre≈øent aiding and abetting him to do it, the indictment will be well maintained again≈øt all the
pri≈øoners, ≈øo far as re≈øpects the killing, becau≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øe, the ≈øtroke of one is, in con≈øideration of law, the ≈øtroke of all.1 Hale, 437, 463. 2 Hale, 344, 345. Fo≈øter, 351. Sa ‚Ä¢ k, 334, 5. And as the crime whereof the pri≈øoners are accu≈øed is of ≈øuch a nature as that it might have been committed by any one of them, though the indictments purport a joint charge, yet the law looks on the charge as ≈øeveral again≈øt each of the pri≈øoners.2 Haw. 25. ¬ß 89 To this charge they have ≈øeverally pleaded Not Guilty, and there by thrown the burden of proof upon the crown.‚ÄîCon≈øidering how much time has already been taken up in this ca≈øe, and the multiplicity of evidence that has been given in it, I ≈øhall not ≈øpend any time in recapitulating what each witne≈øs has te≈øtified, e≈øpecially as your Foreman has taken it in writing from the mouths of the witne≈ø≈øes, but ≈øhall endeavour to point out the manner in which the various te≈øtimonies are to be con≈øidered, and how the evidence given is to be applied, ≈øtill leaving it with you to determine how far that which has been te≈øtified by each witne≈øs is to be believed. But before I do this, it may not be improper, con≈øidering what has in the cour≈øe of this year been advanced, publi≈øhed, and indu≈øtriou≈øly propagated among the people, to ob≈øerve to you that none of the indictments again≈øt the pri≈øoners are founded on the act of this province, or the law given to the Jews, but that, all of them are indictments a ‚Ä¢ common law.‚ÄîThe pri≈øoners are charged with having offended again≈øt the common law, and that only; by that law therefore they are to be judged, and by that law condemned, or el≈øe they mu≈øt be acquitted.‚ÄîThis ≈øeems to make it highly proper for me to ≈øay ≈øomething to you upon the common law, upon homicide and the ≈øeveral kinds and degrees of it, and the rules for trial of homicide as ≈øettled and e≈øtabli≈øhed by the common law.‚ÄîThe laws of England are of two kinds, the unwritten or common law, and the written or ≈øtatute law.‚ÄîThe general cu≈øtoms or immemorial u≈øage of the Engli≈øh nation, is properly the common law. And the evidence thereof are the Records of the ≈øeveral Courts of Ju≈øtice, the Books of Reports and Judicial Deci≈øions, and the Treati≈øes of the Sages of the Law, handed down to us from the times of the highe≈øt an ‚Ä¢ iquity1 Black, 63, 64. The common law is the law by which the proceedings and determinations
in the King's ordinary Courts of Ju≈øtice, are guided and directed‚ÄîThis law is the birth right of every Engli≈øhman‚ÄîThe fir≈øt ≈øettlers of this country brought it from England with them‚ÄîIt was in force here when the act of this province again≈øt murder was made. Pro. Act. 9 W. 3. Murder here was then felony by common law, and excluded Clergy by, 23. H. 8. c. 1. and 1. Edw. 6. c. 12.‚ÄîSo that, that province act, created no new felony‚ÄîIt was in aff ‚Ä¢ mance of the common law‚ÄîIf murder by that act had been made a new felony, a murderer would now be intituled to the benefit of clergy by force of 25. E. 3 c 4. becau≈øe it is not taken away by that province act or any other made ≈øince.2 Haw. 33. ¬ß 24. 2 Hale, 230.334 335 Homicide is of three kinds, ju≈øtifi ‚Ä¢ ble, excu≈øable, and ≈øelonious‚ÄîThe fir≈øt has no ≈øhare of guilt at all‚Äîthe ≈øecond very little, but the third is the highe≈øt crime again≈øt the law of nature.4 Black. 177, 8 There are al≈øo degrees of guilt in felonious homicide, which divide the offence into man≈ølaughter and murder.4 Black. 190. I ≈øhall give ≈øome in≈øtances under each head, proper to be con≈øidered in this ca≈øe, and known at this day. And fir≈øt of ju≈øtifiable homicide.‚ÄîKilling him who attempts to rob or murder me, to break open my dwelling-hou≈øe in the night, or to burn it, or by force to commit any other felony on me, my wife, child, ≈øervant, friend, or even a ≈øtranger, if it cannot otherwi≈øe be prevented, is ju≈øtifiable.24 H. 8. c. 5. 1 Hale 488. 4 Black. 180. Fo≈øter 273.4. By common law it was, and ≈øtill is, the duty of peace officers, ≈øuch as Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Sheriffs, Under-≈øheriffs, and Con≈øtables, to ≈øuppre≈øs riots, routs, and unlawful a≈ø≈øemblies.‚Äî The Stat. 13. H. 4. c. 8. ≈øubjected Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Sheriffs, and Under-≈øheriffs to the penalty of ¬£. 100, if they neglected their duty therein. And as the common law obligues the peace officers to ≈øuppre≈øs riots, &c. ≈øo it empowers them to rai≈øe a ≈øufficient force to enable them to do it.‚ÄîA Ju≈øtice of the Peace, Sheriff, or Under-≈øheriff may rai≈øe the power of the county, and the Con≈øtable of a town, the people of that town, to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing a riot and apprehending the rioters, and if they ≈øtand in their defence, re≈øi≈øt the officer, and continue their riotous proceeding in pulling down a hou≈øe, a≈ø≈øaulting and beating, or abu≈øing any per≈øon or per≈øons, ≈øuch rioters may
lawfully be killed, if they cannot otherwi≈øe be prevented1 Haw. 28. ¬ß 14.65. ¬ß 11. 1 Hale 53.293, 4.495, 596.4 Black. 147. It is the duty of all per≈øons (except women, decrepid per≈øons, and infants under fi ‚Ä¢ teen,) to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the peace officers to ≈øuppre≈øs riots, &:c. when called upon to do it.‚Äî They may take with them ≈øuch weapons as are nece≈ø≈øary to enable them effectually to do it, and may ju≈øtify the beating, wounding, and even killing, ≈øuch rioters as re≈øi≈øt, or refu≈øe to ≈øurrender; if the riot cannot otherwi≈øe be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, or the rioters apprehended1 Haw. 63. ¬ß 10.65. ¬ß 20 21.4 Black. 147 179.180. So in ca≈øe of a ≈øudden affray, if a private per≈øon interpo≈øing to part the combatants, and giving notice of his friendly de≈øign, is a≈ø≈øaulted by them, or either of them, and in the ≈øtruggle happens to kill, he may ju≈øtify it, becau≈øe it is the duty of every man to interpo≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes to pre≈øerve the public peace. Fo≈øter 272. 1 Haw 63. ¬ß 11.13 A fortiori private per≈øons may interpo≈øe to ≈øuppre≈øs a riot. Kely. 76 1 Haw. 65. ¬ß 11.

Homicide excu≈øeable in ≈øelf-defence is where one engaged in a ≈øudden affray, quits the combat before a mortal wound given, retreats as far as he ≈øafely can, and then urged by meer nece≈ø≈øity, kills his adver≈øary in the defence of his own life.1 Hale 479. Fo≈øter 277 This differs from ju≈øtifiable ≈øelf defence, becau≈øe he was to blame for engaging in the affray, and therefore mu≈øt retreat as far as he can ≈øafely; whereas in th ‚Ä¢ other ca≈øe aforementioned neither the peace officers, nor his a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, nor the private per≈øon, is obliged to retreat, but may ≈øtand and repel force by force. Fo≈øter 273.

Man≈ølaughter is the unlawful killing another without malice expre≈øs or implied:‚ÄîAs voluntarily upon a ≈øudden heat, or involuntarily in doing an unlawful act4 Black. 191. Man≈ølaughter on a ≈øudden provocation, differs from excu≈øable homicide in ≈øelf deffence, in this; that in one ca≈øe there is an apparent nece≈ø≈øity for ≈øelf pre≈øervation to kill the aggre≈ø≈øor, in the other there is no nece≈ø≈øity at all, it being a ≈øudden act of revenge.4 Black. 192. As where one is taken in the act of adultry, and in≈øtantly killed by the hu≈øband in the fir≈øt tran≈øport of pa≈ø≈øion. Kely. 137. Ray. 212. Fo≈øter 298. So if one, on angry wo ‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ults another by wringing his no≈øe, and he thereupon immediately
draws his ≈øword and kills the a≈ø≈øailant, it is but Man≈ølaughter, becau≈øe the peace is broken, with an indignity to him that received the a≈ø≈øault, and he being ≈øo affronted, might rea≈øonably apprehend the other had ≈øome further de≈øign on him. Kely. 135. Where one happens to kill another in a contention for the wall, it is bat man≈ølaughter1 Haw 31. ¬ß 36. 1 Hale 455, 6. So where H and A came into Buckner's lodging, A takes down a ≈øword in the ≈øcabbard that hung there, ≈øtood at the chamber door with the ≈øword undrawn, to prevent Buckner from going out before they could bring a Bailiff to arre≈øt him for a debt he owed H; and upon ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe between Buckner and H, Buckner takes a dagger out of his pocket, ≈øtabs and kills H with it. This was adjudged only man≈ølaughter at common law, and not to come within the ≈øtatute of I. Ja 1. again≈øt ≈øtabbing, becau≈øe Buckner was unlawfully impri≈øoned. Style's 467. So where an officer abruptly and violently pu≈øhed into a gentleman's chamber, early in the morning to arre≈øt him, without telling him his bu≈øine≈øs, or u≈øing words of arre≈øt, and the gentleman not knowing him to be an officer, in his fir≈øt ≈øurpri≈øe, took down a ≈øword and ≈øtabbed him. This al≈øo was ruled to be but man≈ølaughter at common law, becau≈øe the gentleman might rea≈øonably conclude from the officer's behaviour, that he came to rob or murder him Fo≈øter 298, 9. 1 Hale 370. Kely. 136. So where Mar≈øhal and ≈øome other B ‚Ä¢ iliffs, came to Cook's dwelling hou≈øe about eight o'clock in the morning, called upon him to open his doors and let them enter, becau≈øe they had a warrant, on ≈øuch and ≈øuch writs, at the ≈øuit of ≈øuch per≈øons, to arre≈øt him, and required him to obey them, but he told them they ≈øhould not enter, and bid them depart, and thereupon they broke a window, and then came to the door of the hou≈øe, and in attempting to foree it open, broken one of the hinges, whereupon Cook ≈øhot Mar≈øhal and killed him; it was adjudged not to be murder, becau≈øe though Mar≈øhal was an officer, yet he was not in the due execution of his office, but was doing an unlawful act in attempting to break open the hou≈øe to execute ≈øuch a civil proce≈øs; and every one has a right to defend his hou≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes; but to be man≈ølaughter, becau≈øe Cook ≈øaw Mar≈øhall, knew him, ≈øhot and killed him voluntarily, when he
might have re≈øi≈øted him without killing him. Cro. Car 537 8. Cook's Ca≈øe. Though no words of reproach, nor actions, or ge≈øtures expre≈ø≈øive of reproach or contempt, without an a≈ø≈øault, will by common ‚Ä¢ aw free the party killing from the guilt of murder, Fo≈øter 290. yet words, of menace of bodily harm, may amount to ≈øuch a provocation, as to make the offence to be but man≈ølaughter.1 Hale 456.

If the≈øe determinations appear new and extraordinary to you, it is not to be wondered at, con≈øidering the doctrines that of late have been advanced and propagated among you. In the cour≈øe of this year you doubtle≈øs have heard much of the law given to the Jews, re≈øpecting homicide, as well as of the precept given to Noah, that "Who≈øo ≈øhedeth man's blood, by man ≈øhall his blood be ≈øhed." Whence it has been inferred, that whoever voluntarily kills another, whatever the inducement, or provocation may be, is a murderer, and as ≈øuch ought to be put to death. But ≈øurely not only the avenger of blood, and he who killed a thief breaking up an hou≈øe in the night, were exceptions to that general precept, but al≈øo he who killed another in his own defence. Even the Jewi≈øh Doctors allowed this‚ñ™ 1 Hale, 4. and that ju≈øtly; becau≈øe the right of ≈øelf-defence is founded in the law of nature, The Jews Indeed, ≈øuppo≈ø ‚Ä¢ d their law equally ≈øubjected to death, him who killed another whether of malice aforethought, or on a ≈øudden fa ‚Ä¢ ling out: but it ≈øeems the early chri≈øtian divines did not, for the Clergy in the reign of Canute, the beginning of the eleventh century, ≈øo con≈øerued the Mo≈øaical law as to deem him a muderer, who in time pa≈øt had conceived hatred again≈øt his neighbour and lain in wait for him and killed him, and him guilty of man≈ølaughter only who killed another on ≈øuden provocation; and it is ordained by one of the laws of this Canute, that if any per≈øon ≈øhall with premeditation kill another he ≈øhall be openly delivered up to the kindred of the ≈ølain, but if the killing be not with premeditation the Bi≈øhop ≈øhall take cognizance of it. Ca. Eq. 270, 1. and as homicides have ≈øince happened, and been tried in the King's Courts, the Judges have from time to time, determined them to be either ju≈øtifiable, excu≈øable, or felonious: and if felonious, to be murder or man≈ølaughter,
according to the particular circum≈øtances that attended the killing.

The≈øe determinations of the King's Courts, for ≈øo many ages pa≈øt, ≈øhew, not only what the common law in ca≈øes of this kind is, but that the≈øe rules of the common law, are the re≈øult of the wi≈ødom and experience of many ages.‚Äî However it is not material in the pre≈øent ca≈øe, whether the common law is agreeable to, or variant from, the law given to the Jews, becau≈øe it is certain, the pri≈øoners are not in this Court to be tried by that law, but by the common law, that is according to the ≈øettled and e≈øtabli≈øhed rules, and antient cu≈øtoms of the nation, approved for ≈øucce≈ø≈øions of ages.

Murder, by the common law, is the unlawful killing a rea≈øonable creature, under the King's peace, of malice aforethought, by a per≈øon of ≈øound mind and di≈øcretion.3 In≈øt. 47. 4 Black 19 ‚Ä¢
Malice is the grand criterion that di≈øtingui≈øhes murder from all other homicide. Malice aforethought, is not confined to an old grudge, or fixed, ≈øettled anger again≈øt a particular per≈øon, but it extends to a di≈øpo≈øition to do evil4 Black. 199. Some witne≈ø≈øes have been produced to prove that Montgomery killed Attucks; and Langford ≈øwears Kulroy killed Gray, but none of the witne≈ø≈øes undertake to ≈øay that either of the other pri≈øoners in particular killed either of the other three per≈øons, or that all of them did it. On the contrary it ≈øeems that one of the ≈øix did not fire, and that another of them fired at a boy as he was running down the ≈øtreet, but mi≈ø≈øed him (if he had killed him, as the evidence ≈øtands, it would have been murder) but the witne≈ø≈øes are not agreed as to the per≈øon who fired at the boy, or as to him who did not fire at all. It is highly probable, from the places where the five per≈øons killed fell and their wounds, that they were killed by the di≈øcharge of five ≈øeveral guns only. If you are upon the evidence, ≈øatisfied of that, and al≈øo that Montgomery killed Attucks, and Killroy Gray, it will thence follow that the other three, were killed, not by the other ≈øix pri≈øoners, but by three of them only: and therefore they cannot all be found guilty of it. And as the evidence does not ≈øhew which three killed the three, nor that
either of the ≈øix in particular killed either of the three, you cannot find either of the ≈øix guilty of killing them or either them 1 Hale 442. If you are ≈øatisfied, upon the evidence given you, that Montgomery killed Attucks, you will proceed to inquire whether it was ju≈øtifiable, excu≈øable, or felonious homicide, and it the latter whether it was maliciou≈øly done or not. As he is charged with murder, if the fact of killing be proved, all the circum≈øtances of nece≈ø≈øity or infirmity are to be ≈øatisfactorily proved by him, unle≈øs they ari≈øe out of the evidence produced again≈øt him, for the law pre≈øumeth the fact to have been founded in malice untill the contrary appears. You will therefore, carefully con≈øider and weigh the whole of the evidence given you re≈øpecting the attack, made upon the party of ≈øoldiers in general, and upon Montgomery in particular. In doing it, you will ob≈øerve the rules I have before mentioned, and not forget the part that ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes took in this unhappy affair, and if upon the whole it appears to you, that Montgomery was attacked, in ≈øuch a violent manner, as that his life was in immediate danger, or that he had ≈øufficient rea≈øon to think it was, and he thereupon fired and killed Attucks, for the pre≈øervation of his own life, it was ju≈øtifiable homicide; and he ought to be acquitted.‚ÄîIf you do not believe that was, the ca≈øe, but upon the evidence are ≈øatisfied, that he was by that a≈ø≈øembly, a≈ø≈øaulted with clubs and other weapons, and thereupon fired at the rioters and killed Attucks: then you ought to find him guilty of man≈ølaughter only. But if upon the evidence you believe, that Montgomery, without being previou≈øly a≈ø≈øaulted, fired, and killed Attucks: then you will find him guilty of muder But you mu≈øt know, that if this party of ≈øoldiers in general were pelted, with ≈ønow-balls, pieces of ice and ≈øticks, in anger, this, without more, amounts to an a≈ø≈øault, not only upon tho≈øe that were in fact ≈øtruck, but upon the whole party; and is ≈øuch an a≈ø≈øault as will reduce the killing to man≈ølaughter. And if you believe, what ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes have ≈øworn, that the people around the ≈øoldiers, and many of them armed with clubs, crouded upon the ≈øoldiers, and with the cry of, "Ru≈øh on, Kill them, Kill them, Knock them over," did in fact ru≈øh on, ≈øtrike at them with their clubs, and give Montgomery
≈øuch a blow, as to knock him down, as ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes ≈øay, or to make him ≈øally, or ≈øtagger, as others ≈øay‚Äîit will be ≈øufficient to ≈øhow, that his life was in immediate danger, or that he had ≈øufficient rea≈øon to think ≈øo.

It ≈øeems, a doctrine, has of late been advanced, "that ≈øoldiers while on duty, may upon no occa≈øion whatever fire upon their fellow ≈øubjects, without the order of a civil magi≈øtrate." This may po≈ø≈øibly account, for ≈øome of tho≈øe who attacked the ≈øolders, ≈øaying to them, "You dare not fire, we know you dare not fire."‚ÄîBut it ought to be known, that the law doth not countenance ≈øuch an ab≈øurd doctrine. A man by becoming a ≈øoldier, doth not thereby lo≈øe the right of ≈øelf-defence which is founded in the law of nature. Where any one is, without his own default, reduced to ≈øuch circum≈øtances, as that the laws of ≈øociety cannot avail him, the law con≈øiders him, "as ≈øtill in that in≈øtance under the protection of the law of nature." Fo≈øter 274, 5. This rule extends to ≈øoldiers as well as others; nay, while ≈øoldiers are in the immediate ≈øervice of the King, and the regular di≈øcharge of their duty, they rather come within the rea≈øon, of civil officers and their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, and ≈øo are alike under the peculiar protection of the law.

If you are ≈øatisfied upon the evidence, that Killroy killed Gray, you will then enquire, whether it was ju≈øtifiable, excu≈øable or felonious homicide, and if the latter, whether it was with, or without malice. If the attack was upon the party of ≈øoldiers in general, and in the manner I have ju≈øt mentioned, as ≈øome of the witne≈ø≈øes ≈øay it was, it is equally an a≈ø≈øault upon all, whether all were in fact ≈øtruck, or not, and makes no material difference, as to their re≈øpective right of firing: for a man is not obliged to wait until he is killed, or ≈øtruck, before he makes u≈øe of the nece≈ø≈øary means of ≈øelf defence. If the blows with clubs were, by an enraged multitude, aimed at the party in general, each one might rea≈øonably think his own life in danger; for though he e≈øcaped the fir≈øt blow, he might rea≈øonably expect more would follow, and could have no a≈ø≈øurance, that he ≈øhould be ≈øo fortunate as to e≈øcape all of them.

And therefore, I do not ≈øee but that Killroy is upon the ≈øame ≈øooting with Montgomery; and your verdict mu≈øt be
the ≈øame as to both, unle≈øs what Hemmingway ≈øwears Killroy ≈øaid, or the affray at the Rope-walk, or both, materially vary the ca≈øe. Hemmingway ≈øwears, that he and Killroy were talking about the town's people and the ≈øoldiers, and that Killroy ≈øaid. "He never would mi≈øs an opportunity, when he had one, to fire on the inhabitants, and that he had wanted to have an opportunity, ever ≈øince he landed." But he ≈øays, he cannot remember what words immediately preceded or followed, or at what particular time the words were uttered, nor does he know whether Killroy was jocular, or not. If the witne≈øs is not mi≈øtaken as to the words, the ≈øpeech was at lea≈øt, very imprudent and fooli≈øh. However, if Killroy, either in Je≈øt or in earne≈øt, uttered tho≈øe words, yet if the a≈ø≈øault upon him was ≈øuch, as would ju≈øtify his firing and killing, or alleviate it ≈øo as to make it but man≈ølaughter, that will not inhance the killing to murder. And though it has been ≈øworn that Killroy and other ≈øoldiers, had a quarrel with Gray and others, at the Ropewalk, a few days before the 5th March, yet it is not certain that Killroy then knew Gray, or armed at him in particular: But if Gray encouraged the a≈ø≈øault by clapping the a≈ø≈øailants on their backs, as Hink ‚Ä¢ ey ≈øwears he did, and Killroy ≈øaw this and knew him to be one of tho≈øe that were concerned in the affray at the Rope walk, this very circum≈øtance would have a natural tendency, to rai≈øe Killroy's pa≈ø≈øions, and throw him off his guard, much more than if the ≈øame things had been done by another per≈øon.‚ÄîIn the tumult of pa≈ø≈øion the voice of rea≈øon is not heard, and it is owing to the allowance the law makes for human frailty, that all unlawful voluntary homicide is not deemed murder. If there be "malice between A and B, and they meet ca≈øually, A a≈ø≈øaults B, and drives him to the wall, B in in his own defence kills A, this is ≈øe defendendo, and ≈øhall not be heightened by the former malice, into murder or homicide at large, for it was not a killing upon the account of the former malice, but upon a nece≈ø≈øity impo≈øed upon him by the a≈ø≈øault of A‚ñ™"1 Hale 479. So upon the ≈øame principle, where the a≈ø≈øault is ≈øuch as would make the killing but man≈ølaughter, if there had been no previous quarrel, the killing ought to be attributed to the a≈ø≈øault, unle≈øs the evidence clearly ≈øhews the contrary: an a≈ø≈øault being
known and allowed by law to be a provocation to kill, that will free the party from the guilt of murder; whereas neither words of reproach, nor actions expre≈ø≈øive of contempt, "are a prov ‚Ä¢ cation to u≈øe ≈øuch violence," Kely. 131. Fo≈øter 290. that is, the law doth not allow them to be, without an a≈ø≈øault, ≈øuch a provocation as will excu≈øe the killing, or make it any thing le≈øs than murder.
Upon the ≈øame principle, where the a≈ø≈øault is ≈øuch, as makes the killing man≈ølaughter, the killing ought to be attributed to the a≈ø≈øault, unle≈øs the evidence clearly ≈øhows the contrary.

This meeting of Killroy and Gray was ca≈øual upon the part of Killroy at lea≈øt; he was lawfully ordered to the place where he was and had no right to quit his ≈øtation without the leave of Capt. Pre≈ø ‚Ä¢ on; nor were any of the party obliged to retreat and give way to the rioters, but might lawfully ≈øtand, and repel force by force.

It is needle≈øs for me to ≈øay what you ought to do with regard to the other ≈øix pri≈øoners, in ca≈øe they had gone to the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, not to protect the Sentry, but to di≈øturb the peace, or after they got there and before the firing had agreed ≈øo to do; or in ca≈øe they had actually unlawfully abetted the killing: becau≈øe none of the≈øe things have been te≈øtified, nor can any of them be deduced from any thing which has been given to you in evidence.

I will return now to the ≈øoldiers and view their behaviour whil≈øt they were going upon duty at the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, and whil≈øt they were there. As they were going from the Main-guard to their po≈øt, to ≈øupport the Sentry, (who by the way behaved with a good temper of mind, in endeavouring to avoid a di≈øpute by attempting to get into the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, which he was by no means obliged to do,) I ≈øay, ‚Ä¢ s they were going down, Nathaniel Fo≈ødick ≈øays, they bid him make way but he refu≈øed: in≈øtead of forcing him to give way, he ≈øays, they gave way to him, and pa≈ø≈øed to their po≈øt; when they got there, they loaded; and John Gridley ≈øays, that, whil≈øt they were loading, he pa≈ø≈øed between the fires and they put up their guns to let him pa≈øs. Now con≈øider whether the pri≈øoners had any ju≈øt provocation to fire upon ihe inhabitants, for that ≈øome of them did fire, you can be in no doubt There are twenty five witne≈ø≈øes who have ≈øworn to ice, ≈ønow-balls, ≈øticks, &c. being thrown at the pri≈øoners, ten of whom, are wine≈ø≈øes for the Crown. Ye have one difficulty to ≈øolve, Gentlemen, and that is, that there were five per≈øons killed, and here are eight ≈øoldiers charged with murdering them. Now one witne≈øs ≈øays, that the Corporal did not fire, and Thowas Wilkin≈øon ≈øays, that the guns of the third or fourth man from the eighth fla≈øhed, ≈øo that there are two guns of eight not di≈øcharged and yet it is ≈øaid ≈øeven were fired This evinces the uncertainty of ≈øome of the te≈øtimonies. div.p:
I know all the pri≈øoners: I was in King-≈øtreet on the evening of the 5th March, when the party of ≈øoldiers at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe fired on the people a≈ø≈øembled in King ≈øtreet.‚Äî I then ≈øaw two fla≈øhes from the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, but who fired them cannot tell, one of the fla≈øhes came from the balcony of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, and the other from a chamber window of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, the ≈øecond window from the corner of Royal exchange-lane, and the third from the balcony; I ≈øaw a per≈øon in the balcony, with ≈øomething in his hand, a gun or pi≈øtol. I al≈øo ≈øaw a fla≈øh from the middle window of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe chamber, between the balcony and Royal-exchange-lane, I cannot tell whether this fla≈øh came from a gun or a pi≈øtol, the muzzel was thru≈øt out of the window above a yard, the fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh was in≈øide. div.head: Charles Bourgat, a French boy, born at Bourdeux, ≈øervant to Mr. Manwarring, ≈øworn.
div.p:
I am an apprentice to Mr. Edward Manwarring. On the evening of the 5th March la≈øt, I was at Mr. Hud≈øon's in Back-≈øtreet, at the North end, where my ma≈øter then lodged, Mr. Hud≈øon and his wife were at home; when the bells rung I ran into King ≈øtreet, and to the door of the Cu≈øtomhou≈øe which was on a jarr partly open, and a young man one Green, he with one eye, (pointing to Hammond Green) opened the door and pulled me in; two or three gentlemen came down ≈øtairs, and one of them a tall man, pulled me up ≈øtairs, and ≈øaid to me, you mu≈øt fire, the tall man gave me a gun, and ≈øaid to me "if you don't fire I'll kill you."‚Äî I went up ≈øtairs and ≈øtood at a front window in the chamber, and the tall man loaded two guns with two balls each, and I fired them both; as ≈øoon as I had fired one gun, he, the tall man, ≈øaid again to me, "if you don't fire I will kill
you." He had a cane with a ≈øword in it in his hand, and compelled me to fire both the guns. After I had fired the≈øe two guns, Mr. Manwarring fired one gun al≈øo out of the ≈øame window. The tall man loaded the three guns, and I ≈øee him put the balls into each of them and heard them go gown. The two guns I fired, I pointed up the ≈øtreet and in the air. When my ma≈øter Mr. Manwarring pointed his gun out of the window I was in the room, but went out and was on the ≈øtairs before his gun went off, I heard it, but did not ≈øee it. As ≈øoon as I had fired, the tall man took me down ≈øtairs, and ≈øaid he would give me money if I would not tell: I replied, I did not want any money, but if I was called before the Ju≈øtices, I would tell the truth. There was a candle in the chamber, but I cannot tell whether there were one or two windows in it. When I came up into the chamber, there were two guns in it, I fired twice out of the ≈øame gun, but I cannot tell whether Mr. Manwarring fired the ≈øame gun I did. At the time I and my ma≈øter fired, the ≈øtreet below was full of people, and the mob were throwing ≈øticks, ≈ønow-balls, &c. It was pretty dark, but I don't know but there might be a little moon. I can't tell whether the guns my ma≈øter and I fired, were fired before or after the firing by the ≈øoldiers. When I went from Mr. Hud≈øon's to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, I pa≈ø≈øed through the lane that leads from the Market to the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe, (Royal-exchange-lane) and I did not ≈øee the Sentry box or any ≈øoldiers near the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe; there were many people round there in the ≈øtreet. I returned to Mr. Hud≈øon's hou≈øe, Mr Hud≈øon and his wife were then at home, and no other per≈øon in the hou≈øe. Upon being again a≈øked where he was when he heard the report of his ma≈øter's gun? Says, he was quite down ≈øtairs. Upon being a≈øked whether he was not ≈øoon after his commitment taken out of goal and
examined by Mr. Molineux? Says, he was in the goaler's hou≈øe with Mrs. Otis the pri≈øon keeper's wife, Mr. Wallis, deputy ≈øheriff, and Mr. Molineux, and that the latter told him to tell the truth: and that this was previous to his examination before the Ju≈øtices.
Mr. Quincy declaring he had no further evidence to produce on the part of the Crown. The pri≈øoners de≈øired the following witne≈ø≈øes might be ≈øworn and examined, which was done accordingly.

Mr. Edward Paine, George Bethane, and Edward Davis, Merchants, and Harri≈øon Gray junr. they te≈øtified, That they ≈øtood oppo≈øite the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt, when the firing was in King ≈øtreet that their faces were towards the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe. That the moon ≈øhone ≈øtrong on the hou≈øe, that they did not ≈øee the balcony door of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe open that evening, or any per≈øon in the balcony, or any window in the front of the hou≈øe open, or guns fired from either the balcony or any of the windows in the front of the hou≈øe, and are fully ≈øatisfied no ≈øuch thing could have happened while the ≈øoldiers were there without their ob≈øerving it. That they ≈øtood oppo≈øite the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe in full view of it from he time the ≈øoldiers fir≈øt came down there until all the guns were di≈øcharged. That they are ≈øatisfied the whole of the firing was from the ≈øtreet, and that all above was quiet, and no light in any of the front rooms of the Cu≈øtom hou≈øe. Mr. Davis added, that ≈øoon after the firing he ≈øaw two women ≈øtanding at the chamber window of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe, which is next to Royal-exchange-lane, with their hands under their aprons, in the po≈øture of ≈øpectators.

div.head: Elizabeth Avery, ≈øworn.
div.p:
I lived with Mr. Bartholemew Green at the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe on the 5th of March la≈øt, and when the noi≈øe was in the ≈øtreet, before the hou≈øe I went with (Hammond Green the pri≈øoner at the bar) Nancey Green and Mary Rogers up into that chamber of the hou≈øe, which is next to Royal exchange-lane and right over the Sentry box as it then ≈øtood, and from the we≈øt window in that room ≈øaw the party of ≈øoldiers come down from the Main-guard to the Sentry; I tarried in this room till the firing was all over, and the ≈øoldiers had returned from whence they came. There was no other per≈øon in this room, (except them I have mentioned) during the
whole time of my being there, but Thomas Greenwood who came in and went out again in a minute. Nor was there any gun or pi≈øtol, or candle in the room. Nor was the door of the balcony or any of the windows of the chamber opened that evening to my knowledge, and I verily believe they were not. The French Boy, who has ju≈øt been ≈øworn in this Court was not there that evening, nor did I ever ≈øee him there in my life. Nor was Mr. Manwarring or Mr. Munroe there on that evening.
Ann Green daughter of Mr. Bartholemew Green, was then ≈øworn, and confirmed in every particular the te≈øtimony of Elizabeth Avery, the preccedihg witne≈øs.

div.head: Elizabeth Hud≈øon, the wife of Mr. John Hud≈øon, with whom Mr. Manwarring boarded on the evening of the 5th of March l ‚Ä¢ , was ≈øworn.
div.p:
She depo≈øed that on the evening of the 5th of March, Mr. Edward Manwarring was at her hou≈øe, in Back ≈øtreet at the northerly part of the town, together with Mr. John Munroe and one Mr. Warwell, that the French Boy, Charles Bourgat was al≈øo there. That when the bells rung, ≈øhe, Mr. Manwarring and the two Gentlemen who were with him, went to a window fro ‚Ä¢ ting the ≈øtreet to inquire where the fire was, ≈øuppo≈øing that occa≈øioned the ringing of the bells. That hearing from the conver≈øation in the ≈øtreet there was no fire but ≈øome di≈øturbance, they all left the window, and Me≈ø≈ørs. Manwarring, Munroe and Warwell, went into Mr. Manwarring's chamber. That her the depone ‚Ä¢ t's hu≈øband was out of town that evening, and ≈øhe being afraid to be alone went into Mr. Manwarring's room, and tarried there until all the bells were done ringing and the di≈øturbance was all over. That Mr. Manwarring called his ≈øervant boy Charles Bourgat up into the room where the deponent and the others were, and kept him there the whole evening, until after the bells had all cea≈øed ringing, and until after ten o'clock, That ≈øhe is certain the French boy, Charles Bourgat, was not out of her ≈øight five minutes at a time, from the time the bells began to ring until after ten o'clock. Nor does ≈øhe know that he went out of the hou≈øe during that night. That M ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øes, Manwarring, Munroe and Warwell, were at her hou≈øe from the du≈øk of evening until about half after ten o'clock, and did not go out of the hou≈øe during that whole time. That Mr. Munroe about
half after ten o'clock ≈øaid he would go home to his lodgings, which Mr. Manwarring endeavoured to di≈ø≈øuade him from, telling him he might be mole≈øted, as he went thro' the ≈øtreet: He Munroe however went away, but Mr. Manwarring and Mr. Warwell tarried in the hou≈øe all night.

The Court then inquired of the boy, whether he heard and under≈øtood what Mrs. Hud≈øon had te≈øtified, he ≈øaid yes, and that her account was fal≈øe, and that what he him≈øelf had now declared in Court, was the truth and nothing but the truth.

Mr. John Lovell, Mr. Edward Marriot, Mr. Ellwin of Quebec, and Mr. Philip Dumare≈øque were then ≈øworn as interpreters; and the boy was re-examined in French and again affirmed in French to ≈øaid interpreters, all the material parts of his te≈øtimony as he had given it in Engli≈øh before.

div.head: James Penny, was then called and ≈øworn.
div.p: He depo≈øed that he was in goal in Bo≈øton for debt, that while there Charles Bourgat the French boy, voluntarily, and without any threats or per≈øua≈øion declared to him, and one Eli≈øha Ingraham then al≈øo a pri≈øoner for debt in ≈øaid goal‚Äî "That what he te≈øtified to the Grand Jury and before the Ju≈øtices on his examination with regard to his ma≈øter Edward Manwarring, and John Munroe, their firing out of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt, was in every paticular fal≈øe, and that he did ≈øwear in that manner by the per≈øua≈øion of William Molineux, who told him he would take him from his ma≈øter and provide for him, and that Mr. Molineux frightned him by telling him if he refu≈øed to ≈øwear again≈øt his ma≈øter and Mr. Munro the mob in Bo≈øton would kill him: and farther that Mrs. Waldron, the wife of Mr. Waldron a taylor in Back ≈øtreet, who ≈øells ginger bread and drams, gave him the ≈øaid Charles ginger bread and chee≈øe, and de≈øired him to ≈øwear again≈øt his ma≈øter." The ≈øaid Charles farther declared, "that neither he nor his ma≈øter Edward Manwarring were at the Cu≈øtomhou≈øe at any time on the evening of the 5th of March la≈øt."

Charles Bourgat the French boy po≈øitively denied he ever made any ≈øuch declaration to Mr. James Penny or any other per≈øon; and de≈øired that one Wm. Page a cabinet maker, who was then al≈øo pri≈øoner for debt in the ≈øaid goal, might be called, and examined relative to the conduct of ≈øaid
Penny, in procuring this declaration.‚ÄîPage was accordingly ≈øworn. He depo≈øed that ≈øome time after Manwarring and Munroe were indicted, he ≈øaw James Penny the former witne≈øs at the window of the room where Charles Bourgat was confined, on the back-≈øide of the goal, that Penny had a pen in his hand, a paper laying before him, and was talking earne≈øtly and roughly to the boy. That he this deponent heard Mr. Penny ≈øpeak quick to the boy, and a≈øked him "Is this true," but that he could not hear what the boy ≈øaid, though he li≈øtened.‚ÄîOn being a≈øked, whether he ever ≈øaw the boy carried out of the goal to Mr. Otis the pri≈øon-keeper's hou≈øe by Mr. Molineux to be examined, ≈øaid that after Penny had told of this confe≈ø≈øion of the boys, Mr. Molineux did come to the goal and the boy was taken out and carried into Mr. Otis's hou≈øe, and there declared he never made the confe≈ø≈øion or declaration Penny pretended, and al≈øo that Mr. Molineux never urged or required him to ≈øay any thing but the truth.
